In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: ou full small and therto softe and rede
But sikirly she had a faire forhede
For hardly she was not vndergrowe
It was almoste a span brode as y trowe
Full fetise was here Cloke as y was ware
Of small corall a boute here arme she bare
A peire of bedys gaudid all with grene .
And thereon hynge a broche of golde full shene
On which was first writen a crowned . A .
And aftur . Amor vincit omia
A nother Nonne with hure had she
That was hure Chapleyne . and prestis the
A Monke there was . a faire for the Mastrie
An oute Rider that loved well venerie
A manly man to be an Abbot able
Full many a deynte hors had he in his stable
And when he rode men myght his bridell here
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doith the Chapell Belle
There as this lorde was keper of the Selle
The rule of Seynte Maury or of Seynt Beneit
Bycause it was olde and somdell streit
This ilke Monke lete olde thynges pace
And hilde aftᵃ the newe worldisspace
He gave not of that texte a Pullyd hen
That seith that hunters ben none holy men
Ne that a Monke . whan he is rechelesse
Ys likenyd to a Fysshe that is waterlesse
This is to sayne . a Monke oute of his Cloystre
But that Texte hilde he not worth an Oystre
And y saide his opyniou was good
What shulde he stodye and make hym self wood
Vppon a boke in Cloystre all day to poure
Or swynke with his hondys and laboure
As Austyn haue bid the . hou shall the worlde be served
Let Austyn haue his swynke to hym reservid
Therefore he was a praunsoure a right
Greihoundys had he that weren full light
On prikkyng . and huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for nothyng wolde he spare
I sawe his slevis purfilid at the honde
With grice . and that the fynest in the londe
And for to fasten his hode vnde his chyn
He hadde of golde wrought a full curious pyn
A love knot in the grettir ende there was
His hede was balled . that shone as eny glas
And eke his face . as he . had be anoynte
He was a lorde full fatte . and in gode poynte
Hys yeen stepe were . and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a furneys of lede
His botys souple . his hors in grete state
Nowe certayne he was a faire prelate
He was not pale . as it were a payned goste
A fatte Swan lovid he . best of eny roste
His Palfraye was as broun as a berye
¶ A Frere there was eke a wantou and a merye
A lymytoure and a full solempne man
In the ordres .iiijᵒʳ. is none so well that can
So moche of dalyaunce and faire langage
He had made full many a faire mariage
Of yonge wymmen at his owne cost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble post
Full well belovid and famylier was he
With Frankelens oủer/ree all in his Contre
And with worthy wymmen of the toun
For he had pouere of Confessyoun
As he saide hym self more than a Curate
For of his ordre he was licenciate
Full swetely harde he Confessioun
And plesaunt was his absolucioun
He was an easy man to yeve penaunce
There as he wist to haue agood petaunce
For vnto a pore ordre for to geve
Is signe that a man is well shreve
For yif he gave he durst make a vaunte
He wist well that aman was repentaunte
For many a man is so harde of harte
He may not wepe all though hym sore smarte
Therfore in stede of penaunce and prayers
Men moste geve silvir to the pore fryers
His Tipet was ay farshed full of knyvis
And pynnys for to geve faire wyvis
And certeynly he had a mery note
Well coude he synge and pley on Rote
Of yeddynges he bare vttirly the prise
His necke was white . as floure delise
Therto he was stronge . as a Champioun
He knewe the Taủer/renys . well in eủer/rey Toun
And eủer/rey hostler and Tapsterre
Better than a laser or Beggesterre
For vnto suche a worthy man as he
Accordith not as to his facalte
To haue with seke lazers acquayntaunce
It is not honest it may not avaunce
For to dele with suche poraile
But all with the Riche and Sellers of vitaile
And oủer/ree all there profite shulde a rise
Curtays he was and lowly of servise
There was no man nowhere so vertuous
He was the best Begger in his hous
For though a widowe had not but a sho
So plesaunte was his In Principio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthyng or he went
His purchas was well bettre than his Rent
And rage he couth as it had ben a whelpe
In love days there coude he moche helpe
For there he was not like a Cloysterere
With a threde bare Cope as ys a scolere
But he was like a Mastere or a pope
Of double worsted was his semy Cope
Rounde as eny Belle . oute of the presse
Somwhat he lispyd for his wantounesse
To make his Englisshe swete on his tonge
And in his harpyng . whan that he had songe
His yeen twynklyd in his hede aright
As doith the sterres in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytoure was clepid hubbard
A Marchaunte there was with a forked bard
In motle and high vppon an hors he sate
And on his hede a Flaundrisshe be hatte
His botes claspid faire and fetously
His resons he spake full solempnely
Sownyng alway the encres of his wynnyng
He wolde the See were kepte for eny thyng
Betwene Middilburgh and Orwell
Well coude he in Eschaunges Rentes sell
This worthy man full well his witte bisette
There wist no wight that he was in dette
So stedfastly did he with his goủer/renaunce
With his bargeynes and with his chevisaunce
Forsothe he was a worthy man with alle
But sothe to sayne y not what men hym calle
A Clerke there was of Oxonford also
That vnto logik had longe y go
And lene was his hors as it were a Rake
And he was not right fatte y vndertake
But lokid holowe . and therto sobirly
Full threde bare was his oủer/reest courtby
For as yit he hadde gete hym none benefise
He was not worldly to haue an offise
For hym was leủer/ree to haue atte his beddes hede
xxᵗⁱ . bokys clad in blacke and rede
Of Aristotle and of his Philophie
Then riche Robys Fidell . or sawtrie
But all be it though . he were a Philosophre
Yit had he but litle golde in his cofre
But all that he from his frendys hente
On bokys and on lernyng he it spente
And besily gan for the soulys praye
Of them that gave hym wherewith to scolaye
Of stodye toke he moste cure and hede
Not a worde spake he more than was nede
And that was seyde in forme and reủer/reence
And shorte and quyk and full of high sentence
Sownyng in morall vertue was his speche
Gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche
A Seriaunte of lawe there was ware and wise
That full often had bene atte . parvise
That was full riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of gre reủer/reence
He semed such his wordis were so wise
Iustise had he be full oftyn in assise
Bothe bi patent . and pleyne commyssiou
For his science and his high renown
Of Fees and Robes had he many one
So grete a purchasoure was nowhere none
All was Fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not be in suspecte
Nowhere so esy aman there nas
And yit he semed bisier than he was
In termys had he cas and domys alle
That fro the tyme of kynge willᵃm were falle
Therto coude he endite and make a thynge
There coude noman pynche at his writynge
And eủer/rey statute coude he playne by rote
He rode but homly in a medley cote
Girt with a seint of silke with barres smale
Of his aray telle y no lengre tale
A Franklyn was in this companye
White was his berde . as is the daisye
Of his complexiou he was sangwyn
Well loved he by the morowe a soppe in wyn
To lyve in delite was eủer/ree his wone
For he was Epicurious owne sonne
That hilde opynyou that pleyne delite
Was verraye . Felitite parfite
An householdre and that a grete was he
The grettist on of all his Contre
His brede his ale . was alway aftur one
A better vyned man was nowhere none
Withoute Bakemete was neủer/ree his house
Off fysshe and flesshe and that so plenteuouse
It snewed in his house of mete and drynke
Of all deyntees that eny man can thynke
Aftur the sondry seasons of the yere
So chaunged he his mete and his sopere
Full many a fatte partriche had he in mue
And many a Breme and many a luce in Stue
Woo was his Coke but yif his sause were
Poynaunt and sharpe and redy all his gere
His table dormant in his halle alway
Stode redy coủer/reyd all the longe day
Atte the cessions there was he lorde and Syre
Full oftyn tyme he was knyght of the Shyre
And an hanlaas and a Gipsiere all of silke
Hynge at his girdill as white as morowe mylke
A Shiref had he be and a Coıı̄unntoure
Was nowhere suche a worthy vauasoure
An habirdassher . and a Carpentere
A wever . a Dyer . and a Tapicere
And they were clothid all in one lyủer/reeye
Of a solempne and a grete fraternytye
Full fresshe and newe here gere piked was
Here knyvis were not chapid with bras
But all with silvyr wrought full clene and well
Here Girdyls and here pouches eủer/rey delle
Well semed eche of them a faire Burgeys
To sitte in the yelde hall vppon the deys
Eủer/reyche for the wisedom that he can
Was shaply to be an aldreman
For catell had they ynough and rente
And eke here wivys wolde it well assente
And elles certayne they weren to blame
It is full faire to be clepid Madame
And go to vigiles all a fore
And haue a mantell roially bore
A Coke they hadde with hem for the nonys
To boyle the Chykenys with the mary bonys
And pouder Marchant tarte and galyngale
Well coude he knowe a draught of londou ale
He coude roste . sithe . boyle . and frye
Make mortrewes and well bake a pye
But grete harme was it as thought me
That on his shynne a mormall had he
And Blaumangere made he with the best
A Shipman there was that wd ferre by west
For ought that y wote he was of dertmouth
He rode vppon a Rouncy as well as he couth
In a gowne of faldyng vnto the kne
A dagger hangyng with a lace had he
A boute his necke vnder his arme a doun
The hote Some had made his hewe al broun
And certeynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draught of wyne had he drawe
From Burdeuxwarde while the Chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Yif that he faught . and had the higher hande
By watere he sente it home from eủer/rey lande
But to rekyn well of his crafte the tydes
The stremes and the strondes hym besides
His herborowe his mone and his lodes manage
There was none suche from hull of Cartage
Hardye he was and wise y vndertake
With many a tempest . had his berde be shake
He knewe all the havyns as they were
Fro Goutlonde to the Cape of Fenestere
And eủer/rey kryke fro Brutaygne in to Spayne
His Barge was clepid the Magdeleyne
¶ With vs there was a doctor of Phisike
In all this worlde was none hym like
To speke of phisik and of surgery
For he was groundid in Astronomye
He kepte his pacient . a full grete dell
In houris by his magik naturell
Well coude he fortune the ascendent
Of his ymagis . for bi his pacient
He knewe the cause of eủer/rey maladye
Whether it were colde hote moyst or drye
And whereof it engendrid and of what humoure
He was a verrey parfite practisoure
The cause he knewe . and of his harme the Rote
Anon he gaf the sikman his Bote
Full redy had he all his Appoticaries
To sende hym dreigges . and his lettuaries
For eche of them made other for to wynne
Here Frenship was not newe to begynne
Well knewe he the olde Esculapius
And Diastorides and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras and Galien
Serapiou Basis and Auicien
Amerois Damastien and Constantyn
Bernardus Gatisden . and Gilbertyn
Of his diet mesurable was he
For he was of none suꝑper/parfluyte
But of grete norisshyng and digestible
His stody was but litle on the bible
In Sangwyn and in peers clad with all
Lyvid with Taffitta and Sendall
And yet he was but easy of dispence
For he kepte that he wan in the pestlence
For golde in phisike is accordiall
Therfore he lovid golde in speciall
A good wyf the was . of beside Bathe
But she was somdele deef . and that was scathe
Of Clothe makyng . she had suche an haunte
That she passed hem of ypres and of Gaunte
In all the parisshe wif was ther none
That to offryng a fore hure shulde gone
And yif ther did certayne so wroth was she
That she was oute of alle cherite
Here kerchefs weren of fyne grounde
I durst swere they weyd a pounde
That on the sonday were vppon here hede
Here hosyn were of fyne scarlet rede
Full streite tyed and shone moyst and newe
Bolde was hure face faire and rede of hewe
She was a worthy womman all hure lyve
Husbondes atte the Churche dore had she fyve
Withoute other compaignye in hure youthe
But thereof nedith nedith not to speke of noughte
And thrise had she be at Ierlme
She had passed many a straunge streme
At Rome had she be and at Babiloyne
In Galice at Seynte Iames and at Coleyne
She coude of moche wandryng by the wey
Gaptothed was she the sothe to sey
Vppon an Amblere easely she satte
Well y wympled and on hure hede an hatte
As brode at it were a bokelere or a targe
A fote mantell a boute hure heppis large
And on hure fete a peyre of sporys sharpe
In felauship coude she laugh and carpe
The remedyes of love the coude ꝑper/parchaunce
For of that arte she knewe the olde daunce
A good man there was of Religyoun
That was a ꝑper/parsoıı̄un of a poure toun
But riche he was of holy thought and werke
He was also a lerned man d and a Clerke
That Cristes gospell truly wolde teche
His parisshynes deuoutly wolde he preche
Benygne he was and wondre diligent
And in adủer/resite full abidyng and pacient
For which he was preysed often sithis
Full lothe were hym to curse for his tithis
But rather wolde hem yeve oute of doute
Vnto his pore parisshenes a boute
Of his offryng and eke of his substaunce
He coude haue yn litle thyng suffisaunce
Wyde was his parisshe and houses ferre a sondre
But he ne lette not for Reyne ne for thondre
In sekenesse and in myschief to visite
The ferthest in his parisshe moche and lite
Vppon his fete . and in his hande a staff
This noble ensample to his shepe he yaff
That furst he wrought and afturwarde taught
Oute of the gospell he tho wordys raught
And this figure he added eke therto
That yif golde rustyd . what shulde Iron do
For yif apreste be foule on whom we trust
No wondre is though a lewid man rust
And shame it is yif a preste take kepe
A shetyn Shepherd and a clene shepe
Well aught a preste ensample for to yeve
By hys clennesse hou his shepe shulde leve
He sette not his benefice for to hire
Ant lette his shepe . accombred be in the myre
Ne renne to londoıı̄un to seynte Poules
To seche hym a Chauntry there for Soules
Or be with a Brotherhood witholde
But dwell atte home . and kepe well his folde
So that the wolf make it not myscarye
He was a Shepherde . and not a mersionarye
And though he holy were and vertuouse
He was not with symple men dispitouse
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his speche discrete and benygne
To drawe folke to heven by fairenesse
By good ensample this was his bisynesse
But and he knewe eny ꝑper/parsone obstynate
Whether he were of high or lowe estate
Hym wolde he snebbe sharpely for the nonys
A bettre preste y trowe nowhere none ys
He waytith aftᵃ no pompe ne reủer/reence
Ne made hym a spiced conscience
But Cristis lore and his a Postels twelf
He taught but furst he did it hym self
With hym there was a plough man his brothere
That had lad of dunge many a fothere
A true Swynker and a good was he
Lyvyng in pees and ꝑper/parfite Charite
God lovid he best . with all his hole herte
At all tymes though he gamed or smerte
And than his nyghtboure right as hym self
He wolde thresshe and eke dike and delf
For cristis sake for eủer/rey poure wight
Withoute hire yif it lay in his myght
His tythis payde he full faire and wele
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and of his catele
In a Tabard he rode vppon a meere
¶ There was also a Reve . and a Mellere
A Sompnoure and a Pardonere also
A Manciple ⁊and my self there were nomo
The Miller was a stoute carle for the nonys
Full bigge he was of body and of bonys
That previd well . for wher eủer/ree he cam
At the wrastlyng he wolde haue the Ram
He was shorte shuldrid brode . and a thicke knarre
There was no dore but he wolde lift of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his hede
His berde . as eny Sowe or fox was rede
And therto brode as it were a spade
Vppon the coppe . of the nose he hadde
A werte and theruppon stode a tufte of heris
Redde as the brystillys of a Sowes erys
His nose thrillys blacke were and wide
A Swerde and a Buklere he bare by his side
His mowth was as grete as a furneis
He was a Iangler and a Golyardeis
And that was moste synne and harlotries
Well coude he stele corn and stele thries
And yit he had a thombe of gold ꝑper/parde
A white Cote and a blewe hode wered he
A Bagpipe well coude he blowe and sowne
And therewith all he brought vs oute of towne
¶ A gentill Manciple there was of a Temple
Of which all Catours myght take an example
For to be wise in beyng of Vitaille
For whethir he payde or toke by taille
Ay wayted he so in his accate
That he was ay bifore and in good estate
Nowe is not that of god a full faire grace
That suche a lewede mannys witte shall pace
The wisedom of an hepe of lerned men
That mastres haue hadde mo than thrise ten
That of lawe weren experte and curyouse
Of which there were . an . xijelf . in an house
Worthy to be Stuardys of Rente and londe
Of eny lorde that is in Englonde
To make hym lyve by his ꝓpropre good
In honoure doutlesse but yif he were wood
Or lyve as scarsly as hym lust desire
And able to helpe all a Shire
In many cas that myght falle or happe
And yit this Manciple set theire althir cappe
The Reve was a sclendre colerikman
His berde was shave as nygh as eủer/ree he can
His here was by his eeris full rounde shorn
His toppe was dockid like a preste biforn
Full longe were his leggis and full lene
Like a staff there was no calf sene
Well coude he kepe a Garner and a bynne
There was none Auditor couth on hym wynne
Well wist he by the drought and by the reyne
The yeldyng of his corne and of his greyne
His lordys shepe his Neete his deyrie
His swyne his hors his store and his pultrie
Was hooliche in this Reves goủer/renyng
And by his couenaunt he yave the rekenyng
Sith that his lorde was . xxᵗⁱ . yere of Age
There coude noman brynge hym a in a rerage
There was no Balyf herde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe here sleight and here covyne
They were drad of hym as of the dethe
His wonnyng was faire vppon an hethe
With grene trees shadowed was his place
He coude better then his lorde purchace
Full riche he was storid privelye
His lorde he coude please full subtellye
To yeve and lene hym of his owne good
And haue a thanke and yit a gowne and a hood
This Reve sate vppon a well good stotte
All pomell gray . and he hight Scotte
Lerned he had in youth a good mystere
He was a good wright and a Carpentere
A longe surcote of peers a bove he hadde
And by his side he bare a lusty bladde
Of Nor Folke was this Reve of which telle
Besides a Towne men clepe Bladwelle
Tukkyd he was as is a Frere a boute
And eủer/ree he rode hyndrest of the route
A Sompnoure there was with vs in tha place
That hadde a fyre rede cherubyns face
Full sausefleme he was with yeen narowe
As hote he was and erous like a sparowe
With scalled browes ke and pilled berde
Of his visage children were sore aferde
There was neyther litarge . quyk silủer/ree . ne Brymston
Borace Ceruse ne Oyle of tartre noon
Ne oygnement that well can clense and bite
That hym myght helpe of his welkes white
Ne of the knobbes sittyng in his chekes
Well lovid he garlyk oynyouns and lekes
And for to drynke stronge wyne as red as blode
Than wolde he . speke and crie as he were wode
And whan that he well dronke the wyne
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe termys had he tweyne or thre
That he had lerned oute of som decre
No wondre ys he herde it all the day
And eke he knowe well hou that a Iay
Can clepe watte as well as can the pope
But who so clo coude in other thynges hym grope
Than had he spendid all his Philosophye
Ay questio quid Iuris wolde he crye
He was a gentill harlot and a kynde
A betre felawe shulde men nowhere fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felawe to haue his Concubyne
Twelvemoneth and excuse hym at the full
Well prively eke a fynche coude he pull
And yif he founde owhere a good felawe
He wolde teche hym to haue none awe
In suche case of this archedekyns curs
But yif a mannys soule hynge in his purs
For with his purs he shulde pyned be
Purs is the Archedekyns helle quod he
But well y wote he lieth right in dede
Of cursyng owith eủer/rey man gilty to drede
For curs wolle sle right as a soylyng savith
And also a ware hym of a sygnifycavith
In daungere had he atte his owne gyse
Alle the yonge gyrles of the diocise
And knewe here counsaille and was all here rede
A Garlonde he had sette vppon his hede
As grete as it were for an ale stake
A Bokelere had he made of a Cake
With hym there rode a gentill Pardonere
Of Rouncivale his felawe and his compere
That streight was comen fro the Courte of Rome
Full loude he songe com hither love com tome
This Sompnoure bare to hym a stif Burdou
Was neủer/ree Trumpe of half so grete a sown
This pardonere had here . as yelowe as eny wex
But smothe hynge it as doith a strike of flex
By ouncis hynge his lokkys that he hadde
And therewith his shurdres it oủer/ree spradde
But thynne it lay by culpons on and on
And an hode for Iolyte wered he non
For it was trussed vppe in his walette
Hym thought he rode all of the newe Iette
Disshevele saue his hat he rode all bare
With glaryng yeen as hath an hare
A vernacle had he sewed on his Cappe
His walet lay be forn hym in his lappe
Fret full of pardou come fro Rome all hote
A voyce he hadde as small as hath a gote
No berde he hadde ne neủer/ree shulde haue
As smothe it was . as it were newe shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his Crafte fro Berwik vnto ware
Ne was there suche another Pardonere
For in his male he a feyre pelowe bere
Which as he saide than . was oure lady veile
He saide he had eke a gobet of the seile
That seynte Petyr had when that he went
Vppon the See . there Ihu Criste hym hent
He had a Crosse of latou full of stonys
And in a glas he had many piggis bonys
But with thise reliquys whan that he fonde
A pore parsou dwellyng vplonde
Vppon a day he gate hym more money
Than did the parsou in monethis twey
And thus with his feyned flatrye and Iapys
He made the parsou and the peple his Apys
But truly to telle of hym at the laste
He was in churche a noble ecciaste
Well coude he rede a lessoıı̄un or a storye
But alther beste he songe an affertorye
For well he wist whan that songe was sunge
He moste preche and well file his tunge
To wynne silvir . as he full well coude
Therfore he songe so mery and so loude
¶ Nowe haue y tolde you sothely l in a clause
The state . the aray . the nombre and the cause
Why that assembled was all this companye
In Southwerke at that Ientill hosterye
That hight the Tabarde fast by the belle
But nowe it ys tyme to you for to telle
Howe that we bare vs that ylke nyght
When we were in that hosterye alyght
And aftur woll y tell of oure viage
And all the remenaunt of oure pilgrimage
But furst y pray you of youre curtesye
That ye arette it nat to my vylonye
That that y pleynly speke in this matere
To telle you here wordys and here chere
Ne though y speke not here wordes propirly
For this ye knowe as well a y
Who so shall telle a tale aftir aman
He moste reherce it as nygh as eủer/ree he can
Eủer/rey worde yif it be in his charge
Speke he neủer/ree so rudely ne so large
Or ellys he mot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thynges or fynde wordes newe
He may not spare all though it were his brothere
He mote aswell say one . worde as a nothere
Criste spake hym self full brode in holy writte
And well ye wote no vylany is ytte
Eke Plato seith who so can hym rede
The wordes moste be Cosyn to the dede
Also y pray you to for yeve it me
Though y haue not sette folke in here degree
Here in this tale . as that they shulde stonde
My wit is short yᵉ may well vnderstonde
Grete chere made oure hoste vs eủer/reychone
And to souper . sette we vs anone
He servid vs with vitaile at the beste
Stronge was the wyne and well to drynke vs leste
A semely man oure . hoste was with alle
For to be a Marchall yn an halle
A large man he was with yeen stepe
A fairer Burgeys was ther none in Chepe
Bolde of his speche wise and well y taught
And of Manhode lakkid hym right naught
Eke he was therto right a mery man
And aftur sopere playe he began
And speke of myrthe amonge other thyng
Whan that we had made oure rekenyng
He seide lo lordyngis truly
Ye be to me right welcom hertly
For by my trouth yif that y sha nat lye
I sawe nat this yere so mery accompanye
Attones in this herborowgh as ys nowe
Fayne wolde I do you myrth and y wist howe
And of a myrthe y am right nowe bethought
To don you ease and it shall cost you nought
Ye go to Caunterbury god you spede
That blisfull Martir there quyte youre mede
And well y wote as ye gone by the wey
Ye shapen you to talkyn and to pley
For truly comfort ne myrth is it none
To ride by the way as dom as a stone
And therfore wolde y make you disporte
As y seide erst . and do you som comforte
And yif you like all by on assent
To stonde this tyme at my Iugement
And for to werkyn as y shall you sey
To morowe when ye ride by the wey
Nowe by my faders soule that ys dede
But ye be mery y woll yeve you my hede
Holde vp youre handys withouten more speche
Oure counsaile was not longe forto seche
Vs thought it was nought worth to make it uyce
And grauntid hym withoute more advice
And bade hym sey all his verdite as hym leste
Lordynges quod he nowe herknyth for the beste
But take it not I pray you at disdayne
This is the poynt to speke it shorte and pleyne
That eche of you to shorte with youre wey
In this viage shall . telle tales twey
To Caunterburywarde y mene it so
And homward he shall telle other two
Of aventuris that somtyme haue befalle
And which of you berith hym beste of alle
That is to say that tellith yn this case
Tales of moste scentence and solase
Shall haue a Sopere at oure althir cost
Here in this place sittyng by the post
When that we commyn a geyn fro Caunterburye
And forto make you the more myrye
I will my self goodly with you ride
Right at myn owne cost and be youre gide
And who so will my Iugement with sey
Shall paie for all that we spende by the wey
And yif ye vouchesafe it be so
Telle me anon withoute wordis mo
And y woll erly shape me therfore
This was grauntid . and oure othes swore
With full glad harte . and praied hym alsoo
That he wolde vouchesaf so to doo
And that he wolde be oure goủer/renoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And sette a Sopere at a certeyne prise
And we will ruelid be at youre devise
In hygh and lowe and thus by one assent
We be accordid to youre Iugement
And thereuppon the wyne was fet anon
We drunke and wente to rest eủer/reychon
Withoute eny lenger tareyng
Amorowe when that the day gan spryng
Vp rose oure hoste and was all oure althir cokke
And gadred vs to gedre on a flokke
And furth we riden a softe pase
Vnto the watryng of seynte Thomase
And there oure hoste gan his Bridell to areste
And seide lordes herkenyth yif ye leste
Y knowe oure forward yif ye it recorde
Yif evissong and morowe songe accorde
Latte se who shall telle the furst tale
As so eủer/ree mot y drynke wyne or ale
Who so be rebell to my Iugement
Shall paie for all that is by the wey spent
Nowe drawith Cutte or we ferther twyn
For he that hath the shortist shall be gyn
Sir knyght quod he my Master and my lorde
Nowe drawith Cut for this for this is myn accorde
Comth nere quod . he my lady prioresse
And ye Sir Clerke let be youre shamfastnesse
Ne studieth nought ley hande to eủer/rey man
And to drawe eủer/rey wight began
And shortly to telle as it was
Were it by adventure or sorte or cas
The sothe is the Cutte felle to the knyght
Of which full gladde was eủer/rey wyght
And tell he moste his tale as it was reasou
By forward and by composicyou
And that ye haue harde what nedeth wordes moo
And whan this gode man sawe it was soo
As he that wise was and obedient
To kepe his forward by his fre assent
And seide sith y shall begynne the game
Welcom be the Cutte in goddis name
Now lette vs ride and herkenyth what y sey
Nowe with that worde we riden furth on oure wey
And he began with right a mery chere
His tale anon and seide on this manere
Iamque domos patrias . Scithice post aspera gentes Prelia laurigero et cetera

(base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs

(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour

div.l: (base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten

div.l: (base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe

div.l: (base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
(base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng

div.l: (base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo

div.l: (base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely

div.l: (base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider

div.l: (base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede

div.l: (base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte

div.l: (base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte

div.l: (base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go

div.l: (base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus

div.l: (base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye

(base) ¶ The god of loue / a benedicitee
(base) How myghty / and how greet a lord is he

div.l: (base) For he kan maken / at his owene gyse

(base) ¶ Lo here / this Arcite / and this Palamoun
(base) That quitly were / out of my prisoun

(base) ¶ Who may been a fool / but if he loue
(base) Bihoold for goddes sake / that sit aboue
(base) Se how they blede / be they noght wel arrayed
(base) Thus hath hir lord / the god of loue ypayed
(base) Hir wages / and hir fees / for hir seruyse
(base) And yet they wenen / for to be ful wyse
(base) That seruen loue / for aught that may bifalle
(base) But this is yet the beste game of alle
(base) That she / for whom / they haue this Iolitee
(base) Kan hem therfore / as muche thank as me
(base) She woot namoore / of al this hoote fare
(base) By god / than woot a cokkow of an hare
(base) But al moot been assayed / hoot and coold
(base) A man moot been a fool / or yong or oold
(base) I woot it by myself / ful yoore agoon
(base) For in my tyme / a seruant was I oon
(base) And therfore / syn I knowe of loues peyne
(base) And woot how soore / it kan a man distreyne
(base) As he that hath been caught ofte in his laas
(base) I yow foryeue / al hoolly this trespas
(base) At requeste of the queene / that kneeleth heere
(base) And eek of Emelye / my suster deere
(base) And ye shal bothe anoon / vnto me swere
(base) That neuere mo / ye shal my contree dere
(base) Ne make werre vpon me / nyght nor day
(base) But been my freendes / in al that ye may
(base) I yow foryeue / this trespas euerydel
(base) And they hym sworen / his axing faire and wel
(base) And hym of lordshipe / and of mercy preyde
(base) And he hem graunteth grace / and thanne he seyde
(base) ¶ To speke of roial lynage / and richesse
(base) Thogh that she weere a queene / or a princesse

div.l: (base) Ech of yow bothe / is worthy doutelees
(base) To wedden whan tyme is / but nathelees
(base) I speke / as for my suster Emelye
(base) For whom / ye haue this stryf and Ialousye
(base) Ye woot your self. she may nat wedden two
(base) Atones / thogh ye fighten eueremo
(base) That oon of yow / al be hym looth / or lief
(base) He moot go pipen / in an yuy leef
(base) This is to seyn / she may nat now haue bothe
(base) Al be ye neuere so Ialous / ne so wrothe
(base) And for thy / I yow putte in this degree
(base) That ech of yow / shal haue his destynee
(base) As hym is shape / and herkneth in what wyse
(base) Lo here youre ende / of that I shal deuyse
(base) ¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioun
(base) Withouten any replicacioun
(base) If that yow liketh / take it for the beste
(base) That euerich of yow / shal goon where hym leste
(base) Frely / withouten raunsoun / or daunger
(base) And this day fifty wykes / fer ne neer
(base) Euerich of yow / shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
(base) Armed for listes / vp at alle rightes
(base) Al redy / to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght
(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou
(base) May with his hundred / as I spak of now
(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun

div.l: (base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe
(base) And thus with good hope / and herte blythe
(base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde
(base) To Thebes / with olde walles wyde
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda
(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily
(base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree
(base) He letted noght his felawe for to see
(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral

div.l: (base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye

div.l: (base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /

div.l: (base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor

div.l: (base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas

div.l: (base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde

div.l: (base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee

div.l: (base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore

div.l: (base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye

div.l: (base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan

div.l: (base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle

div.l: (base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure

div.l: (base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare

div.l: (base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun

div.l: (base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd

div.l: (base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
(base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde
(base) But o cours / with a sharp ygrounde spere
(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
