div.l: (base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aft̉er/re here degre
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
(base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon
(base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down

div.l: (base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
(base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede
(base) Out brest the blood / with sterne stremys rede
(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun
(base) And he hym hurteth / with his hors adoun
(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite

div.l: (base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
(base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
(base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
(base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
(base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Some hadde saluys made for the nones
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght
(base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
(base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
(base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye
(base) Ther may no man / clepe it cowardye
(base) ¶ For which anoon / duc Theseus leet crye
(base) To stynten / al rancour and enuye
(base) The gre / as wel of oo syde as of oother
(base) And eyther syde ylyk as otheres brother
(base) And yaf hem yiftes / after hir degree
(base) And fully heeld a feeste / dayes three
(base) And conueyed / the kynges worthily
(base) Out of his toun / a iournee largely
(base) And hoom wente euery man / the righte way
(base) Ther was namoore / but fare wel haue good day
(base) Of this bataille / I wol namoore endite
(base) But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) Of Palamon wil I stynte alite
(base) Swelleth the brest of Arcite / and the soore
(base) Encreeseth at his herte / moore and moore
(base) The clothered blood / for any lechecraft
(base) Corrupteth / and is in his bouk / ylaft
(base) That neyther veyne blood / ne ventusynge
(base) Ne drynke of herbes / may been his helpynge
(base) The vertu expulsyf / or animal
(base) Fro thilke vertu / clepyd natural
(base) Ne may the venym / voyden ne expelle
(base) The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
(base) And euery lacerte / in his brest adown
(base) Is shent with venym and corrupcioun
(base) Hym gayneth neither / for to gete his lyf
(base) Vomyt vpward / ne downward laxatyf
(base) Al is to brosten / thilke regioun
(base) Nature / hath no dominacioun
(base) And certeinly / ther nature wol nat werche
(base) Fare wel Phisyk. go ber the man to cherche
(base) This al and som / that Arcita moot dye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For which / he sendeth after Emelye
(base) And Palamon / that was his cosyn deere
(base) Thanne seyde he thus / as ye shal after heere
(base) ¶ Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
(base) Declare a point of alle my sorwes smerte
(base) To yow my lady / that I loue moost
(base) But I byquethe / the seruice of my goost
(base) To yow / abouen euery creature
(base) Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
(base) Allas the wo / allas the peynes stronge
(base) That I for yow haue suffred / and so longe
(base) Allas the deeth / allas myn Emelye
(base) Allas / departyng of oure compaignye
(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf
(base) Myn hertys lady cawser of my tene
(base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
(base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
(base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
(base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye
(base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) That soroweth and cryeth I wyl not lye
(base) Now wepith Emelye ⁊and waylith Palamon
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
(base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) As þat þ̉er/re was for deþ of þis Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) For sorwe of him þer weepeþ boþe child and man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
(base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
(base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
(base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be
(base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer

div.l: (base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Explicit Fabula Militis Hic incipit prologus Fabule Molendinarij et cetera
When that the knyght had thus his tale y tolde
In all the companye was ther yonge ne olde
That hene seide it was a noble storie
And worthy to be drawe into memorie
And namely the Ientils eủer/reychone
Oure hoste seide and swoor so mot y gone
This goith a right vnbocled is the male
Let se nowe who shall telle a nother tale
For truly this game is well begonne
Nowe telle sir Monke yif that ye conne
Somwhat to quyte with the knyghtis tale
The Miller that for dronkyn was of ale
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he sate
He nolde avale nether hode ne hatte
Ne a bide noman for his curtesie
But in pilates voice he gan to crie
And swere by armes blode and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With which y will nowe quyte the knyghtis tale
Oure hoste saugh he was dronke of ale
And seide Robyn abide dere brother
Som bettur man shall telle vs first another
A bide and let vs werkyn thriftly
By goddis soule quod he that will not y
For y will speke or ellys goo my wey
Oure hoste than aunswerde . tell on a devilwey
Thou arte a fole thy wit ys oủer/reecom
Nowe herkneth quod the Miller all and som
But furst y make a protostacioun
That y am dronke y knowe well by my soun
Therfore yif y myspeke or sey
Witith it the ale of suthwerke y you prey
For y will telle a legende or a lyf
Bothe of a Carpynter and of his wyf
How that a Clerke hath sette the wrightes cappe
The Reve than aunswerde and seide stynte thy clappe
Lette be thy lewede drunkyn harlatrie
It ys a synne and eke a grete folie
To apeire eny man or hym defame
And eke to brynge a wif in suche name
Thou mayst y nowe of other thynges seyne
This drunkyn Miller spake full sone ageyne
And seide leve brother Oswolde
Who so hath no wyf he ys no Cokolde
But y sey not therfore that thou art one
There be full good wifis many one
Why arte thou angry with my tale nowe
I haue a wife pardie as wele as thowe
Yit nolde y for the Oxen yn my plough
Take vppon me more than y nough
As demen of my self that y were one
I will beleve well that y am none
An husbonde shall not be Inquysitif
Of goddis pryvite ne of his wif
So he may fynde goddis foysou there
Of the remenaunte nedith not to enquere
What shulde y more seyne . but this Millere
He wolde his wordes for noman forbere
But tolde his Churles tale yn this manere
Me athynkith that y shall rehers it here
And therfore eủer/rey Ientill wight y prey
Demeth not for goddis love that y sey
Of evill entente . but for y mot reherce
Here tales all be they bet or werce
Or elles falsen som of my matere
And therfore who so lystnot itto here
Turne oủer/ree the lef and chese a nother tale
For he shall fynde ynowe grete and smale
Of storiall thyng that touchith ientilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blameth not me yif þe . chese amysse
The Miller is a churle ye knowe well thysse
So was the Reve eke and other mo
And harlotrie they tolden bothe two
Avisith you and put me oute of blame
And eke men shulde not make ernest of game
Whilom there was dwellyng yn Oxonford
A Riche Gnoff that gestys hilde to bord
And of his crafte he was a Carpenter
With hym there was dwellyng a pore scoler
That had lerned arte . but all his fantasie
Was turned to lerne Astrologye
And coude acerteyne of conclusions
To deme by interogacions
Yif that men asked hym in certayne houres
When men shulde haue droughte other elles shoures
And yif men asked hym what shulde befalle ̉er/re
Of eủer/rey thyng y may not rekon all
This clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne love he coude and of Solas
And therto he was sly and full prive
And like a mayde meke for to se
A chambre had he in that hosterye
Alone withoute eny companye
Full fetously dight with herbys sote
And he hym self as swete as is the rote
Of licoris or elles of eny Setwale
His Almageste and bokes grete and smale
His astrolabre hangynge for his arte
His augrym stones leyne faire aparte
On shelves couchid at his beddes hede
His presse coủer/reed with a faldyng rede
And all above there lay agay Sawtrie
On which he made a nyght melodie
So swetely that all the Chambre rang
And Angelus ad Virginem he sange
And aftur that he sange the kynges note
Full ofte blessed was his mery throte
And thus this swete Clerke his tyme spente
Aftur his frendes fyndyng and his rente
This Carpenter had newe wedded awif
The which that he loved more than his lif
Of xviij . yere she was of age
Ielouse he was . and hilde here narowe in a Cage
For she was wilde and yonge and he was olde
And demed hym self to be like a Cuckewolde
He knewe nat Caton for his wit was rude
That bade that men shulde wedde here symilitude
Men shulde wedde aftur here estate
For youth and age ben ofte at debate
But sithen that he was fallen in the snare
e endure as other folke his care
re was this yonge wif and there with alle
As eny wesell hure body gente and smalle
A syllet she wered . barred all of Sylke
A faire clothe as white as morowe mylke
Vppon hure lendes with many a Gore
White was hure smok and browded all before
And eke behynde oủer/ree hure Colere aboute
Of cole blacke silke within and withoute
The Tapes of hure white volupere
Were of the same sute as hure Colere
Hure filet brood of Silke and sette full hye
And sikyrly she hadde a licoris . ye
Full smale pulled were hure browes two
And tho were bent and blacke as is a slo
She was full more blisfull vnto see
Then is the newe pere Ienet tree
And softer than is wolle of a wether
And by hure girdle hynge a purs of lether
Tasselled with silke and ꝑper/parled with latou
In all this worlde to seke vp and doun
There is no man so wise that coude thenche
So gay a popelote or suche a wenche
Full brighter was she shynyng of hure hue
Than in the Toure the noble forged nue
But of hure songe it was as loude and yerne
As eny swalowe sittyng sittyng on the berne
Therto she coude skip and make game
As eny kyde or calf folwyng the dame
Hure mowth was swete as braggot or Meth
Or horde of Applesse leyde in hey or heth
Wynsyng she was as is a Ioly Colte
Longe as a Mast and vpright as a bolte
A Broyche she bare vppon hur love Colere
As brode as ys the boos of Bokelere
Here Shoes were laced on hure legges hye
She was a Prymmerose a Piggysnye
For any lorde to leggen in his bedde
Or yet for any good yoman to wedde
Now sir and afte sir . so byfell the cas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fell with this yonge wif to rage and to playe
While that hure husbonde was atte Osnaye
As clerkes ben full sotell and full queynte
And prively he caught hure by Queynte

Or I will dien also god me save
And she sprange as a Colte dothe in a Trave
And with hure hede she wried fast a wey
She seide I will not kysse the by my fey
We lat be quod ich / lat be Nicholas
Or y will crie oute harowe and alas
Do way youre handes for youre curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy forto crye
And spake so faire and profered hure so fast
That she hure love hym graunted at the last
And swere hure othe by seynt Thomas of kent
That she wolde ben at his commaundement
When that she may here leysere well a spye
Myn husbonde is so full of Ielosye
That but ye waite well and be prive
I wote right well y am but dede quod she
Ye mot be full derne all in this cas
Nay thereof care ye not quod Nicholas
A Clerke had letherly biset his while
But yif he coude a Carpenter begile
And thus they ben acorded and y swarn
To waite a tyme as y haue tolde biforn
Whan Nicholas had done thus eủer/rey dele
And twakked hure aboute the lendes wele
He kisseth hure swete and takith his Sawtrie
And playth full fast and makith melodie
Then fell it thus . that to the parisshe Cherche
Cristes owne werke for to werche
This good wyf wente on an holyday
Hure forhede shone as bright as eny day
So was it wasshen when she litte hur werke
Nowe was there of that parisshe Churche a Clerke
The which was clepid Absolou
Crulle was his here and as the golde it shon
And strouted as a Fane . and large and brode
Full streyte and even lay his Ioly shode
His rood was rede his yeen gray as goos
With Paules wyndowes corven on his shoos
In hoses rede he wente full fetously
I cladde he was full small full and ꝓpropirly
All in a kyrtell of light waget
Full faire and thik bene the poyntys set
And thereuppon he had a gay Surplise
As white as is the blossom on the Rise
A mery Childe he was so god me save
Well coude he let blode clippe and shave
And make a Charte of londe or acquytaunce
In . xxᵗⁱ . mane couth he trippe and daunce
Aftur the scole of Oxonford . thoo
And with his legges casten . to . and froo
And playne songe on a small Ribible
And therto he songe . somtyme a loude Quinible
And aswell coude he pley on a Giterne
In all the Towne nas ther Bruhous ne Taverne
That he ne visited with his Solas
There eny gay fresshe Tapster was
But sothe to seyne he was somdell squamous
Of fartyng . and of speche daungerous
This Absoloıı̄un that Ioly was and gay
Gothe with a Senser the holiday
Sensyng the wyvys of the parisshe faste
And many alovely loke on hem he caste
And namely vppon this Carpynters wif
To loke on hure hym thought a mery lif
She was so ꝓpropre swete and licorouse
I dar well seyne yif she had ben a mouse
And he a Catte he wolde hure hente anon
This parisshe Clerke this Ioly Absolou
Hath in his herte suche alove longyng
That of no wif toke he non offryng
For curtesy he seide he wolde none
The mone whan yt was nyght full bright shone
And Absolon his giterne hath y take

Full well accordyng to his giteryng
This Carpynter a woke and herde hym syng
And spake vnto his wif and seide anon
What Alisoıı̄un herest thou not Absolou
That chauntith thus vnder oure bowres wall
And she aunswerd hure husbonde therewith all
Yis god wote Iohn y here it eủer/rey dell
This passith furth what will ye bette then well
Fro day to day this Ioly Absolou
So wowith hure that hym is wo bigon
He wakith all the nyght and all the day
He kembith his lockes brode and made hym gay
He woweth hure by meane and brocage
And swore that he wolde ben here owne page
He syngith brockyng as a Nightyngale
He sente hure pyment Meth and Spiced ale
And wafers pypyng hote oute of the glede
And for she was of Toun he profered hure mede
For som men woll by wounnen for Richesse
And som for strokes and som for gentilnesse
Somtyme to shewen his lightnes and mastrie
He pleith herode vppon a Scaffolde hie
But what a vailith hym all in this cas
She loveth so this hende Nicholas
That Absolou may blowe the Bukkys horn
He ne had for his laboure but a scorn
And thus she makith Absolou hure ape
And all his ernest turneth till a Iape
Ful soth is this proverbe it ys no lie
Men seyn right thus alway the nyght flie
Maketh the fer low to be lothe
For though that Absolou be wode and wrothe
Because that he fer was from hure sight
This nygh Nicholas stode in his lyght
Nowe bere the well thou hende Nicholas
For Absolou may weile and syngyn alas
And so be fele it that on a Saturday
This Carpynter was gon till Osnay
And hende Nicholas and Alisou
Accorded ben to this conclusiou
That Nicholas shall shapen theme a wile
The sely Ielous husbonde to begile
And yif so be the game wente a right
She wolde slepe in his Armys al nyght
For this was his desire and here also
And right anon withoute wordis mo
This Nicholas wolde no lenger tarie
But doth vnto his Chambre carie
Bothe mete and drynke . for . I . day . or twey
And to hure husbonde bade hure for to sey
Yif that he asketh aftʳ hende Nicholas
She shulde sey . she nyst where he was
Of all that day she sawe hym not with ye
She trowed that he was in som maladye
For no crye hure Maide coude hym calle
He wolde aunswere for nothyng that myght falle
This passith furth alle thilke Saturday
That Nicholas styll in his Chambre lay
And ete and slepe and did what hym lyst
Till Sonday that the sonne wente to rest
This Sely Carpynter hath grete mervaile
Of Nicholas what thyng myght hym aile
And seide I am a drad by seynte Thomas
Hit stant not aright with Nicholas
God shelde that he died sodenly
This worlde is nowe full tuly . sikirly
I saugh this day a Corps y bore to Cherche
That nowe on Monday . last y sawe hym werche
Go vp quod . he vnto his knave anon
Clepe at the dore and knocke with a ston
Loke hou . it is and telle me boldely
This knave goth vp full sturdely
And at the Chambre dore while that he stood
He cried and knocked as he were wood
What howe what do ye Maister Nicholay
Hou may ye slepe thus all the longe day
But all for nought . he seide not a worde
An hole he fande full lowe vppon a borde
There as the Catte was wonede in to crepe
And at that hole he loked in full depe
And at the last he had of hym a sight
This Nicholas sate eủer/ree gapyng vpright d
As he had keked the newe moone
his maister sone
this ilke man
This carpenter hym bigan
And seide seynte Frideswide
A man what shall hym betide
This man with his Astromye
or in som Agonye
hou that it shulde be
Men shulde not knowen of goddes privete
Ye blessed be alway a lewid man
That naught but only his bileve can
So ferde a nother Clerke with his Astronomye
He walked yn the feldes for to prye
Vppon the Sterrys what there shulde befalle
Till as in a Marle pitte doun was falle
He sawe not that But yet by seynte Thomas
Me rewith sore of hende Nicholas
He shalbe arated of his stodeyng
Yif that y may by Ihu heven kyng
Gete me a staffe that y may vnderpore
While that thou Robyn hevyst at the dore
He shall oute of his stodeyng . as y gesse
And to the Chambre dore he gan hym dresse
His knave was a stronge Carle for the nones
And by the haspe he haf it vp attones
Into the flore the dore fele anon
This Nicholas sate ay as still as eny ston
And eủer/ree he gapid vpward to the heyre
This Carpynter wende he hadde ben in dispeyre
And hent hym by the shuldres myghtly
And shoke hym harde and cried spitously
What Nicholas what how loke a doun
A wake and thynke on cristes passioun
I crouche the from Elves and from wightes
Therewith the nyghtspell seide he anon rightes
On iiij halfes . of the hous aboute
And at the Thressholde at the dore withoute
Ihu Crist and seynte benedight
Blesse this hous from eủer/rey evill wight
Fro the nyght mare the white Pater noster
Where wentist thou seynte Petris Suster
And at the last this hende Nicholas
Gan for to sigh sore and seide alas
Shall alle the worlde be loste eft sones nowe
This Carpenter aunswerde what seyst thowe
What thynke on god as we do men that swynke
This Nicholas aunswerde go fech me drynke
And aftur will y speke in privete
Of certayne thyng that touchith the and me
I woll tell it to none other man certayne
¶ This Carpenter goth doun and comth a gayne
And brought of myghty ale a large quarte
And when that Eyther of them hadde dronke his parte
This Nicholas his dore fast shette
And doun the Carpenter by hym he sette
And seide Iohn myn hoste leve and dere
Thou shalte vppon thy trouthe ensuere me here
That to no wight thou shalte my counseile wrey
For it is cristis counceill that y the sey
And yif thou telle eny man thou arte for lore
For this veniaunce thou shalte haue therfore
That yif thou wrey me thou shalte be wood
Nay criste for bede it for his holy blood
Quod tho this Sely man y am no labbe
Ne though y sey it . y am not lef to gabbe
Sey what thou wilte y will . never telle
To childe ne wif . by hym that harowed helle
Nowe Iohn quod Nicholas y will not lie
I haue founde in myn Astrologie
As y haue loked in the mone bright
That nowe on Monday nexte aftur quarter nyght
Shall falle a Reyne and that so wilde and wood
That half so grete was neủer/ree Noes Flood
This worlde he seyde yn lasse than half an houre
Shalbe dreynte so hidouse shalle that shoure
Thus shall mankynd drenche and lese here liff
The Carpenter aunswerd allas my wyff
And shall she drenche allas myn Alisoun
For sorowe of this he fill almoste adoun
And seide is there no remedie in this cas
Yes for god . quod hende Nicholas
Yif thou wilte werke aftⁱ lore and rede
Thou mayst not werke aftur thyn owne hede
For thus seith Salamon that is full true
Werke all by counsaile and thou shalte nat rue
And yif thou wilte werke by good counsaile
I vndertake withoute mast or saile
Yet shall y save hure and the and me
Hast thou not harde hou savid was Noe
When that oure lorde had warned hym biforn
That all the worlde with water shulde be lorn
Yis quod this Carpenter full yore a goo
Hast thou not harde quod Nicholas alsoo
The sorowe of Noe with his felauship
Or that he myght gete his wif to Ship
Hym had be levyr I vndertake
At thilke tyme than all the wethers blake
That she had . y had a shippe hur silf allone
And therfore wost thou what best is to done
This askith haste and of an hasty thyng
Men mowe not preche and make tareyng
Anon go gete vs fast ynto this ynne
A knedyngtrowgh or elles a kymlynne
For eche of vs but loke that they be large
In which we mowe swymme as in a barge
And haue there Inne vitaille sufficiaunt .
But for one day . fy on the remenaunt
The water shall a slake and goo a waye
Aboute pryme on the nexte daye
But Robyn may not wete of this thy knave
Ne eke Gylle thy Maide . y may not save
Aske not whye . for though thou aske me .
I will not telle goddes privete
Suffiseth the but yif thy wittes madde
To haue as grete a gᵃce as Noe hadde
Thy wif shall y well save oute of doute
Go nowe thy wey and spede there a boute
But when thou hast for hure the and me
I gete vs thise knedyng Tubbes . thre
Then shalte thou hangen hem in Rofe full hye
That no man of oure purveaunce espye
And when thou hast done as y haue seide
And haste oure vitaille feire in hem leide
And eke an axe to smyte the corde a two
When that the water comth that we may go
And breke an hole on high on the gable
Vnto the garden warde oủer/ree the Stable
That we may frely passe furth in oure waye
When that the grete shoure is gon a weye
Then shalte thou swymme as mery y vndertake
As doith the white doke aftur hure drake
Then woll y clepe howe Alison . howe Iohn
Be mery for the flode shall passe anon
And thou wilte say haille Master Nicholay
Good morowe y seᵗ the well for it is day
And then shull we be lordes all oure liff
Of all the worlde as Noe and his wif
But of one thynge I warne the full right
Be well a vised on that ilke nyght
That when we be entred in to shippis borde
That none of vs speke not a worde
Ne clepe ne crie . but bene in his preyre
For it is goddis owne heste dere
Thy wif and thou motten hange fer atwynne
For that betwyxt you shalbe no synne
No more in likyng than ther shall in dede
This ordynaunce is seide go nowe god the spede
To morowe at nyght when men ben a slepe
Into oure knedyng Tubbes woll we Crepe
And sitte there abidyng goddis grace
Go nowe thy wey y haue no lenger space
To makyn of this no longer Sermonyng
Men seyn thus . sende the wise . and say no thyng
Thou arte so wise it nedith the nought to teche
God save oure lives . that y hym beseche
This Sely Carpenter goth furth his wey
Full ofte he seide allas and welaway
And to his wif he tolde his privete
And she was war and knewe it bet than he
What all this quaynte cas was for to seye
But natheles she ferde as she wolde deye
And seide allas go furth thy way anon
Helpe vs to scape or we be dede echon
I am thy true verrey weddid wiff
Go dere spouse and helpe to save oure . liff h
Lo which a grete thyng is affeccioun
Men mowe dye bi of ymagynacioun
So depe may Impressioun be take
This sely carpynter begynneth to quake
Hym thynkith verely that he may see
Noes flode com walwyng as the See
To drenche Alisou his hony dere
He wepith and wayleth and makith hevy chere
He sighigh with many a full sory swowe
And goth and getith hym a knedyng trowe
And aftur a Tubbe and a kymlynne
And prively he sente hom to his Inne
And hyng hem in the rofe in privete
With his owne hande he made laddris thre
To clyme by the ronges and the stalkes
Vnto the Tubbes hangyng on the balkes
And hem vitailled bothe kymlyn Trowe and Tubbe
With brede and chese and good ale in a Tubbe
Suffisyng right y nough as for on day
But er that he had made this aray
He sente his knave and eke his wenche alsoo
Vppon his nede to london for to goo
And on the Monday when it drowe to nyght
He shet his dore withoute candell lyght
And dressed all thyng as it shulde be
And shortly vp they clymben all thre
They setyn still well a forlong way
Nowe pater noster clum seide Nicholay
Clum quod Iohn and clum seide Alisou
This Carpenter seide his devociou
And still he sate and seide his preyre
Awaytyng on the Reyne yif he hit myght here
The dede slepe for verrey besynesse
Fill on this Carpentere right a y gesse
A boute Curfue tyme or litle more
For travaill of his goste he groneth sore
And efte he rowtid for his hed myslay
Doun by the ladder stalkith Nicholay
And Alysou full ofte a doun here spedde
Withoute wordes mo they gon to bedde
There as this Carpenter was woned to lye
There was revell and the melodye
And thus lyen Alisou and Nicholas
In bisynesse and myrth and in solas
Till that the belle of lawdes gan to rynge
And freres yn the Chauncell gon to synge
This parisshe Clerke this amorous Absolou
That ys for love alway so sore begon
Vppon the Monday was at Osnay
With companye hym to disporte and play
And asked vppon this cas there a Cloysterer
Full prively aft̉er/re Iohn the Carpenter
And he drowe hym a partie oute of the Cherche
And seide y ne y wete y sawe hym here not werche
Sith Saturday . I trowe that he be went
For tymbre there oure Abbot hath hym sent
For he ys woned for tymbre for to goo
And dwelle at the Graunge a day or twoo
Or elles he is at his house certayne
Where that he be y can not sothely sayne
This Absolou full Ioly was and light
And thought nowe is tyme to wake all nyght
And sikerly y sawe hym not steryng
Aboute his dore seth the day gan spryng
So mot y thrive y shall at Cokkys crowe
Full prively cnacke at his wyndowe
That stante full lowe vppon his boures wall
To Alisou nowe will y tellen all
My love longyng and yet y shall not mys
That at the leste way y shall hure kys
Som mane comfort shall y haue parfay
My mowth hath ycchid all this longe day
That ys a signe of kissyng atte the leste
All nyght me mette eke that y was at a feste
Therfore y woll go slepe an houre or twey
And all the nyght then will y wake and pley
When that the first cocke hath crowe anon
Vp riseth this Ioly lover Absolou
And hym arayd gay at poynte devise
But first he chewith graynes and licorise
To smelle swote . er he had kempte his here
Vnder his tonge a trewe love he bere
For ther by wened he to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters hous
And still he stant vnder the shot wyndowe
Vnto his brest it raught it was so lowe
And softe he coughed with a semy sowne
What do ye hony Combe my swete Alisone
My faire brid my swete Synamome
Awakith lemman myn and speke here toome
Well litle thynke ye vppon my woo
That for youre love y swete there y goo
No wondre ys though y swelte and swete
I morne as doth a lambe aftur the tete
I wys lemman y haue suche love longyng
That like a Turtell true is my mornyng
I may not ete no more than a Maide
Go fro the wyndowe Iakke fole she saide
As helpe me god It woll not be com bame
Y love another and elles y were to blame
Well bet than the by Ihu Absolou
Go furth thy wey or y will cast a ston
And lette me slepe a twenty devilway
Alas quod Absolou and welaway
That trulove was eủer/ree so evill biset
Then kys me sith it will be no bet
For Ihu love and for the love of me
Wolte thou go thy wey therwith quod she
Yes certis lemman quod this Absolou
Then make the redy qd she y com anon
This Absolou doun sette hym on his knees
And seide I am nowe a lorde of all degrees
For aftur this y hope there comth more
Lemman thy grace and swete brid thyn ore
The wyndowe she vndoth and that in haste
Haue do quod she and spede the faste
Lest that oure neyghtbours it espie
Absolou gan wipe his mowth full drie
Derke was the nyght . as picche or the Cole
And at the wyndowe oute put she hure hole
And Absolou hym fell no bet ne wers
But with his mowth he kyst hur naked ers
Full savourly or he were ware of this
A backe he sterte and thought it was amys
For well he wist a womman had no berde
He felte a thyng all rough and longe y herede
And seide fy alas what haue y do
Te he quod she and clappid the wyndowe to
And Absolou goth furth a sory pas
A berde a berde seide hende Nicholas
By goddis corps this goth fayre and well
This sely Absolou hard eủer/rey dell
And on his lippe for angre he gan bite
And to hym self he seide y shall the quite
Who rubbith nowe who frotith nowe his lippis
With dust with sonde with strawe with cloth with Chippis
But Absolou that seith full ofte allas
My soule betake y to Satanas
But me were levyr than all this toun quod he
Of this dispite a wrekyn for to be
Alas quod he allas y ne hadde y bleynt
His hote love was colde and all y queynt
For fro that tyme . that he had kist hure Ers
Of paramours rought he not a kers
For he was heled of his maladie
Full ofte paramours he gan defie
And wepe as doth aChilde that is bete
A softe pas he went hym oủer/ree the strete
Vnto a Smyth men called daun Gerveys
That in his Forge smythid plough harneys
He sharped Share and Cultur besily
This Absolou cnocked all easely
And seide vndo Gerveis . and he than anon
What who arte thou . y am Absolou
What Absolou for Cristis swete tre
Why arise ye so rathe ey benedicite
What eyleth you som gay girle god it wote
Hath brought you thus vppon the veritote
By seynte notte ye wote well what y mene
This Absolou rought not a bene
Of all his pleynte no worde ayen he yaf
He had more towe vppon his distaf
Then Gerveys knewe and seide frende so dere
That whote Culture in thy Chymney there
As lende me it y haue therwith to done
I will bryng it ageyne to the sone
Gerveys seide certis were it golde
Or in a poke nobles all vntolde
Thou shuldest hem haue as y am true Smyth
Ey cristis fote what will ye do therwyth
Thereof quod Absolou be as be may
Y shall it well tell the another day
And caught the Cultur by the colde stele
Full softe oute at the dore he gan to stele
And wente vnto the Carpentars wall
He coughed furst and cnocked there with all
Vppon the wyndowe right as he did ere
This Alisou aunswerd who is there
That knockith so y warant it is a thef
Nay nay quod he god wote my swete lef
I am thyn Absolou thy derlyng
Of golde quod he y haue brought the a Ryng
My Moder yaf it me so god me save
Full fyne it is and therto well y grave
This will y yeve the yif thou me kysse
This Nicholas was risen vp to pysse
He thought he wolde a mende all the Iape
He shulde kis his ars or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe he did hastely
And oute his ars he put prively
Oủer/ree the buttok to the haunche bone
And therewith spake hym Absolone
Speke swete birde y not where thou arte
This Nicholas anon lette fle a farte
As grete as it had ben a thonder dent
That with the stroke he was all most y blent
And he was redy with his Iron hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smote
Of goth the Skyn an hand brede aboute
The hote Cultur brende so his toute
That for the smerte he wende forto dye
As he were wode for wo he gan to crye
Helpe water water . for goddes herte
This Carpynter oute of his slomer sterte
And harde one crie water as he were wood
And thought allas nowe commeth Noes flood
He set hym vp withoute wordes moo
And with his Axe he smote the corde two
He fell doun to the flore and there a swoun he lay
Vp sterte hure Alisoıı̄un and Nicholay
And cried oute and harowe in the strete
The nyghtbours than bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawren on this man
That in swounyng lay bothe pale and wan
For with the fall he broken had his armes
But stonde he moste to his owne harmes
For when he spake . he was anon bore doun
Of hende Nicholas and Alisoun
They tolden eủer/rey man that he was wood
He was agast so of Noes flood
Thrugh fantasie that of his vanyte
He bought hym knedyng Tubbys thre
And had hem hanged in the Rof a bove
And that he praide them for goddis love
To sitten in the Rof for companye
The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
Into the . Rof they kekyn and they gape
And turned all his harmys vnto Iape
For what so that this Carpenter aunswerd
It was for nought . no man his reasou herd
With othes grete he was so sworn doun
That he was holden wode thrugh all the toun
For eủer/rey Clerke anon right hilde with other
And seide the man was wode my lef brother
And eủer/rey wight gan laughen at this strif
Thus swyved was the Carpenters wif
For all his kepyng and his Ielosie
And Absolou had kist hure nether ye
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
My tale is don . and god save all this route
Thus endeth the Millers tale

div.l: (base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) Here endeth the Reuys prolog
(base) Narrat
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade

div.l: (base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
(base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo

div.l: (base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
(base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir
(base) Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage
(base) His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended
(base) Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
(base) Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
(base) Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
(base) With whete and malt of al the land aboute
(base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
(base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
(base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
(base) An hondred tyme moore than biforn
(base) For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
(base) But now he was a theef outrageously
(base) For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
(base) But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
(base) He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
(base) Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
(base) That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
(base) Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
(base) And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
(base) Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
(base) To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
(base) To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
(base) And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
(base) The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
(base) Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
(base) And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
(base) Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
(base) Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
(base) Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
(base) This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
(base) And on an hors the sak he caste anon

div.l: (base) Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
(base) With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
(base) Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
(base) And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
(base) Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
(base) How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
(base) Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
(base) And Iohn also how now what do ye here
(base) By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
(base) Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
(base) Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
(base) Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
(base) Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
(base) And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
(base) To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
(base) I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
(base) It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
(base) What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
(base) By god right by the hoper wol I stande
(base) Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
(base) Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra
(base) Aleyn answerde Iohn wiltow swa
(base) Thanne wol I be byneth by my crown
(base) And se how that the mele falles down
(base) In to the trogh that sal be my desport
(base) For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort
(base) I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
(base) This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
(base) And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
(base) They wene that no man may hem bigile
(base) But by my thrift yet shal I blere hir Iye
(base) For al the sleighte in hir phislophye
(base) The moore queynte crekys that they make
(base) The moore wol I stele whan I take
(base) In stede of flour yet wol I yeue hem bren
(base) The grettest clerkes been noght the wisest men
(base) As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
(base) Of al hir art counte I noght a tare
(base) Out of the dore he gooth ful pryuely
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
(base) He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
(base) The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde
(base) Bihynde the Mille vnder a leefsel
(base) And to the hors he gooth hym faire and wel
(base) He strepeth of the bridel right anon
(base) And whan the hors was laus he gynneth gon
(base) Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
(base) And forth with wehe thurgh thikke and thenne
(base) This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde
(base) But dooth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
(base) Til that hir corn was faire and wel ygrounde
(base) And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
(base) This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away
(base) And gan to crye harrow and weilaway
(base) Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
(base) Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
(base) Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
(base) This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn
(base) Al was out of his mynde his housbondrye
(base) What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
(base) The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren
(base) She seyde allas youre hors gooth to the fen
(base) With wilde mares as faste as he may go
(base) Vnthank come on his hand that boond hym so
(base) And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne
(base) Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne
(base) Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa
(base) I is ful wight god waat as is a ra
(base) By god hert he sal nat scape vs bathe
(base) Be cockis herte he shal not a scape vs bathe
(base) Why ne had thow pit the capil in the lathe
(base) Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne
(base) This sely clerkes haan ful faste yronne
(base) Toward the fen bothe Alayn and eek Iohn
(base) And whan the Millere seigh that they were gon
(base) He half a busshel of hir flour hath take
(base) And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
(base) He seyde I trowe the clerkes were aferd
(base) Yet kan a Millere maken a clerkes berd
(base) For al his art ye lat hem goon hir weye
(base) Lo wher he gooth ye lat the children pleye
(base) They gete hym noght so lightly by my croun
(base) Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun

div.l: (base) With keep keep stand stand Iossa warderere
(base) Ga whistle thow and I sal kepe hym heere
(base) But shortly til that it was verray nyght
(base) They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght
(base) Hir capyl cacche he ran alwey so faste
(base) Til in a dych they caughte hym at the laste
(base) Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
(base) Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
(base) Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
(base) Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
(base) Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
(base) Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
(base) And namely the Millere weilawey
(base) Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
(base) Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond
(base) The Millere sittyng by the fyr he fond
(base) For it was nyght and ferther myghte they noght
(base) But for the loue of god they hym bisoght
(base) Of herberwe and of ese as for hir peny
(base) The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
(base) Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
(base) Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
(base) Ye kan by argumentz make a place
(base) A myle brood of twenty foot of space
(base) Lat se now if this place may suffise
(base) Or make it rowm with speche as is your gyse
(base) Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
(base) Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
(base) I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
(base) Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
(base) But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
(base) Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
(base) And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
(base) With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
(base) Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende
(base) This Millere in to town his doghter sende
(base) For ale and breed and rosted hem a goos
(base) And boond hir hors it sholde namoore go loos
(base) And in his owene chambre hem made a bed
(base) With shetes and with chalons faire yspred

div.l: (base) Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
(base) His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue

A prentise whilom dwelde in oure Cite

And yif he haue nought seide hem leve brother
In o heboke heboke he hath seide hem yn an other

Youre wifhode he commaundith with the beste

And therfore he of full avisement
