And thynkith lorde amonge youre thoughtis wise
Hou that oure days passe in sondrye gise
For thogh we slepe or wake or renne or ride
Ay fleeth the tyde it wel no man abide
And thogh youre grene youth floure as yit
In crepith age alway as stil as stone
And deth manassith eủer/ree age and smyt
In eche estate for thereᵉscapith none
And also certeyne as we knowe echone
That we shul die as vncerteyne we ale
Ben of that day than deth shal on vs fale
Accepti0th then of vs the true entente
That neủer/ree yit refuseden oure heste
And we wol lord yif that ye wol assente
Chese you a wif yn short time at the leste
Born of the gentlest and of the meste
Of al this londe so that it ought seme
Honoure to god and you as we can deme
Deliủer/ree vs oute of al this besy drede
And tak a wif for high goddis sake
For yif so bifelle as god forbede
That thurgh youre deeth youre ligne sholde slake
And that a straunge Successour sholde take
Youre heritage o wo were vs alyue
Wher fore we pray yow hastily to wyue
Hir meke prayere and hir pitous cheere
Made the Markys herte han pitee
Ye wol quod he myn owene peple deere
To that I neuere erst thoghte streyne me
I me reioysed of my libertee
That selde tyme is founde in mariage
Ther I was free I moot ben in seruage
But nathelees I se your trewe entente
And truste vp on youre wit and haue doon ay
Wher fore of my free wyl I wol assente
To wedde me as soone as euere I may
But ther as ye han profred me to day
To chese me a wyf I yow relesse
That choys and pray yow of that profre cesse
For god it woot that children ofte ben
Vnlyk hir worthy eldres hem bifore
Bountee comth al of god nat of the stren
Of which they been engendred and ybore
I triste in goddes bountee and therfore
My mariage and myn estat and reste
I hym bitake he may doon as hym leste
Lat me allone in chesyng of my wyf
That charge vp on my bak I wol endure
But I pray yow and charge vp on your lyf
That what wyf that I take ye me assure
To worshipe hire whil that hir lyf may dure
In word and werk bothe here and euerywhere
As she an Emperours doghter were
And ferther moore this shal ye swere that ye
Agayn my choys shal neither grucche ne stryue
For sith y shal for go my liberte
At youre request as eủer/ree mot y thribe
There as myn harte is set ther wol I wibe
And but ye wol assent in suche mane
I prey you spekith no more of this mate
With hertly wil they sworn and assenten
To al this thyng there seide no wight nay
Besechyng hym of grace er that they wenten
That he wolde graunte them a certeyne day
Of his spousaille as sone as eủer/ree he may
For yit alway somwhat the peple dredde
Lest that the Marquys no wyf wolde wedde
He graunted them a day suche as hym lest
On which he wolde be wedded sikirly
And seide he did al this at there request
And they with humble entent buxumly
Knelyng vpon there knees ful reủer/reently
Hym thankyng al and thus they haue an ende
Of there entent and hom ageyne they wende
And here vppon he to his officers
And commaundith for the fest to purveie
And to his prive Knyghtis and Squyers
Such charge yaf as hym lust on them leye
And therto his commaundement obeye
And eche of them doth his diligence
To do vnto the fest reủer/reence
Incipit pars secunda
Noght fer fro thilke paleys honurable
Wher as this Markys shoop his mariage
Ther stood a Throop of site delitable
In which that poure folk of that village
Hadden hir bestes and hir herbergage
And of hir labour token hir sustenance
After that the erthe yaf hem habundance
Among this poure folk ther dwelte a man
Which that was holden pourest of hem alle
But heighe god som tyme senden kan
His grace in to a litel Oxes Stalle
Ianicula men of that Throop hym calle
A doghter hadde he fair ynogh to sighte
And Grisildis this yonge mayden highte
But for to speke of vertuous beautee
Thanne was she oon the faireste vnder the sonne
For poureliche yfostred vp was she
No likerous lust was thurgh hir herte yronne
Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel labour but noon ydel ese
Hit was hir lust and hir most ese
But thogh this mayde tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of hir virginitee
Ther was enclosed rype and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir olde poure fader fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnynge on feld she kepte
She wolde noght been ydel til she slepte
And whan she homward cam she wolde brynge
Wortes or othere herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seeth for his lyuynge
And made hir bed ful harde and no thyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lyf on lofte
With euery obeysance and diligence
That child may doon to fadres reuerence
Vp on Grisilde this poure creature
Ful ofte sithe this Markys sette his eye
As he on huntyng rood per auenture
And whan it fil that he myghte hir espie
He noght wit wantowne lookyng of folye
Hise eyen caste on hir but in sad wyse
Vp on hir cheere he wolde hym ofte auyse
Commendynge in his herte hir wommanhede
And eek hir vertu passyng any wight
Of so yong age as wel in cheere as dede
For thogh the peple hath no greet insight
In vertue he considered ful right
Hir bountee and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hir oonly if euere he wedden sholde
The day of weddyng cam but no wight kan
Telle what womman that it sholde be
For which merueille wondred many a man
And seyden whan they were in priuetee
Wol nat oure lord yet leue his vanytee
Wol he nat wedde allas the while
Why wol he thus hym self and vs bigyle
But nathelees this Markys hath doon make
Of gemmes set in gold and in Asure
Broches and rynges for Grisildis sake
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure
Of a mayde lyk to hir stature
And eek of othere aournementes alle
That vn to swich a weddyng sholde falle
The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approcheth that this weddyng sholde be
And al the palays put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with plentee
Ther maystow seen of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as last Ytaille
This Roial Markys richeliche arrayed
Lordes and ladys in his compaignye
The whiche that to the feste were yprayed
And of his retenue the Bachilrye
With many a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village of the which I tolde
In this array the righte wey han holde
Grisilde of this god woot ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was al this array
To fecchen water at a welle is went
And cometh hom as soone as euer she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd that thilke day
The Markys sholde wedde and if she myghte
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte
She thoghte I wole with othere maydens stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and se
The Markisesse and therfore wol I fonde
To doon at hom as soone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vn to me
And thanne I may at leyser hir biholde
Yf she this wey vn to the Castel holde
And as she wolde ouer the thresshfold gon
The Markys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water pot anon
Bisyde the thresshfold in an Oxes Stalle
And doun vp on hir knees she gan to falle
And with sad contenance kneleth stille
Til she hadde herd what was the lordes wille
This thoghtful Markys spak vn to this mayde
Ful sobrely and seyde in this manere
Where is youre fader o Grisildis he sayde
And she with reuerence in humble cheere
Answerde lord he is al redy heere
And she goth with outen lenger lette
And to the Markys she hir fader fette
He by the hand than took this olde man
And seyde thus whan he hym hadde asyde
Ianicula I neither may ne kan
Lenger the plesance of myn herte hyde
If that thow vouche sauf what so bityde
Thy doghter wol I take er that I wende
As for my wyf vn to my lyues ende
Thow louest me I woot it wel certeyn
And art my feithful lige man ybore
And al that liketh me I dar wel seyn
It liketh thee and specially ther fore
Tel me that point that I haue seyd bifore
If that thow wolt vn to that purpos drawe
To take me as for thy sone in lawe
The sodeyn cas this man astoneyd so
That reed he weex abayst and al quakyng
He stood vnnethe seyde he wordes mo
But oonly this lord quod he my willyng
Is as ye wole ne ayeins youre likyng
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so deere
Right as yow list gouerneth this matere
Yet wol I quod this Markys softely
That in thy chambre I and thow and she
Haue a collacioun and wostow why
For I wol aske if it hir wille be
To be my wyf and rule hir after me
And al this shal be doon in thy persence
I wol noght speke out of thyn audience
And in the chambre whil they were aboute
Hir tretys which as ye shal after heere
The peple cam vn to the hous with oute
And wondred hem in how honeste manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader deere
But outrely Grisildis wondre myghte
For neuere eft ne saw she swich a sighte
No wonder is thogh that she were astoned
To seen so greet a gest come in to place
She neuere was to swiche gestes woned
For which she looked with ful pale face
But shortly forth this matere for to chace
Thise arn the wordes that this Markys sayde
To this benygne verray feithful mayde
Grisilde he seyde ye shal wel vnderstonde
It liketh to youre fader and to me
That I yow wedde and eek it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
But thise demandes aske I first quod he
That sith it shal be doon in hastif wyse
Wol ye assente or ellis yow auyse
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To al my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynketh do yow laughe or smerte
And neuere ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eek whan I sey ye ne sey nat nay
Neither by word ne frownyng contenance
Swere this and heere I swere oure alliance
Wondrynge vp on this word quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne or vnworthy
I am to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self right so wol I
And heere I swere that neuere willyngly
In werk ne thoght I nel yow disobeye
For to be deed thogh me were looth to deye
This is ynough Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobre cheere
Out at the dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wyf quod he that standeth heere
Honureth hire and loueth hire I preye
Who so me loueth ther is namoore to seye
And for that no thyng of hir olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommen sholde dispoylen hir right there
Of which thise ladys were noght right glad
To handle hir clothes wher Inne she was clad
But nathelees this mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe
Hir herys han they kembd that laye vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A coroune on hir heed they han ydressed
ꝙquoday tyred hire heed that longe rudely lay dressed
And sette hir ful Nowches grete and smale
Of hir array what sholde I make a tale
Sche is now fair of hew that arst was pale
Vnnethe the peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she translated was in swich richesse
This Markys hath hire spoused with a ryng
Broght for the same cause and thanne hir sette
Vp on an hors snow whyt and wel amblyng
And to his palays er he lenger lette
With ioyful peple that hir ledde and mette
Convoied hire and thus the day they spende
In reuel til the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth this tale for to chace
I seye that to this newe Markysesse
God hath swich fauour sent hire of his grace
That it ne semed nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an Oxes Stalle
But norissed in an Emperours halle
Was as well tauȝt as any wiȝt in an emperours halle
To euery wight she woxen is so deere
And worshipful that folk ther she was bore
That from hir burthe knewe hir yeer by yeere
Vnnethe trowed they but dorste han swore
That to Ianicle of which I spak bifore
She doghter were for as by coniecture
Hem thoughte she was another creature
For thogh that euere vertuous was she
She was encressed in swich excellence
Of thewes goode yset in heigh bountee
And so discreet and fair of eloquence
So benygne and so digne of reuerence
And koude so the peples herte embrace
That ech hir louede that looked on hir face
Noght oonly of Saluce in the town
Publissed was the bountee of hir name
But eek bisyde in many a Regioun
If oon seyde wel another seyde the same
So spradde of hir heighe bountee the fame
That men and wommen as wel yonge as olde
Goon to Saluce on hir to biholde
Thus Walter lowely nay but roially
Wedded with fortunat honestetee
In goddes pees lyueth ful esily
At hom and outward grace ynow hath he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hyd the peple hym helde
A prudent man and that is seyn ful selde
Noght oonly this Grisildis thurgh hir wit
Koude al the feet of wifly humblenesse
But eek whan that the cas required it
The commune profit koude she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land that she ne koude apese
And wisly brynge hem alle in reste andese
Thogh that hir housbond absent were anon
If gentil men or othere of hir contree
Were wrothe she wolde bryngen hem aton
So wise and rype wordes hadde she
And Iuggementz of so greet equytee
That she from heuene sent was as men wende
Peple to saue and euery wrong tamende
Nat longe tyme after that this Grisild
Was ywedded she a doghter hath ybore
Al hadde hir leuere haue had a knaue child
Glad was the Markys and the folk ther fore
For thogh a mayde child coome al bifore
She may vn to a knaue child atteyne
By liklyhede syn she nys nat bareyne
¶ Incipit tercia pars
Ther fil as it bifalleth tymes mo
Whan that this child hath souked but a throwe
This Markys in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myghte out of his herte throwe
This merueilous desir his wyf tassaye
Nedelees god woot he thoghte hir for tafraye
Forbere / wherfore he purposid on a day
He hadde assayed hir ynow bifore
And fond hir euere good what neded it
Hir for to tempte and alwey moore and moore
Thogh som men preyse it for a subtil wit
But as for me I seye that yuele it sit
Tassaye a wyf whan that it is no nede
And putten hir in angwyssh and in drede
For which this Markys wroghte in this manere
He cam allone a nyght ther as she lay
With steerne face and with ful trouble cheere
And seyde thus Grisilde quod he that day
That I yow took out of your poure array
And putte yow in estat of heigh noblesse
Ye haue nat that forgeten as I gesse
I seye Grisilde this persent dignitee
In which that I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh yow nat foryetful for to be
That I yow took in poure estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mote your seluen knowe
Tak hede of euery word that I yow seye
Ther is no wight that hereth it but we tweye
Ye woot your self wel how that ye cam heere
In to this hous it is nat longe ago
And thogh to me that ye be lief and deere
Vnto my gentils ye be no thyng so
They seyn to hem it is greet shame and wo
For to be subgitz and been in seruage
To thee that born art of a smal village
And namely sith thy doghter was ybore
Thise wordes han they spoken doutelees
But I desire as I haue doon bifore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste and pees
I may nat in this cas be recchelees
I moot doon with thy doghter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my peple leste
And yet god woot this is ful looth to me
But nathelees with outen your wityng
I wol nat doon but this wol I quod he
That ye to me assente as in this thyng
Shewe now youre pacience in your wirkyng
As we accorded was at the begynnyng
That ye me highte and swore in yone village
By youre bihest a fore youre fader ᵒage
That day that maked was oure mariage
Whan she hadde herd al this she noght ameued
Neither in word or cheere or contenance
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seyde lord al lith in your plesance
My child and I with hertly obeisance
Been youres al and ye mowe saue or spille
Youre owene thyng werketh after your wille
Ther may no thyng god so my soule saue
Liken to yow that may displesen me
Ne I ne desire no thyng for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly thee vel ye
This wyl is in myn herte and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to oother place
Glad was this Markys of hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were nat so
Al drery was his cheere and his lookyng
Whan that he sholde out of the chambre go
Soone after this a furlang wey or two
He pryuely hath told al his entente
Vn to a man and to his wyf hym sente

A maner sergeant was this priuee man
The which that feithful ofte he founden hadde
In thynges grete and eek swich folk wel kan
Doon execucioun in thynges badde
The lord knew wel that he m loued and dradde
And whan this sergeant wiste his lordes wille
In to the chambre he stalked hym ful stille
Madame he seyde ye mote foryeue it me
Thogh I do thyng to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that ful wel knowe ye
That lordes hestes mowe nat ben yfeyned
They mowe wel been biwailled or compleyned
But men mote nede vn to hir lust obeye
And so wol I ther is namoore to seye
This child I am comaunded for to take
And spak namoore but out the child he hente
Despitously and gan a cheere make
As thogh he wolde han slayn it er he wente
Grisildis moot al suffre and al consen te
And as a lamb she sitteth meke and stille
And leet this crewel sergeant doon his wille
Suspecious was the diffame of this man
Suspect his face suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doghter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right tho
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked
Conformynge hire to that the Markys liked
But at the laste speken she bigan
And mekely she to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she moste kisse hir child er that it deyde
And on hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kesse
And thus she seyde in hir benygne voys
Fare wel my child I shal thee neuere see
But sith I thee haue marked with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy soule litel child I hym bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trowe that to a Norice in this cas
It hadde been hard this routhe for to se
Wel myghte a moder haue cryd allas
But nathelees so sad stedefast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn youre litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wol I pray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbad yow at the leeste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That bestes ne no bryddes it to race
But he no word wol to that purpos seye
But took the child and wente vp on his weye
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and playn
And hym persenteth with his doghter deere
Som what this lord hadde routhe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes doon whan they wol han hir wille
And bad this Sergeant that he pryuely
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tendrely
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp on peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entente
Ne whennes he cam ne whider that he wente
But at Boloigne he to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
Incipit pars quarta
IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly geant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte

¶ Wel qd this Ianuar and hast thou saide

Lette voiden al this hous in curteise wise
And they haue done right as he wol devise
Men drynken and the travers drawen anon
The brid was brought in bed as stil as ston
And when the bed was with the prest blessed
Oute of the Chambre hath eủer/rey wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath fast in Armys take
His fresshe May his Paradise his make
He lulleth hure he kissith hure ful ofte
With thikke bristles of his berde vnsofte
Like to the skyn of houndis fisshe sharpe as abrere
For he was shave al newe in his manere
He rubbeth hure a boute hure tendre face
And seide thus alas y mot trespace
To you my spouse and you gretly offende
Or tyme com that y wolde doun descende
But natheles considerith thus qd he
There nys no werke man what so eủer/ree he be
That may bothe werke wel and hastily
This wil be don at leiser parfitly
Hit is no force hou longe that we pley
In true wedlok coupeled be we twey
And blessed by the yoke that we ben Inne
Fo in actes we mowe do no synne
Aman may do no synne with his wif
Ne hurte hym self with his owne knif
For we haue leve for to pleie as by the lawe
Thus laboureth he til that the day gan dawe
And then he takith a soppe of fyne Clarre
And vpright in his bed then sittith he
And aftur that he songe ful loude and clere
And kyst his wif and made wantou chere
He was al Coltisshe ful of Ragerie
And ful of gargon as a flekked pie
The slak skyn a boute his necke shakith
While that he songe . so chauntith he and crakith
And god wote what that May thought in hure harte
When she sawe hym vprisyng in sharte
In his nyght Cappe and with his necke lene
She preisith not his pleyng worth a bene
Then seide he thus my rest wol y take
Nowe day is com y may no lenger wake
And doun he leide his hede and slepte til pryme
And afturward when that he sawe his tyme
Vprisith Ianuarie . but the fresshe May
Hilde hure Chambre vnto the . iiij . th day
As vsage is of wifis for the best
For eủer/rey laboure somtyme motte haue rest
Or elles longe may he not endure
This is to seyne none lyvis creature
Be it fisshe or Brid best or man
Nowe wol y speke. of woful Damyan
That languysshith for love as ye shal here
There for y speke to hym in this manere
¶ I seide . o . selye Damyan alas right
Aunswere to my demaunde as in this cas
Hou shalte thou to thy lady fresshe May
Tel thy woo . she wol alwey sey nay
Eke yif thou speke she wol thy wo bewrey
God be thyn helpe y can no bettʳ sey
This seke Damyan in venus fire
So brennyth that he dieth for desire
For which he puttith his lif in a venture
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But prively a Pennar gan he borowe
And in a lettre wrote he all his sorowe
In mane of a compleynte or a lay
Vn to this feire fresshe May
And in a Purs of silke . hyng on his shert
He hath put it and layde it at his hert
The mone that atte noon was that ilke day
That Ianuarie hath weddid the fresshe May
In two of Taure was in to Cancr gliden
So longe hath Mayus in hure Chambre biden
As custom is vnto thise nobles alle
A bride shall not ete yn the halle
Til days . iiij . or . iij . daies at the leste
Passed ben then let hure go to feste
The . iiij . th day complete from non to none
When that the high masse was done
In hal sate this Ianuarie and May
As freshe as is the bright someres day
And so befele hou that this good man
Remembrid hym vppon Damyan
And seide seynt Mary hou may it be
That Damyan entendith not to me
Is he ay seke or how may it betide
His Squyers which that stoden by his side
Excused hym by cause of his sikenesse
Which lettid hym to don his bisynesse
None other cause myght make hym tarie
That me forthynkith qd this Ianuarie
He is a Ientil Squyere by my truthe
Yif that he died it were harme and ruthe
He is as wise discrete . and as secre
As eny man y knowe of his degre
And therto manly and eke servisable
And for to be aman trusty and able
And aftur mete as sone as eủer/ree y may
I will my self visite hym and eke may
To don all the comforte that y can
And for that worde hym blessid eủer/rey man
That of his bountie and his Ientilnesse
He wolde so comfort in seknesse
His Squyer for his Ientil dede
Dame qd this Ianuarie take good hede
At aftur mete ye with youre wymmen alle
When ye haue ben in Chambre oute of this halle
That alle ye gone to se this Damyan
Doith hym disporte he is a Ientilman
And telleth hym that y wil hym visite
Haue y nothyng do but rest me a lite
And spede you fast for y wol a bide
Til that ye slepe first by my side
And with that worde he gan to hym calle
A Squyer that was Marchall of the halle
And tolde hym certayne thynges that he wolde
This fresshe May hath streight hure wey holde
With al hure wymmen vnto Damyan
Doun by his beddis side sette she hure than
Comfortyng hym as goodly as she may
This Damyan when he his tyme say
In secrete wise his purs and eke his bille
In which that he writen had his wille
Hath putte in to hure honde withoute more .
Save that he sighith wondre sore
And softly to hure right thus seide he
Mercie and that ye not bewreie me
For y am dede yif that thynges be kid
This purs she within hure bosom hid
And went hure wey ye gete no more of me
But vnto Ianuarie ageyne comyn is she
That on his bed side sate ful softe
And takith hure and kissith hure ful ofte
And leide hym doun to slepe and that a non
She feyned hure as though she moste gon
There as ye wote that eủer/rey wight moste nede
And when she of this bille had takyn hede
She rent it al to peces at the last
And in the prive softly it cast
Who stodieth nowe but faire fresshe May
A doun by olde Ianuarie she lay
That slepte til the Cough hath hym waked
Anon he preide hure to stripen hure al naked
He wolde of hure he seide haue som pleasaunce
And seide hure cloth did hym combraunce
And she obeith hym be the lef or loth
But lest that precious folke be with me wroth
Howe that he wrought y dar not you tel
Or whethir hure thought it Paradise or hel
But here y leh tehym werkyn in this wise
Til evensong rong . and that they moste rise
Were it by desteny or by a venture
Were it by influence . or nature
Or Constellaciou that in suche estate
The heven stode in that tyme fortunate
Was for to put a Bil of venus werkis
For all thyng hath tyme as seyne thise Clerkis
To eủer/rey womman for to gete hure love
I cannot sey but grete god a bove
That knowith that none acte is causeles
He deme of al for y wol holde my pes
But soth is this hou that the fresshe May
Hath take suche impressiou that day
Of pite of this seke Damyan
That fro hure harte she ne drive can
The remembraunce for to don hym ease
Certeyne thought she whom that thise thynges displease
Y recke not for hure . y hym assuere
To love hym best of eny creature
Though he no more had then his shert
Lo pite renneth sone in Ientil hert
Here may ye se hou excellent Fraunchise
In womman is whan they them narowe avise
Som tyraunt is as there ben many on
That hath an harte as hard as eny ston
Which wolde haue let hym starve in that place
Wel rather then haue grauntid hym hure grace
And hym reioisen in hure cruel pride
And recke not to ben an homicide
This Ientil May fulfilled of pite
Right of hure honde a lettre makith she
In which she grauntid hym hure verrey grace
There lackith nought but only . day and space
There as she myght vnto his lust suffise
For it shalbe right as he wol devise
And when she saugh hure tyme vppon a day
To visite this Damyan goith this May
And softly this lettre doun she threst
Vnder his pelowe rede ht yif hym lest
She toke hym be the hande . and hard hym twyst
So secrettly that no man it wist
And bade hym be al hole and forth she went
To Ianuarie whan that he for hure sent
Vp risith Damyan the next morowe
Al passed is his sekenes and his sorowe
He kembith hym proyneth and pikith
He doith al that his lady lust and likith
And eke to Ianuarie he goith as lowe
As eủer/ree did a dogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt to eủer/rey man
For crafte is al . who so that do it can
That eủer/rey wight his faine to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stood
Thus latte y Damyan a boute his nede
And in my tale furth wol y procede
Som Clerkis holden that felicite
Stont in delite and therfore certeyne he
This noble Ianuarie with al his myght
In honest wise as longeth to a knyght
Shope hym to lyve ful deliciously
His house is arraied as honestly
To his degre was made as a skyng
Amonges other of his honest thyng
He made agardyn walled al with stone
A fairere gardyn wote y no where none
For oute of doute y verreily suppose
That he that wrote the Romaunce of the Rose
He coude of hit the beaute wel devise
Ne Priapus myght not suffise
Though he be god of Gardens for to telle
The beaute of the Gardyn and the welle
That stode vnder a laurer alwey grene
Full ofte tyme Pluto and his Quene
Proserpina and al hure fairie
Disporten them and makyn melodie
A boute that welle and daunsyng as men tolde
This noble knyght Ianuarie the olde
Suche deynte hath in hit to walke and pley
That he wolde suffre no wight to bere the key
But he hym self for of the smal wiket
He bare alway of silvir a Cliket
With which when that hym list . he it vnshet
And whan he wolde pay his wifis det
In somer season thider wolde he go
And May his wif and no wight but they two
And thynges which that were not done a bedde
He in the gardeyn . ꝑper/parformed them and spedde
As in this wise ful many a mery day
Levith this Ianuarie and this fresshe May
But worldly ioy may not alway endure
To Ianuarie ne to . no creature
O . sodayn hap . o . thou fortune vnstable
Like to the Scorpyon so disceyvable
That flaterest with thyn hede when that thou wilte styng
Thy taile is deth thrugh thyn enveinymiyng
O . brotel ioy of swete venym queynte
O . monstre that so sotelly canst peynte
Thy yiftis vnder hue . of stedfastnesse
That thou desceivest bothe more and lesse
Why has thou Ianuarie thus desceivid
That haddist hym for thy ful frende receivid
And nowe thou hast birafte hym bothe his yeen
For sorowe of which he desirith to dyen
Alas this noble Ianuarie the fre
In myddis of his lust and his prosꝑper/parite
Is woxen blynde . and that so sodenly
He wepith and he wailith also pitouslys
And there with al the fire of Ielosy
Lest that his wif shulde falle in som foly
So brent his hart that he wolde fayne
That som man bothe hure and hym had slayne
For neither aftur his deth ne his lif
Ne wolde he that she were no love ne wif
But eủer/ree live as a widowe in clothis blake
And morne as the Turtil that lost hath hure make
But at the last aftur a moneth or twey
His sorowe gan to swage sothe to sey
For whan he wist it myght none other be
He paciently toke his adủer/resite
Save oute of doute he may not forgon
That he nas Ielous eủer/remore in on
Which Ielousie it was outragious
That neither in hal ne in none other hous
Ne in none other place neủer/ree the mo
He nolde suffre hure for to ride ne go
But yif that he had honde on hure alway
For which ful ofte wepith fresshe may
That lovith Damyan so benygnely
That she most other dien sodenly
Or ellis she mot haue hym as hure lest
She waitith whan hure harte wolde brest
Vppon that other side Damyan
Bicom is the sorowfullist man
That eủer/ree was . for neither nyght ner day
Ne myght he speke a worde to fresshe May
As to this pʳpos of no suche matere
But yif that Ianuarie most it here
That had an honde vppon hure eủer/remo
But natheles by writyng to and fro
And prive signes wist he what she ment
And she knewe eke the syne of his entent
¶ O . Ianuarie what myght it a vaile
Though thou myght seen as ferre as shippis saile
For as gode is blynde desceivid be
As ben desceivid . whan a man may se
Lo Argus . which had an . C . yeen
For al that eủer/ree he coude poure or pryen
Yit was he blynde as god wote so ben mo
That wenyn wisly that it be not so
Passe oủer/ree is an ease y seie nomore
This fresshe May that y speke of bifore
In warme wax . hath emprynted the Cliket
That Ianuarie bare of the smale wiket
By which to hir gardyn ofte he went
And damyan that knewe al hure entent
The Cliket countrefetid prively
There is no more to sey but hastely
Som wondre by thes Cliket shall betide
Which ye shulle here yif ye woll a bide
O . noble Ouide full soth seist thou god wote .
What sleight is it though it be longe and hote
That love nyll fynde it oute in som manere
By Priamus and Tesbe may ye lere
Though they were kepte full longe and streite oủer/ree al
There no wight coude haue founde on suche a sleight
They ben accordid rounyn thrugh a wal
But nowe to oure purpos er that days eight
Were passed or that the noneth of Iule bifel
That Ianuarie hath caught so grete a wil
Thrugh eggyng of his wif hym for to pley
In his gardeyn and no wight but they twey
That in a morowe vnto this May seith he
Rise vp my wif my love my lady fre
The turtils voice is harde my wif so swete
The wynter is gon with his reynes wete
Comforth nowe with thyn yeen columbyne
With thy brestis whitter then y can devyne
The gardeyn is enclosed al a boute
Comforth my swete spouse for oute of doute
Thou has me woundid in myn hert . o . wif
No spot ne knowe y in the in al my lif
Comthfurth and lette vs taken oure disporte
I chese you for May wyf and my comforte
Suche olde lewde wordis vsed he
On Damyan a syne than made sche
That he shulde go before with the Cliket
This Damyan then hath opened the wiket
And in he stert and that in suche manere
That no wight myght hym se neither neither here
And still he sate vnder a busshe anon
This Ianuarie as blynde as eny ston
With Mayus in his honde and no wight mo
Into his fresshe gardeyne is y go
And clappid to the wicket sodenly
Nowe wif qd he here is but ye and y
Ye are the creature that y best love
For bi that lorde that sittith in heven above
Leủer/ree y had to dien on a knyf
Then you offend true dere wyf
For goddis sake thynke hou y the chese
Not for no covetise doutlese
But only for the love y had to the
And though that y be olde and may not se
Bith to me true and y will tel you why
Iijᵉ thynges certis shul ye wyn therby
Furst love of Crist and to youre self honoure
And al myn heritage bothe Toun and Toure
Y yeve it you makith Charters as you lest
This shalbe don to morowe or the son rest
So wisly god my soule brynge to blisse
I pray you first in covenaunt ye me kysse
And though y be Ielous wite me nought
Ye ben so depe empreynted in my thought
That when y considre youre beaute
And therewith al the vnlickly age of me
I may not certis though y shulde die
For bere to ben oute of youre companye
For verrey love this is withoutyn doute
Nowe kysse me wif and lette vs rome aboute
This fresshe May . when she thise wordes herde
Benygnely to Ianuarie she aunswerde
But first and forward she be gan to wepe
I haue qd she god wote a soule to kepe
Also wel as ye . and also myn honoure
And of my wifhode thilke tendre floure
Which that y haue assured in youre honde
Whan that the prest to you my body bonde
Wher for I woll answer in þˢ man
By the leve of you that be my lorde so dere
I pray to god that neủer/ree dawe the day
That y ne sterve as foule as womman may
Yif eủer/ree y do vnto my kyn that shame
Or elles yif that y empeire so my name
That y be fals . and yif y do that lacke
Do stripe me and put me in a sacke
And in the nexte River do me drenche
I am a Ietilwomman and no wenche
Why speke ye thus . but men ben eủer/ree vntrewe
And wommen haue of you ay repreve newe
And with that worde she sawe where Damyan
Sate in a bushe and cough she began h
¶ And with hure fynger assigne made sche
That Damyan shulde clyme vppon a Tre
That charged was with fruyt and vp he went
For verrely he knewe al hure entent
And eủer/rey sygne that she she coude make
Wel bettre than Ianuarie hure owne make
For in a lre she had tolde hym alle
Of this matere hou he werkyn shalle
And thus y lette hym sytte vppon this pirie
And Ianuarie and May romyng ful merie
Bright was the day and blue the firmament
Phebus hath of golde his streames doun sent
That gladen eủer/rey floure with there warmnesse
He was that tyme in Gemynys as y gesse
But litle from his declinacion
Of Cancer Iouis . exaltaciou
And so it befel in that bright morowe tide
That in that Gardeyne in the ferther side
Pluto that is kynge of Fairie
And many a lady in his companie
Folowyng the Quene his wif Proserpina
Which that he ravisshed oute of Cithia
While that she gadred floures in the mede
In Claudian ye may the stories rede
Hou in grislely Carte he hure sette
This kynge of Fairie doun hym sette
Vppon a benche of turves fresshe and grene
And right anon thus seide he to his Quene
Nowe wif qd he there may no wight seye nay
The ful exꝑper/parience so provith it eủer/rey day
The treasou which that wymmen don to man
X . C . M . ˢ wel tel y can
Notable of youre vntrouth and brotilnesse
O . noble Salamon Richist of Richesse
Fulfilled of Sapience and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy ben thy wordes to memorie
To eủer/rey wight that wit and reason can
Thus preisith he yit the bountie of man
A monge a . M . men yit founde y one
But of wymmen al yit founde y none
Thus seith this kyng that knowith youre wickidnesse
And Iesus filius Sirac as y gesse
Ne spekith of you but selde reủer/reence
A wilde fire and corrupte pestilence
So fal vppon youre bodies yit to nyght
Ne se ye not this honourable knyght
By cause allas that he is blynde and olde
His owne man shal make hym cockholde
Lo where he sittith the lecchoure on the tre
Nowe shal y graunte of my magiste
Vnto this olde blynde worthy knyght
That he shall haue ageyne his yeen sight
And whan that his wif . wolde don hym a vilanye
Than shal he knowe al hure harlatrie
Bothe in rapref of hure and other mo
Ye Sir . qd . Proserpina wol ye so
Nowe by my Moders soule Sir I you swere
That y shal yeve hure sufficiaunt aunswere
And al wymmen aftur for hure sake
That though they ben in eny gilt take
With face bolde they shul them self excuse

l.seg: And ber them doon þᵗat wold hem acuse

div.l: For lacke of aunswere non of them shull dien
All had aman seyn a thyng with his yeen
Yit shull we wymmen visage it hardely
And wepe and swere and chide subtilly
So that ye men shul be as lewid as gese
What reckith me of youre auctoritese
I wote wel that this Iewe this Salamon
Founde of vs wivis . foles many on
But though that he fonde no good womman
Yit hath there founden many a nother man
Wymmen ful true ful good and vertuous
Witnes of them that wel in cristis hous
With Martirdom they provid there constaunce
The Romayns Iestes eke makyn remembraunce
Of many a verrey true wif also
But sir be not wroth al be it so
Though that he seide he fonde no true womman
I pray you take this sentence of that man
He ment thus that in soủer/reaygne bountie

l.seg: Nys non but good neyþ̉er/re he ne sche

div.l: Ey for verrey god that nys but one
What make ye so moche of Salamon
What though he made a Temple goddis house
What though it were riche and gloriouse
He made it a Temple eke of fals goddis
Who myght do a thyng that more for bode is
Parde as feire as ye his name emplastre
He was alechoure and an ydolastre
And in his elde he verrey god for soke
And yif that god ne had as seith the boke
Spared hym for his fadres sake he sholde
Haue lost his reigne rather then he wolde
I set not of al the vilanye
That he of wymmen wrote a buttirflye
I am a wōmman nedes most y speke
Or elles swelle till myn hart breke
For sith he seide that we be Iangeleresses
As eủer/ree hole mot y bouk my tresses
I shall not spare for no curtesie
To spekyn hym harme that wolde vs vilanye
Dame qd this Pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeve it vp . but sith y swore myn oth
That y wolde graunt hym his sight ageyne
My worde shal stande y warne you certeyne
I am kynge it sittith me not to lie
And y qd she a Quene of feirie
Hure aunswere shal she haue y vndertake
Lette vs no mo hereof make
For sothe y woll no lenger you contrarie
Nowe let vs turne ayen to Ianuarie
¶ That in the gardeyn with his faire May
Syngeth merier then the Popyniay
You love y best and shal . and other none
So longe a boute the aleis he is gon
Till he was comen a geyne the pirie
Where as Damyan sittith full merie
An high amonges the fresshe levis grene
This fresshe May that is so bright and shene
Gan for to sygh and seide allas my side
Nowe sir qd she for ought that may betide
I moste haue one of the peris that y se
Or y mot die so sore longith me
To eten of the smale peris grene
Helpe for hure love that is heven Quene
I tel you wel a womman in my plite
May haue to fruyt . so grete an appetite
That she may dien but she it haue
Allas qd he that y haue here no knave
That coude clyme alas alas qd he
For y am blynde. ye Sir no force qd she
But wolde . ye whitsave for goddis sake
The pirie within youre armes for to take
For well y wote that ye mystrust me
Then shulde y clyme wel y nough qd she
So y my fote may set vppon youre backe
Certis qd he thereof shalbe no lacke
Might y helpen you with my harte blode
He stouped doun and she vppon his bak stode
And caught hure a twist and vp she goith
Ladies y praie you that ye be not wroith
I cannot glose y am a rude man
And sodenly anon this Damyan
Gan pullen vppe the smok and in he throng
And when that Pluto saugh this grete wrong
To Ianuarie yave anon his sight
That he myght se aswel as eủer/ree he might
And whan that he had caught his sight a geyne
Ne was ther neủer/ree man of sight so feyne
But on his wif his thought was eủer/ree mo
Vppon the tre he cast his yeen two
And saugh that Damyan . his wif had dressed
In suche mane it may not be expressed
But yif y wolde speke vncurteislye
And vp he yave a roryng and a crye
As doith the Moder . whan the childe shal die
Oute helpe alas harowe he gan to crie
O . stronge ladye store what doist thou
And she aunswerd Sir . what eilith you
Haue pacience and reason yn youre mynde
I haue you holpen of bothe youre yeen blynde
Vppon ꝑper/parel of my soule y shal not lyen
As me was taught to helen with youre yen
Was nothyng better to make you se
Then to strogle with a man vppon a tre
God wote I did it in ful good entente
Strogle qd he . ye algate . In it went
God yeve you bothe on shames deth to dyen
He swivid the y saugh it with myn yen dhertil
And elles be I hanged by the hals
Sir then is qd she my medicyne fals
For certeyne yif that ye myght se
Ye wolde not sey thise wordes vnto me
Ye haue som glemeryng and no ꝑper/parfite sight
I se qd he aswel as eủer/ree y myght
Thanked be god with myn yeen two
And by my trouth me thought he did the so
¶ The mase the mase good Sir qd she
This thanke haue y for y haue make you se
Alas qd she that eủer/ree y was so kynde

div.l: (base) And on this Faukon looketh pitously
(base) And heeld hir lappe abrood for wel she wiste
(base) The Faukon moste fallen fro the twiste
(base) Whan that it swowneth next for lakke of blood

(base) Vnto the hauk as ye shal after heere

(base) Is this for sorwe of deeth or los of loue
(base) For as I trowe thise been causes two

(base) For ye your self vpon yow self yow wreke

(base) That ferde with hymself so pitously
(base) Ye sleen me with youre sorwe verraily
(base) I haue of yow so greet compassioun
(base) For goddes loue com fro the tree adoun

(base) If that I verraily the cause knewe

(base) To heele with youre hurtes hastily
(base) Tho shrighte this Faukon yet moore pitously
(base) Ye sle me with your sorwe verrily cat

(base) That pitee renneth soone in gentil herte

div.l: (base) As wel by werk as by auctoritee
(base) For gentil herte kitheth gentilesse
(base) I se wel that ye han of my distresse
(base) Compassion my faire Canacee
(base) Of verray wommanly benygnitee
(base) That nature in youre principles hath set
(base) But for noon hope for to fare the bet
(base) But for to obeye vnto youre herte free
(base) And for to maken othere ywar by me
(base) As by the whelp chasted is the leoun
(base) Right for that cause and for that conclusioun
(base) Whil that I haue a leyser and a space
(base) Myn harm I wol confessen er I pace
(base) And euere whil that oon hir sorwe tolde
(base) That oother weep as she to water wolde

(base) And with a syk right thus she seyde hir wille
(base) Ther I was bred allas that ilke day

(base) Til I koude fle ful hye vnder the sky
(base) Tho dwelte a tercelet me faste by
(base) That semed welle of alle gentillesse
(base) Al were he ful of trayson and falsnesse
(base) It was so wrapped vnder humble cheere
(base) And vnder hewe of trouthe in swich manere
(base) Vnder plesaunce and vnder bisy peyne

(base) And kepeth in semblant alle hise obseruaunces

(base) That sownen in to gentilesse of loue
(base) As on a Tombe is al the faire aboue

div.l: (base) Al Innocent of his crowned malice
(base) For fered of his deeth as thoughte me
(base) Vpon his othes and his seuretee
(base) Graunted hym loue vpon this condicioun
(base) This euere mo myn honour and renoun
(base) Were saued bothe pryuee and apert
(base) This is to seyn that after his desert
(base) I yaf hym al myn herte and my thoght
(base) God woot and he that oother wise noght
(base) And took his herte in chaunge of myn for ay
(base) But sooth is seyd goon sithen many a day
(base) A trewe wight and a theef thynketh nat oon
(base) And whanne he saw the thyng so fer ygon
(base) That I hadde graunted hym fully my loue
(base) In swich a gise as I haue seyd aboue
(base) And yeuen hym my trewe herte as fre
(base) As he swoor he yaf his herte to me
(base) Anoon this tygre ful of doublenesse
(base) Fil on his knees with so deuout humblesse
(base) With so heigh reuerence and as by his cheere
(base) So lyk a gentil louere of manere
(base) So rauysshed as it semed for the ioye
(base) That neuere Iason ne Parys of Troye
(base) Iason certes ne noon oother man
(base) Syn Lameth was that alderfirst bigan
(base) To louen two as writen folk biforn
(base) Ne neuere syn the firste man was born
(base) Ne koude man by twenty thousand part
(base) Countrefete the Sophymes of his art
(base) Ne were worthy vnbokele his galoche
(base) Ther doublenesse or feynyng sholde approche
(base) Ne so koude thanke a wight as he did me
(base) His manere was an heuene for to see
(base) Til any womman were she neuer so wys
(base) So peynted he and kembde at poynt deuys
(base) As wel his wordes as his contenaunce
(base) And I so loued hym for his obeisaunce
(base) And for the trouthe I demed in his herte
(base) That if so weere that any thyng hym smerte
(base) Al were it neuer so litel and I it wiste

div.l: (base) That my wyl was his willes Instrument
(base) This is to seyn my wyl obeyed his wil
(base) In alle thyng as fer as reson fil
(base) Kepynge the boundes of my worship euere
(base) Ne neuere hadde I thyng so lief ne leuere
(base) As hym god woot ne neuere shal namo
(base) This laste lenger than a yeer or two
(base) That I supposed of hym nat but good
(base) But finally thus at the laste it stood
(base) That Fortune wolde that he moste twynne
(base) Out of that place which that I was Inne
(base) Wher me was wo that is no questioun
(base) I kan nat make of it descripsioun
(base) For o thyng dar I tellen boldely
(base) I knowe what is the peyne of deeth ther by
(base) Swich harm I felte for he ne myghte bileue
(base) So on a day of me he took his leue
(base) So sorwefully eek that I wende verraily
(base) That he hadde feelyd as muche harm as I
(base) Whan that I herde hym speke and saw his hewe
(base) But nathelees I thoughte he was so trewe
(base) And eek that he repeyre sholde agayn
(base) With Inne a litel while sooth to sayn
(base) And reson wolde eek that he moste go
(base) For his honour as ofte happeth so
(base) Wherfor I wold not ben ayein his honour
(base) That I made vertu of necessitee
(base) And took it wel syn that it moste be
(base) As I best myghte I hidde from hym my sorwe
(base) And took hym by the hand Seint Iohn to borwe
(base) And seyde thus lo I am youres al
(base) Beeth swich as I to yow haue been and shal
(base) What he answerde it nedeth nat reherse
(base) Who kan seyn bet than he who kan doon werse
(base) Whan he hath al wel seyd thanne hath he doon
(base) Therfore bihoued hire a ful long spoon
(base) That shal ete with a feend thus herde I seye
(base) So at the laste he moste forth his weye
(base) And forth he fleeth til he cam ther hym leste
(base) Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
(base) I trowe he hadde thilke text in mynde
(base) That alle thyng repeiryng to his kynde

div.l: (base) Gladeth hymself thus seyn men as I gesse
(base) Men louen of propre kynde Newfangelnesse
(base) As bryddes doon that men in Cages feede
(base) For theigh thow nyght and day take of hem hede
(base) And strawe hir Cages faire and softe as sylk
(base) And yeue hem sugre hony breed and Milk
(base) Yet right anon as that his dore is vppe
(base) He with his feet wol sporne doun his cuppe
(base) And to the wode he wole and wormes ete
(base) So newfangel been they of hir mete
(base) And louen nouelries of propre kynde
(base) No gentilesse of blood may hem bynde
(base) So ferde this gentil tercelet allas the day
(base) Thogh he were gentil born and fressh and gay
(base) And goodlich for to seen and humble and free
(base) He saw vpon a tyme a kyte flee
(base) And sodeynly he loued this kyte so
(base) That al his loue is clene fro me ago
(base) And hath his trouthe falsed in this wise
(base) Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir seruyse
(base) And I am lorn withouten remedye
(base) And with that word this Faukon gan to crye
(base) And swowned eft in Canacees barm
(base) Greet was the sorwe for the haukes harm
(base) That Canacee and alle hir wommen made
(base) They nyste how that they myghte the Faukon glade
(base) But Canacee hom bereth hire in hir lappe
(base) And softely in plastres gan hir wrappe
(base) Ther as she with hir beek hadde hurt hir selue
(base) Now kan nat Canacee but herbes delue
(base) Out of the grownd and maken saues newe
(base) Of herbes preciouse and fyn of hewe
(base) To heelen with this hauk fro day to nyght
(base) She dooth hir bisynesse and al hir myght
(base) And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
(base) And couered it with veluettes blue
(base) In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
(base) And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
(base) In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
(base) As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles

div.l: (base) Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
(base) And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
(base) Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
(base) I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
(base) Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn
(base) How that this Faukon gat hir loue ageyn
(base) Repentant as the storie telleth vs
(base) By mediacion of Cambalus
(base) The kynges sone of which I to yow tolde
(base) But hennes fort I wol my proces holde
(base) To speke of auentures and of batailles
(base) That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
(base) First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
(base) That in his tyme many a Citee wan
(base) And after wol I speke of Algarsyf
(base) How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
(base) For whom ful ofte in gret peril he was
(base) Ne hadde he been holpen by the Steede of bras
(base) And after wol I speke of Cambalo
(base) That faught in lystes with the bretheren two
(base) For Canacee er that he myghte hir wynne
(base) And ther I lefte I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Here endeth the Squiers tale

And bigynneth
the Prologge of the Frankleyne
In feith Squyer ye haue you well y quytte
And Ientilly y preise well youre witte
Quod the Frankeleyn considryng youre youthe
So felyngly ye speke sir y a low . the
As to my dome there is none that is here
Of eloquence . that shall be youre pere
Yif that ye leue god . yeve you good chaunce
And in vertue sende you continuaunce
For of youre speche y haue grete deynte
I haue a sonne and by the Trinite
I hadde lever then . xxᵗⁱ . li . worth of londe
Though ght nowe . were fallen in myn honde
He were a man of suche discrecion
As that ye ben fy on possessyon
But yef aman be vertuous with alle
I haue my sonne snybbed and yet shall
For he to vertue lustith not to entende
But for to pley at the dice and dispende
And lese all that he hath . is his vsage
And he hath leủer/ree talkyn with a page
Then to comune with eny Ientill wight
Where he myght lerne Ientilnes a right
¶ Strawe for thy Ientilnes qd oure hoste
What Frankeleyne parde well thou woste
That eche of you . mot tellen at the leste
A tale or . ijᵒ . or brekyn his biheste
That knowe y well sir qd the Frankeleyne
I pray you haueth me not in disdayne
Though to this man y speke a worde or twoo
Tell on thy tale withouten wordes moo
Gladly sir host qd he y woll obeie
Vnto youre will nowe herkeneth what y seie
I woll you not contrarie in no wise
As fer as that my wittis wollen suffise
I pray to god that it may plesen yowe
Then wote y well that it is good y nowe
Here endeth the Frankeleyns Prologge
And here begynneth his tale
Thise olde Ientill Brutons in there daies
Of dyủer/res aventures maden laies
Rymyng in there furst Brutons tonge
Which laies with hure Instrumentes they songe

l.seg: Or elles reden them for there plesaunce

div.l: And on of them haue y in remembraunce
Which y shall seyne with good will as y can
But sires bi cause y am a burell man
At my begynnyng first y you beseche
Haue me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neủer/ree retorik certeyne
Thyng that y speke it mot be bare and pleyne
I slepte neủer/ree on the Mounte of Parnaso
Ne lerned neủer/ree Marcus Tullius Sithero
Colours ne knewe y non withouten drede
But suche Colours as growen in the Mede
Or elles suche as men die or peynte
Colours of Retorik ben to me queynte
My sprite feleth nought of suche matere
But and you lust my tale shull ye here
¶ In Armorik that called is Brutaigne
There was a knyght that loved and did his peine
To serve a lady in his best wise
And many a laboure and many a grete emprise
He for his lady wrought er she were won
For she was one the feirest vnder the son
And eke therto comen of so high kynred
That well vnnethes durst this knyght for drede
Tell hure his wo his peyne and his distresse
But at the last she for his worthynesse
And namly for his meke obeisaunce
Hath suche apite caught of his penaunce
That p rively she fell of his accorde
To take hym for hure husbonde and hure lorde
Of suche lordship as men haue of there wivis
And for to lede the more in blisse there livis
Of his fre will he swore hure as a knyght
That neủer/ree in all his lif by day ne nyght
He nolde vppon hym take no mastrie
Ageyne hure will ne kith hure Ielousie
But hure obeie and folowe hure will in all
As eny lovier to his lady shall
Save that the name of soủer/reaignete
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
She thanked hym and with full grete humblenesse
She seide sir sith of youre Ientilnesse
Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
Ne wolde neủer/ree god bitwene vs tweyne
As in my gilt were either warre or strif
Sir ye will be youre humble true wif
Haue here my trouth till that myn harte brest
n they bothe in quiete and in rest
ng siris safly dar y seie
yche to other mot obeie
holde companye
constreyned by mastrye
When mastrie with the god of love anon h
Betith his wynges and fare well he is gon
Love is a thyng as eny sprite fre
Wymmen of kynde desiren lib̉er/rete
And not to be constreyned as a thrall
And so do men yf y soth seyne shall
Loke who is moste pacient in love
He is at his avauntage all a bove
Pacience is an high vertue certeyne
For it venquissheth as thise clerkes seyne
Thyng that rigoure shall neủer/ree atteyne
For eủer/rey worde men mowe not chide or pleyne
Lerneth to suffre or elles so mot ygon
Ye shull it lerne whether ye will or non
For in this worlde certayne there no wight ys
That he ne doth or seith somtyme a mys
Ire sekenesse or constellaciou
Wyn . wo . or chaungyng of complexiou
Causith full ofte to don amys or skekyn
On eủer/rey wronge aman may not be wrekyn
Aftur the tyme moste be temꝑper/paraunce
To eủer/rey wight that can on goủer/renaunce
And therfore hath this ewisewise worthy knyght
To live in ease suffraunce to hure behight
And she to hym full wisely gan to swere
That neủer/ree shulde be faute in here
Here mowe men seen an humble wise accorde
Thus hath she take hure servaunt and hure lorde
Servaunt in love and lorde in mariage
Then was he bothe in lordship and in servage
Servage nay but lordship a bove
Sith he he hath bothe his lady and his love
His lady certis and his wif also
To which that lawe of love accordith so
And when he was in his prosꝑper/parite
Home with his wif he goth to his Contre
Not ferre fro Penmarke there his dwellyng was
Where as he levith in blisse and inin solas
Who coude tell but he hadde weddid be
The Ioy the ease and the prosꝑper/parite
That is betwene an husbonde and his wif
A yere and more lastith this blisfull lif
Till that the knyght of which y speke of thus
That of Cairuda was clepid Aruaragus
Shope hym to gon and dwelled a yere or tweyne
In Engeland that clepid was eke Brutayne
To seke in armes worship and honoure
For all his lust he sette in suche laboure
And dwelde there . ijᵉ . yere . the boke seith thus
Nowe woll y stynt of this Aruaragus
And speke y woll of Dorigen his wif
That lovith hure husbonde as hure hertis lif
For his absence wepith she and sighigh
As done thise noble wifis when them likith
She morneth wakith waileth fastith and pleyneth
Desire of his psence hur so distreyneth
That all this worlde she set at nought
Hure frendes which that knewe hure hevy thought
Comforten hure in all that eủer/ree the may
They prechen hure they tellen hure nyght and day
That causeles she sleeth hure self alaas
And eủer/rey comfort possible in this caas
They don to hure with all hure besinesse
All for to make hure to leve hure holynesse
By processe as ye knowe eủer/reychon
Men mowe so longe graven in a stone
Till som figure therin apreynted be
So longe haue they comfortid hure till she
Resceyved hath by hope and by reasou
The empreyntyng of hure consolaciou
Thrugh which hure grete sorowe hure harte sleyne
Hure frendes hure sorowe gan to slake
And praiden hure on knees for goddis sake
To com and romen hure in companye
Away to dryve hure derke fantasye
And fynaly she graunted that request
For well she saugh it was for the best
Nowe stode hure Castell fast by the See
And often with hure frendes walked she
Hure to disporte vppon the banke on high
Where as she many a shippe and barge sigh
Seillyng ther cours where them lust to go
But then was that a ꝑper/parcell of hure wo
Nexte hure self full ofte alas seith she
Is there no ship of so many as y see ll
Will bryng home my lorde then were my harte
All warishid of his bittʳ peynes smarte
Another tyme wolde she sitte and thynke
And cast hure yeen dounward fro the brynke
But when she saugh the grisly rockis blake
For verrey fere wolde hure harte quake
That on hure fete she myght hure not sustene
Then wolde she sitte a doun vppon the grene
And pitously in to the see biholde
And seie right thus with sorowfull sighes colde
¶ Eterne god that thrugh thyn purveiaunce
Ledest the worlde by eterne goủer/renaunce
In ydill as men seie ye no thyng make
But lorde thise grisely fendly rockes blake
That semeth rath a foule confusiou
Of werke then eny feire creaciou
Of suche a parfite wise god and a stable
Why haue ye wrought thise werkis vnresnable
For by this werke South . North . West . and Este
Ther nys fostred no man brid ne beste
It doith no good to my witte but anoyeth
Se ye not lorde hou mankynde hit destruyeth
An hundred thousand bodies of mankynde
Haue rockes slayne all be they not in mynde
Which mankynde is so faire aparte of thy werke
That thou it made to thyn owne merke
Then semed it ye had a grete charite
Toward mankynde but hou then may it be
That ye suche meanes make it to destoien
Which menes doo no good but eủer/ree noyen
I wote well Clerkis woll seyn as them leste
By argumentis that all is for the best
Though y ne can the causes not knowe
But thilke god that made wynde to blowe
As kepe my lorde this is my conclusiou
To Clerkis lete y shall disputaciou
But wolde god that all thise rockes blake
Were sonkyn in to helle for his sake
Thise Rockes sleen myn harte for the fere
Thus she seide with many a pitous tere
¶ Hure frendes sawe that it was no disporte
To romen by the See but discomforte
And shopen for to pleien somwhat elles
They ledden hure by Rivers and by welles
And eke in to other places delectables
They dauncen and they pleyn atte Chesse and at tables
So on a day right in the morowe tide
Vnto a garden that was there biside
In which they had made there ordynaunce
Of victuaile and of other purveaunce
They gon to pley them all the longe day
And this was on the sixt morowe of May
Which had peynted with his softe shoures
This garden full of lefes and of floures
And crafte of Mannys hande so curiously
had this gardyn truly
That neủer/ree was ther garden of suche a prise
were the verrey Paradise
The odoure of floures and the fresshe sight
Wolde haue made eny harte light
That eủer/ree was born but yif to grete sekenesse
Or to grete sorowe helde it in distresse
So full it was of beaute with pleasaunce
And aftur dyne goo they to daunce
And synge also saue Dorigen alone
Which made alway hure complaynte and hure mone
For she nene saugh hym on the daunce go
That was hure husbonde and hure love also
But natheles she moste atyme a bide
And with good hope lette hure sorowe slide
Vppon this daunce amonge other men
Daunced a Squyer bifore Dorigen
That fresshe was and Iolier of aray
As to my dome than is the Month of May
He syngith and daunceth passyng eny man
Ther is or was sith the worlde began
Therwith he was yif men shulde discrive
On of the best faryng man on live
Yonge stronge right vertuous rich and wise
And welbeloued and holden in grete prise
And shortly yif y the sothe tell shalle
Vnwetyng of this Dorigen at alle
Thus lusty Squyer Servaunt to Venus
Which that y clepid was Aurelius
Had lovid hure best of eny creature
Two yere and more as was his a venture
But neủer/ree durst he tellen hure his grevaunce
Withoute cuppe dranke all his penaunce
He was dispeired nothyng wolde he seie
Save in his songes somwhat wolde he bebe wreie
His wo as in a Ientilll compleynyng
He seide he loved and was biloued nothyng
Of suche matere made he many laies
Songes compleyntes roundeles verelaies
Hou that he durst not his sorowe telle
But languyssheth as fire doth in helle
And die he moste he seide as did Ecko
For Narcisus that durst not tell his wo
In other mane than ye here me seie
Ne durst he not to hure his wo bewreie
Save that ꝑper/paraventure somtyme at daunces
There yonge folke kepyn there observaunces
It may wel be he loked on hure face
In suche awise as man that asketh grace
But nothyng wist she of his entente
Natheles it happid er that they thens wente
By cause that he was hure neyghtboure
And was aman of worship and honoure
And y knowe hadde she hym of tyme yore
They fill in speche and furth more and more
Vnto that pʳpose drough Aurlelius
And when he saugh hys tyme he seide thus
¶ Madame qd he bigod that this worlde made
Yif that y wist it myght youre harte glade
Y wolde that day that youre Aruaragus
Wente oủer/ree the See that y Aurelius
Hadde went there neủer/ree y shulde haue comen ageyne
For well y wote my servise is in veyne
My guerdou is but brestyng of myn harte
Madame ruyth vppon my peynes smarte
For with on worde ye mowe me sle or save
Here at youre fete god wolde y were grave
I ne haue as nowe no leiser more to sey
Haue mcy swete or ye woll do me dey
Sheo begon to loke vppon Aurelius
Is this youre will qd she and seie ye thus
Never erst qd she wist y what ye ment
By thilke god that yave me soule and lif
Ne shall y neủer/ree be an vntrewe wif
In worde ne werke as ferre as y haue wit
I will be his to whom that y am knit
Take this for a fynall aunswere as of me
But aftur that in pley thus seide she
Aurelie qd she by hygh god a bove
Yit wolde y graunte you to be youre love
Sith y you see so pitously compleyne
Loke what day that evenlonge Bruteyne
Ye remeve all the rockes ston by stone
That they nene lette shippe ne bote to gone
I sey when ye haue made the Coste so clene
Of Rockis that there nys no stone sene
Then woll y love you best of eny man
Haue here my trouth in all that eủer/ree y can
¶ Is ther none other grace qd he
No by that lorde qd she that made me
Lette suche folies fro youre harte slide
For well y wote it shall neủer/ree betide
What deynte shulde aman haue in his lif
For to go loue a nother mannys wif
That hath hure body when so that hym likith
Aurelius ful sore ofte sighith
Wo was aurelius when that he this harde
And with a sorowfull harte thus aunswerde
Madame qd he this were an Impossible
Then mot y die on sodeyn deth possible
And with that worde he turned hym anon
Tho com hure other frendes many on
in the Aleys romed vp and doun
