And home they gon in Ioie and in solas
Save only wrecchid Aurelius allas
He to his hous is gon with sorowfull harte
He seith he may not fro his deth a starte
Hym semed that he felte his harte colde
Vp to heven his handes gan he holde
And on his knees bare he sette a doun
And in his ravyng seide his orisoun
For verrey wo oute of his wit he breide
He nyst what he spake but thus he seide
With pitous harte his playnte hath he begon
Vnto the goddes and first to the son
¶ He seide Appollo god and goủer/renoure
Of eủer/rey planet . herbe . tre . and floure
That evist aftʳ thy declynaciou
To eche of them his tyme and his seasou
As thyn herborowe chaungith lowe or hye
Lorde Phebus cast thy merciable ye
On wrecchid Aurelius which that am but lorn
Lo lorde my lady hath my deth sworn
Withoute gilte . but thy benignyte
Vppon myn dedly harte haue som pite
For well y wote lorde Phebus yif you lest
Ye mowe me helpe save my lady best
Nowe vouche saf that y may you devise
Hou that y may be holpen and in what wise
¶ Youre blisfull Sustir lucina . x luna the shene
That of the See is chief goddesse and Quene
Though Netunis haue deite in the See
Yet Emprise aboven hym is shee
Ye knowe well lorde that right at hure desire
Ys to be quyked and ligted of youre fire
For which she foloweth you full bisilye
Right so the See desireth naturallye
To folowen hure as she that is goddes
Bothe in the See and Rivers more and les
Wherfore lorde Phebus this is myn request
Do this miracle or do myn hert brest
That nowe nexte atte this opposiciou
Which in the signe shalbe of the liou
As praieth hure so grete aflood to brynge
That . v . fathom atte the lest it oủer/ree sprynge
The highest Rocke in Armorik Brutaygne
And lette this flode endure yeres tweyne
Then certis to my lady may y sey
Holdith youre heste the rockes ben awey
¶ Lorde Phebus do this Miracle for me
Pray hure to go no faster cours than ye
I said preith youre sustir that she go
No fastir Cours than ye thise yeres two
Then shall she be even at the fulle alway
And sprynge flood lastyng bothe nyght and day
And but she vouche saf in suche manere
To graunte me my soủer/reeigne lady dere
Praire hure synke Inne eủer/rey rocke a doun
Into there owne derke Regioun
Vnder the grounde there Pluto dwellith Inne
Or neủer/ree mo shall y my lady wynne
Thy Temple in Delphos woll y barefote seke
Lorde Phebus se the teres on my cheke
And of my peyne haue som compassioun
And with that worde in sorowe fill he doun
And longe tyme he lay furth in a Traunce
His brother which that knewe of his penaunce
Vp caught hym and to bed hath brought
Dispeired in this tʳment and in this thought
Lette y this wofull creature lie
Chese he for me whethir he woll live or die
¶ Aruaragus with hole and grete honoure
As he that was of Chivalrie the floure
Is comyn home and other worthy men
O blisfull arte thou nowe Dorigen
That hast thyn lusty husbonde in thyn armes
The fresshe knyght the worthy man of armes
That lovith the as his hertis lif
Nothyng lust hym to be ymaginatif
Yif Eny wight hadde spoken while he was oute
To hure of love he had of it no doute
He nought entendith to no suche matere
But daunceth Iustith makith hure good chere
And thus in Ioie and blis y lette them dwell
And of the seke Aurelius y woll you tell
In langoure and in tʳment furious
Two yere and more lay wrechid Aurelious
Or eny fote he myght on erthe gon
Comfort in this tyme had he non
Save of his Brother which that was a Clerke
He knewe of all this wo and all this werke
For to none other creature certeyne
Of this matere he durst no worde seyne
Vnder his brest he bare it more secre
Than eủer/ree did Pamphilus for Galathe
His brest was hole withoute for to sene
But in his harte was ay the arowe kene
And well ye knowe that of suche a sursauniure
In Surgerie is ꝑper/parilous to cure
But men myght touchen the arowe or com therby
His Brother wepte and wailled prively
Till at the last hym fell in remembraunce
That whiles he was at Orliaunce in Fraunce
As yonge clerkes that ben likerous
To reden artes that ben curious
Seken in eủer/rey halke and eủer/rey herne
Particuler sciences for to lerne
He hym remembred that vppon a day
At Orliaunce in studie . a boke he say
Of Magik naturell which his felawe
That was that tyme a Bacheler of lawe
All were he therto lerne a nother Crafte
Had prively hit vppon his deske lafte
Which boke spake moche of the oꝑper/paracions
Touchyng the . xxviij . Mancions
That longeth to the Mone and suche folie
As in oure daies is not worth a flie
For holy churche seith in oure bileve
Ne suffreth none illusiou vs to greve
And whan this boke was in remembraunce
A non for ioy his harte gan to daunce
And to hym self he seide prively
My brother shalbe warisshed hastely
For y am siker that ther ben sciences
By which men maken diủer/res apparances
Suche as thise subtell Tregetours pley
For ofte at festes haue y harde sey
That Tregetours within an halle large
Haue made com in a water and a barge
And in the halle rowen vp and doun
Somtyme hath semed to me a wode lyoun
And somtyme floures spryngyng as in a mede
Somtyme avyne and grapes white and rede
Somtyme a Castell of lyme and stone
And whan hym liked voide it anone
Thus semed it to eủer/rey mans sight
Nowe then conclude y thus yif that y myght
Atte Orliaunce som olde felawe fynde
That had this . Mone . mancions in mynde
Or other Magik naturell a bove
He shulde well make my brother haue his love
For with apparence a Clerke may make
To mannys sight that all the rockes blake
Of Brutaigne were y voide eủer/reychone
And Shippes by the brynke comen and gone
And in suche forme endure a day or two
Than were my brother warisshid of his wo
Than moste she nedes holden hure by hest
Or elles he shall shame hure at the lest
What shulde y make a lenger tale then this
Vnto his Brothers bed he comyn is
And suche comfort he yaf hym for to gon
To Orliaunce that he vp stertith anon
And on his wey forward then is he fare
In hope for to ben lassed of his care
When they were com almost to the Cite
But yif it were a . ijᵒ . forlonge or thre
A yonge Clerke romyng by hym self they mette
Which that in laten thriftly they hym grette
And aftur that he seide a wonder thyng
I knowe qd he the cause of youre commyng
And er they ferther eny fote wente
He tolde them all that was in ther entente
This Brutou Clerke hym asked of felawes
The which that he had knowen in olde dawes
And he aunswerd hym that they dede were
For which he wepte full ofte many a tere
Doun of his hors Aurelius light anon
And with this Magicien furth is he gon
his house and made them well at ease
lacked no vitaille that myght them please
ell arraied house as there was one
lius in his lif sawe neủer/ree none d
He shewed hym or he wente to sopere
Forestes Parkis full of wilde dere
There sawe he hartis with ther hornes highe
The grettist that was eủer/ree seyne with ye
He sawe of them an . C . slayne with houndes
And som with arowes blede of bittir woundes
He sawe whan voidid were the wilde dere
Thise Faukeners vppon a feire Rivere
That with ther haukis haue haue the heyrou slayne
Tho sawe he knyghtis Iusten in a playne
And aftur . this he did hym suche pleasaunce
That he hym shewid his lady on a daunce
On which hym self he daunced as hym thought
And whan this Master . had this Magik wrought
Sawe it was tyme . he clapte his hondes two
And fare well oure revell was aa go
And remeved they neủer/ree oute of the house
While they sawe this sight mervelouse
But in his stody there as his bokes be
There sitten still . but no wight but they thre
To hym this Master called his Squyere
And seide hym thus . is redy oure sopere
Almost an houre it is I vndertake
Sith y you bade oure sopere for to make
Whan that this worthy man went with me
Into my stody there as my bokis be
Sir qd he this Squyer . whan it likith yowe
It is all redy though ye will right nowe
Go we then soupe qd he for the best
Thise amarous folke som tyme mote haue there rest
Atte afture soupere fell they in tretee
What som shulde this Masters guerdou bee
To remeven all the rokkes of Brutayne
And eke from Gerounde to the Mounte of Sayne
He made it straunge and swore so god hym save
Lesse then a . Mˢ . li . he wolde not haue
Ne gladly for that som he wolde not gon
Aurelius with blisfull harte anon
Aunsuerd hym .fy . on a . Mˢ. li . pounde
This wide worlde which that men seen rounde
I will it yeve . yif that y were lorde of it
This bargeyne is full dryve for we ben knit
Ye shalbe paide truly by my trouth
But lokith nowe for no negligence or slouth
Ye tarie vs here . no lenger then to morowe
Nay qd this Clerke haue here my feith to borowe
To bed is gon Aurelius whan hym lest
And well nygh all the nyght he had his rest
What for his laboure and his hope of blisse
His wofull harte of penaunce had a lisse
Vppon the morowe whan it was day
To Brutaigne toke they the right way
Aurelius and this Magicien biside
And ben descendid there they wolde a bide
The colde frosty seasou of Decembre
And this was as thise bokes me remembre
Phebus wax olde and hued like latou
That in his hote declinaciou
Shone as the burned goold with streames bright
But nowe in Capricorne adoun he light
Where as he shone full pale y dar well seyne
The bittre Frostes . with the slete of Reyne
Destroied hath the grene in eủer/rey yerde
¶ Ianus sittith by the fire with double berde left
And drynkith of his bugle horn the wyne
Biforn hym standith brawne of the tusked swyne
And nowell crieth eủer/rey lusty man
Aurelius in all that eủer/ree he can
Doth to this Master chere and reủer/reence
And praith hym to don his diligence
To bryngen hym oute of his paynes smarte
Or with a swerde he wolde slitte his harte
This subtill Clerke suche rueth had of this man
That nyght and day he sped that he can
To waiten a tyme of his conclusiou
This is to seyne to make Illusiou
By suche apparence or Iogelerie
I can no t̉er/remes of Astrologie
That she and eủer/rey wight shulde wene and seie
That of Brutaigne the Rokkes were aweie
Or elles they were sonkyn vnder grounde
So atte the last he hath his tyme founde
To make his Iape and his wrechidnesse
Of suche a suꝑper/parsticies . cursednesse
His tables Tolletanes furth he brought
Full well correctid ne there lacke nought
Ne there his Collecte ne his expans yeres
Ne his Rotes . ne his other geres
As ben his scentres and his argumentes
And his ꝓproporcions conuenientes
And his Equaciouns in eủer/rey thynge
And by his Eight spere in his werkynge
He knewe full well . hou ferre Alnath was shoue
Fro the hed of directe . fix . Aries a boue
Full subtilly he calked all this
Whan he had founden his first manciou
Accordyng to his oꝑper/paraciou
And knewe the arisyng of the mone well
And in which face and t̉er/reme eủer/rey dell
And knewe all so his other observaunces
And suche Illusions and suche myschaunces
As hethen folke vseden in thilke daies
For which no lengre makith . he delaies
But thrugh his Magik for a weke or tweie
It semed that all the Rokkes were a weie
Aurelius which that dispaired is
Whether he shall haue his lif or fare amis
A waitith nyght and day on this miracle
And whan he knewe that there was none obstacle
That voided were thise Rokkes eủer/reychone
Than to this Mastirs fete he fell anone
And seide y wofull wrecchid Aurelius
Thanke you lorde . and lady myn venus
That me haue holpen from my cares colde
And to the Temple his wey furth hath he holde
Where as he knewe he shulde his lady se
And whan he sawe his tyme anon right he
With dredfull herte and with humble chere
Salue hath his soủer/reaigne lady dere
My rightfull lady qd this wofull man
Whom y moste drede and love as best can
And lothest were of al thy this worlde displease
Nere it that y for you haue suche disease
That y moste dien here at youre fete here anon
Nought will y tell hou me is wo begon
But certis either moste y dien or pleyn
Ye sle me giltles for verray peyn
But of my dethe . though that ye haue no rueth
A visith you er that ye breke youre trueth
Repentith you . for thilke god a bove
Or ye me slene . by cause that y you love
For Madame well ye wote what ye haue hight
Not that y chalenge eny thyng of right
Of you my soủer/reaigne lady but youre grace
But in a gardyn yonder at suche a place
Ye wote hit well . what ye behight me
And in myn honde youre trueth plight ye
To love me best god wote ye seide so
All be that y vnworthy am therto
Madame y speke it for the honoure of yowe
More than to save myn hartis lif right nowe
I haue don so . as ye commaunded me
And yif ye vouchesaf ye may go se
Doith as you lest . haue y youre byhest in mynde
For quik or dede . right there ye shall me fynde
In you lieth all to do me live or deye
But well y wote the Rokkes ben a weye
He taketh his leve and she astonyed stode
In all hure face nas a droppe of blode
She wende neủer/ree to haue com in suche a Trappe
Allas qd she . that eủer/ree this shulde happe
For wende y neủer/ree by possibilite
That suche a Monstre or merveill myght be
Hit is ageyns the processe of nature
And home she goith a sorowfull creature
For verrey fere vnneth may she go
She wepith wailith all a day or two
And swouneth that it is ruyth was for to se
But why it was to no wight tolde she
For oute of toun was gon Aruaragus
But to hure selfself she spake and seide thus
In hure complaynte as ye shall aftur here
Allas qd she on the fortune y pleyne
That vnware wrappid hast me in thy chayne
For which to scape wote y no socoure
Save only deth or elles dishonoure
One of thise . . ijᵒ . behovith me to chese
But natheles . that haue y levir to lese
My lif then of my body to haue a shame
Or knowe my selfen fals . or lese my name
And with my deth y may be quitte y wisse
Hath ther not many a noble wif or thisse
And many a Maide slayne hure self a llasse
Rather then with hure body do trespasse
Yis certayne . lo thise stories beren witnesse
Whan . xxx . Tirauntes full of cursednesse
Had slayne Phidou in Athenes at the feste
They commaundid his doughtirs for to areste
And bryngen them bifore hem in dispite
All naked to fulfill there foule delite
And in there Fadre blode they made them daunce
Vppon the pavement god yeve them myschaunce
For whiche thise wofull Maydenes full of drede
Rather then they wolde lese there Maydenhede
They prively byn stert in to a welle
And dreynte them self as the boke doth vs telle
They of Messene let enquere and seke
Of Lacedomie . l .ᵗⁱ ladyes eke
On which they wolde done there lecherie
But was there none of all the compenie
But she nas slayne . and with a good entente
Chese rather for to die then assente
To ben oppressed of there Maidenhede
Why shulde y than to die ben in drede
Lo eke the Tiraunte . Aristoclides
That loued a Maiden . hight Stymphalides
Whan that hure fadre slayn was vppon a nyght
Vnto Dianes Temple goith she ryght
And hente the ymage in hure hondes two
From which ymage wolde she neủer/ree go
No wight ne myght hure hondes of hit a race
Till she was slayne right in the same place
Nowe sith þatþat Maidenes had suche dispite
To ben defouled with mannys foule delite
Well ought yy a wif than rather my selfen sle
Than to be defouled as it thynkith me
What shall y seyne . of hastribaldus wif
That at Cartage . bireft hur self hure lif
For whan she sawe . that Romayns wan the Toun
She toke hure Children all and skipte a doun
Into the fire and chese rather to die
Then eny Romayne did hure vilanie
Hath not lucresse y slayne hure self allas
At Rome whan sheshe oppressed was
Of Tarquyn for hure thought it was a shame
To liven when she had loste hure name
The . vijnᵉ . Maidenes of Melesie also
Haue slayne them self for verrey drede and wo
Rather then folke of Sawle shulde them oppresse
Moo then a . Mˢ . stories as y gesse
Coude y nowe telle as touchyng this matere
Whan habradate was sleyne his wif so dere
Hure selfen slowe and lete hure blode to glide
In habradates woundes depe and wide
And seide my body at the leste way
There shall no wight defoulen yif y may
What shulde y mo ensaumples here of seyne
Sith that so many haue them self sleyne
Well rather than they wolde defouled be
I woll conclude that it is best for me
To slee my self then be defouled thus
I will be true vnto Aruaragus
Or rather sle my self in som manere
As emocius Doughtʳ dere
Bi cause that she nolde defouled be
O ; Cedasus . it is full grete pite
To rede hou thy Doughtirs dieden allas
That slowen them self for suche mane cas
A grete pite was it . or well more
The Theban Maiden . that for Nichanore
Hure silfen slough right for suche mane wo
Another Theban Maiden did right so
For onon of Macedoyne had hure oppressed
She with hure deth hure Maidenhode redressed
What shall y seyne of Nicerates wif
That for suche caas bireft hure self hure lif
How true eke was . Alcebiades
His love that rather for to dien chese
Then for to suffre his body vnburied be
Lo which a wf was Alcest qd she
What seith Omere of good Penolope
All Grece knoweth of hure chastite
Parde of laodomia is writen thus
That whan atte Troie was slayne Prothesaleus
No lenger wolde she live aftur his day
The same of noble Porcia tell y may
Withouten Brutus coude she not live
To whom she had all hole hure harte yeve
¶ The Parfit wifhode of Arthemesye
Honoured is thrugh all the Barbarye
O . Theuta Quene thy wifly chastite
To all wifis may a Mirroure be
Thus pleyned Dorigen a day or tweie
Purposyng eủer/ree that she shulde deie
But natheles vppon the . iijde . nyght
Hom come Aruaragus this worthy knyg
And axed hure why that she wepte so sore
And she gan wepen eủer/ree lenger the more
Allas qd she that eủer/ree was I born
Thus haue y seide qd she . thus haue y sworn
And tolde hym all . as ye haue harde bifore
It nedith not to reherce it nowe no more
This husbonde with glad chere and frendly wise
Aunsuerd and seide as y shall you devise
Is ther ought elles Dorigen but this
Nay nay . qd she god helpe me so as wis
This is to moche . and it were goddis wille
Ye wif qd he lat slepen that is stille
It may be well paraventure yet to day
Ye shall youre trouth holden by my fay
For god so wisly haue mercye vppon me
I had wellwell levir y stekid for to be
For verraye love which that y to you haue
But yif ye shulde youre trouth kepe and saue
Trouth is the highest thyng that man may kepe
But with that worde he brast oute anon to wepe
And seide y you for bede vppon peyne of dethe
That neủer/ree while you lastith the brethe
