Me to distourbe of Cristes holy werke
And after that . then tell y furth my tales
Of Popes Bulles and of Cardynales
Of Pattriarkes and of Bisshoppes y shewe
And in latyn speke y wordes fewe
To saffrou with my predicaciou
In eủer/rey village and in eủer/rey Toun
This is my tyme and shall and eủer/ree was
Radix omni malorum est cupiditas
Then shewe y furth my longe cristall stones
I crammed full of cloutes and of bones
Reliquys ben they as wenen they echone
Then haue y in a latou a shuldre bone
Which that was of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men y say take of my wordes kepe
Yif that this bone be wasshed in eny welle
Yif Cowe or calf or Oxe or shepe swelle
That eny worme hath ete or worme y stonge
Take water of that welle and wasshe his tonge
And it shalbe hole anon and furthermore
Of pokkes and of scabbes and eủer/rey sore
Shall eủer/rey shepe be hole that of this well
Drynkith a draught take kepe eke what y tell
Yif that the good man that the bestes oweth
Woll eủer/rey weke er that the cokke hym croweth
Fastyng drynken of this well a draught
As thilke holy Iewe oure eldre taught
His bestes and his store shall multiplie
And sir also it helith Ielousie
For though aman be falle in Ielous rage
Lette maken with this water his potage
And neủer/ree shall he more his mystrust
Though he the sothe of hure defaute wust
All had she taken prestis . ij . or thre
Here is a mytayne eke that ye may se
He that his honde wolle put in this mytayne
He shall haue multipliyng of his grayne
When he hath sowen be it whete or Otes
So that he offre pens or ells grotes
Good men and wommen othyng warne y you
Yif eny wight be in this Cherche nowe
That haue don synne so orrible that he
Dar not for shame of it y shriven be
Or eny womman be she yonge or olde
That hath made hure husbonde Cokolde
Suche folke shulde haue no powere ne grace
To offren to my Reliquys in this place
And who so fyndeth hym oute of suche blame
They woll com vppe and offre on goddis name
And y assoyle them by the auctorite
Which that by Bull y graunted was to me
¶ By this Gaude haue y won yere by yere
An . C . marke sith y was Pardonere
And stode like a Clerke in my pulpet
And when the lewede people doun is y set
Y preche so as ye haue harde byfore
And tell an . C . fals Iapes more
Then peyne y me to streche furth my nek
And Est and west vppon the peple y bek
As doth a doth a dove sittyng on a berne
Myn hondes and my tonge gon so yerne
That it is Ioy to se my bisynesse
Of Avarice and of suche cursednesse
Is as my prechyng for to make them fre
To yeve there pens and namely vn to me
For myn entente is not but for to wynne
And nothyng for correcciou of synne
I rek neủer/ree when that they ben buried
Though there soules gone a blakberied
For certis many a predicaciou
Comth ofte of Evill entenciou
Som for plesaunce of folke and flaterie
To ben avaunced by ypocrisie
And som for veyne glorie and som for hate
For whan y dar none other weyes debate
Than woll y stynge hym with my tonge smerte
In prechyng so that he shall not asterte
To ben defamed falsly yif that he
Haue trespased to my bretheren or to me
For though y tell not his ꝓpropre name
Men shull well knowe that is the same
By signys and by other circumstaunces
Thus quyte y folke that don vs displeasaunces
Thus spete y oute my venym vnder hue
Of holynesse to semyn holy and true
But shortly myn entente y will devise
I preche of nothyng but of Covetise
Therfore my tyme is yet and eủer/ree was
Radix omn malorum est cupiditas
Thus can y preche ageyne that same vice
Which that y vse and that is avarice
But though that my self be gilty in that synne
Yet can y make other folke to wynne
From avarice and sone them repente
But that is not myn pryncipall entente
I preche nothyng but for covetise
Of this matere it ought y nough suffise
Then tell y them ensaumples many on
Of olde stories longe tyme agon
For lewde peple loven tales olde
Suche thynge conne they wele reporte and holde
What trowe ye whiles that y may preche
And wynne golde and silvir for y teche
That y woll live in poủer/rete wilfully
Nay Nay y thought it neủer/ree truly
For y will preche and teche in sondry londes
I will not do no laboure with myn hondes
Ne make basketis and live therby
By cause y will not begge ydelly
I woll none of the Aposteles counterfete
I woll haue money wolle chese and whete
All were it yeven of the porest page
Or of the porest widowe in a village
All though hure children shulde sterve for famyne
Nay y woll drynke the licoure of the wyne
And haue a Ioly wenche in eủer/rey toun
But herkeneth lordynges in conclusioun
Youre likyng is that y shall tell a tale
Nowe haue y dronke a draught of corny ale
By god y hope y shall you tell a thynge
That shall by reasou ben at youre likynge
For though my self be a full vicious man
A morall tale yet y you tell can
Which y am wonte to preche forto wynne
Nowe holde youre pees my tale y will be gynne

Here endith the prologge of the Pardonere
And begynneth his tale rỏer/re
In Flaundres whilom was a companie
Of yonge folke that haunteden folie
As Riot . hasard . Stewes and Tavernes
Where as with harpes . lutes and Giternes
They daunce . and pleyen at dice bothe day and nyght
And ete also and dronken oủer/ree there myght
Thrugh which they don they don the devill sacrifise
Within that devils temple in cursed wise
By suꝑper/parfluite abhominable
There othes ben so grete and so dampnable
That it is grisly for to here them swere
Oure blessed lordes body they to tere
Them thought that Iewes rente hym not y nough
And eche of them of other synne lough
And right anon then comen Tumbilsteres
Fetise and smale and yonge frutesteres
Syngers with harpes Bawdes and waferers
Which ben the verrey devils officers
To kendell and blowe the fire of lecherie
That is annexed vnto glotenye
The holy writte take y to my witnesse
That lecherie is in wyne and dronkynnesse
Lo hou that drunken . loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doughturs . ij . vnwytyngly
So dronke he was he nyst what he wrought
Herode who so will the stories sought
Whan he of wyne was replete at his fest
Right at his owne table he yaf his hest
To sle Iohn the Baptiste full giltlesse
Senec seith a good worde doutelesse
He seith he can no difference fynde
Betwixt aman that is oute of his mynde
And aman which that is drunkelewe
But that wodenesse y fallen in a shrewe
Percevereth lenger then doth dronkynesse
O . gloteny full of cursednesse
O . cause furst of oure confusiou
O . originall of oure dampnaciou
Till crist had bought vs with his blode a geyne
Lo hou dere shortly forto seyne
A bought was that ilke cursed vilanye
Corrupte was all this worlde for glotenye
Adam oure fader and his wif also
Fro paradise to laboure and to wo
Were driven for that vice it is no drede
For while that Adam fasted as y rede
He was in paradise and whan that he
Ete of the frute defended on the tre
Anon he was oute cast to wo and peyne
O . glotonye on the ought wele vs compleyne
O . wist a man . hou maladies
Folowen of exces and of glotonyes
He wolde bene the more mesurable
Of his diet sittyng atte his table
Allas the shorte throte . the tender mouth
Makith that Est and West North and South
In Erthe in Eyre in Water man to swynke
To gete a glotou deynte mete and drynke
Of this matere o poule well canst thou trete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe eke vnto mete
Shall god destroien bothe as Paule seith
Allas a foule thyng is it by my feith
To sey this worde and foweler is the de
What man so drynkith oft the white and the rede
That of his throte he makith his prive
Thrugh thilke cursed suꝑper/parfluyte
The Apostle seith wepyng full pitously
There walken many of which you tolde haue y
I sey it wepyng nowe with pitous voice
There ben enemyes of cristes croice
Of which the ende is deth wombe is there god
O . wombe . o . Belly . o . stynkyng Cod
Fulfilled of Donge and of corrupciou
At eyther ende of the foule is the soun
Hou grete laboure and cost is the to fynde
Thise Cokes hou they stampe streyne or grynde
To turnen substaunce in to accident
To fulfill all thy likorous talent
Oute of the harde bones Cnocke they
The marie for they cast not a wey
That may go thrugh thrugh the golet softe and sote
Of Spicerie . of leef . of . barke . of Rote
Shall ben his sauce y made by delite
To makyn hym haue a newer appetite
But certis he that hauntith suche delites
Is dede while that he liveth in tho vices
A lecherous thyng is wyne and dronkenesse
Is full of strivyng and of wrechidnesse
O . dronkyn man disfigured is thy face
Soure is thy breth . foule arte thou to embrace
And thrugh thy dronkyn nose semeth thy soun
As though thou seidest ay Sampsou Sampsoun
And yet god wote Sampsou neủer/ree dranke wyne
Thou fallest as it were a steked swyne
Thy tonge is lost and all thyn honest vre
For dronkennesse is verrey Sepulture
Of mannys witte and his discreciou
In whom that drynke hath domynaciou
He can none counsaille kepe it is no drede
Nowe kepe you from white and fro rede
And namly from the white wyne of lepe
That is to sell in Fisshestrete or in Chepe
This wyne of Spayne crepith subtilly
And other wynes growyng fast by
Of which there riseth such fumosite
That whan a man hath dronke draughtes thre
And weneth that he be at home in Chepe
He is in Spayne right at the toun of lepe
Not at the Rochell ne at Burdeux toun
And then woll he sey Sampsou Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordynges . onthyng y you pray
That all the soủer/reaigne actes dar y sey
Of victories thrugh the olde testament
Thrugh verrey god that is omipotent
Were done in Abstynence and in preire
Lokith the bible ye mowe it lere
Loke Attila the grete Conqueroure
Died in his slepe with shame and dishonoure
Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capytayne shulde live in sobernesse
And oủer/ree all this a visith you right wele
That was commaunded vnto lamuele
Not Samuell but lamuell sey y
Redith the Bible and fynde it expresly
Of wyne yevyng to them that haue yistise
No more of this for it may well suffise
And nowe that y haue spoken of Glotonye
Nowe will y you defenden hasardrie
Hasarde is verrey moder of lesynges
And of disceite and of cursed for swerynges
Blasfemyg of Criste manslaughtre and wast also
Of Catell and of tyme and furthermo
It is reprove and contrarie of honoure
For to bene holde a Comyn hasardoure
And eủer/ree the higher he is of estate
The more is he holden desolate
Yif that a Prynce vsith hasardrie
In all goủer/renaunce and policie
He is as by comune oppyniou
I holde the lasse in reputaciou
¶ Stilbone that was a wise Embassatoure
Was sent to Corynthe in full grete honoure
Fro lacedomye to maken there alliaunce
And whan he come hym hapned parchaunce
That all the grettist that were of the lande
Pleyng at the hasardrie he them fande
For which as sone . as it myght be
He yode hym home ageyne to his Contre
And seide there woll y not lese my name
Ne y will not take on me so grete defame
You for to allie vnto none hasardours
Sendith other wise Embassatours
For by my trouth me were leủer/ree die
Than y you shulde to hasardours alie
For ye that ben so glorious in honoures
Shull not allye you with hasardoures
And by my will ne as by my trete
This wise philosophre thus seide he
¶ Loke eke that the kynge Demetryus
The kynge of Parocke as the boke seith vs
Sent hym a peire of dice of golde in scorn
For he had vsed hasardrie there biforn
For which he hilde his glorie and his renoun
At no value or reputaciou
Lordes mowe fynde other mane pley
Honest y nough for to drive the day awey
¶ Nowe will y speke of othes fals and grete
A worde or . ij . as olde bokes trete
Grete sweryng is a thynge abhominable
And fals sweryng is yit more reprevable
The high god for bade sweryng at all
Witnes on Mathewe but in speciall
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieremye
Thou shalte swere sothe thyn othes and not lye
And swere in dome . and eke in rightwisnesse
But ydell sweryng is cursidnesse
Biholde and se that in the first table
Of high goddis hestis honourable
Hou that the . ij . heste of hym is this
Take not myn name in Idel or a mis
Lo rather he forbedith suche sweryng
Then homycide or many a cursed thyng
I sey that as by ordre thus it standith
This knowen they that his hestes vnderstandith
Hou that the . ij . heste of god is that
And further oủer/ree y woll the tell all plat
That veiaunce shall nat parten from his hous
That of his othes is to outeragious
By goddis precious hart and by his nayles
And by the blod of Criste that is in hayles
Vij . is my chaunce . and thyn synke and treie
By goddis Armes yif thou falsly pleye
This dagger shall thrugh thyn harte go
This fruyt commyth of the bicchid bones two
For sweryng . Ire . Falsnesse . homicide
Nowe for the love of Crist that for vs dide
Lette youre othes bothe grete and smale
¶ But nowe sires woll y tell furth my tale
Thise Riotours . iij . of which I telle
Longe erst or pryme ronge of eny belle
Were set them in Taverne to drynke
And as they sate they hard a belle clynke
Biforn a Cors . was caried to his grave
That one of them gan callen his knave
Go bet qd and axe redily
What Cors is that . that passeth furth by
And loke that you reporte his name wele
Sir qd this boy it nedith neủer/ree a dele
Hit was me tolde or ye came here . ij . houres
He was parde an olde felawe of youres
And sodeynly he was slayne to nyght
For dronke as he sate vppon his benche vpryght
There com a prive thef men clepen deth
That in this Contre all the peple sleth
And with his spere he smote his hart a two
And wente his wey withoute wordes mo
He hathe a Ml . slayne this pestilence
And master er ye com in his presence
Me thynkith that it were necessarie
For to be ware of suche an adủer/resarie
Beth redy for to mete hym eủer/remore
Thus taught me my dame y sey no more
By seynt Marie seide this Tavernere
The childe seith soth for he hath sleyne this yere
Hens oủer/ree a Mile with in a grete village
Both man and womman Childe . hyne and page
I trowe his habitaciou there
To to be avised grete wisedom it were
Er that he did aman . a dishonoure
Ya goddis armes qd this Riotoure
Is it suche perell . with hym to mete
I shall hym seke by wey or by strete
I make avowe to goddes digne bones
Herkneth felawes we ben . iij all ones
Lette eche of vs holde vp his honde till other
And eche of vs bicom others brother
And we will slene this fals traitoure deth
He shall be slayne . he that so many sleth
By goddis dignite or it be nyght
To gedres haue thise . iij . here plyght
To live and to die eche of them for other
As though he were his owne bore brother
And vp they sterte all dronken in this rage
And furth they gone towardis that village
Of which the Tavernere had spoke biforn
And many a grisly othe then haue they sworn
And cristes blessed body they to rent
Deth shall be dede yif that they nowe hym hent
And whan they haue gon not fully half a myle
Right as they wolde haue treden oủer/ree a style
An olde man and a pore with them mette
This olde man full mekely them grette
And seide thus . nowe lordes god you se
The proudest of thise Riotours . thre
Aunswerde ageyne what Carle with sory grace
Why arte thou all for wrapped save thy face
Why livest thou longe in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus for y ne can not fynde
A man though y walked in to the ynde
Neither in Cite ne in no village
That wolde chaunge his youth for myn age
And therfore mot y haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as it is goddis wille
Ne deth allas wolde not haue my lif
Thus walke y like a recheles Caitif
And on the grounde which is myn moders gate
I cnocke with my staf bothe erly and late
A sey leve modere lette me Inne
Lo hou y wanysshe blode and skinne
Allas whan shall my bones be at rest
Modere with you wolde y chaunge my chest
That in my Chambre longe tyme hath be
Ya . for an heere cloute to wrap in me
But yet to me she woll not do that grace
For which full pale and welked is my face
But siris to you it is no curtesie
To speken to an olde man vilanie
But he trespased in worde or els in dede
In holy writ ye mowe youre self wele rede
Ageyns an olde man hore vppon his hede
Ye shulde arise . wherfore y you rede
Ne doth vn to an olde man non harme nowe
No more than ye wolde a man did to yowe
In age yif that ye so longe a bide
And god be with you where ye go or ride
I mot go thider as y haue to go
Nay olde Churle by god thou shalte not so
Seide this other hasardoure a non
Thou partist not so lightly by seynte Iohn
Thou spake right nowe of thilke Traitoure dethe
That in this Contre all oure frendes slethe
Haue here my trouth thou arte his . spie
Tell where he is or thou shalte it abie
By god and by the holy sacrament
For sothely thou arte on of there assent
To slen vs yonge folke thou fals thef
Nowe siris qd he yif that ye be so lef
To fynde deth turne vp this croked wey
For in that grove y lefte hym by my fey
Vnder a tre and there he wolde a bide
Not for youre bost he woll hym not hide
Se ye that Oke right there ye shall hym fynde
God save you that bought a geyne mankynde
And you amende thus seide this olde man
And eủer/reyche of thise Roiatours ran
Till they come to that tree and there they founde
Of floreyns fyne of golde y coyned rounde
Well nygh an . viij . busshels as them thought
No lenger then aftur deth they sought
But eche of them so glad was of the sight
For that the florens ben so feire and bright
That doun they sete them by the precious horde
The worst of them spake the first worde
Brithren qd he take kepe what y sey
My wit is grete though that y borde and pley
This tresoure hath fortune vnto vs yeven
In myrth and Iolite oure lif to leven
And lightly as it commyth so will we spende
Ey goddis precious dignite who wende
To day that we shulde haue so feire agrace
But myght this golde be caried from this place
Home to myn hous or els vnto yours
For woll ye wote that all this golde is ours
Then were we in high felicite
But truly by day it nell not be
Men wolde seyne that we were thefes stronge
And for oure owne tresoure don vs honge
Wherfore y rede that Cut amonge vs alle
We drawe and let se where the Cut woll falle
And he that hath the Cut with harte blithe
Shall renne to toun and that full swithe
And brynge vs brede and wyne full prively
And . ij . of vs shall kepe full subtelly
This tresoure wele . and yif he will not tarie
When it is nyght we will this tresoure carie
By on assent where as vs thynkith best
That on of them the Cut brought in his fest
And bade them drawe and loke where it will fall
And it fele on the yongest of them all
And furth toward the toun he went anon
And also sone as that he was gon
That on them spake thus vnto that other
Thou knowest well thou arte my sworn brother
Thy profite will y the tell anon
Thou wotist well that oure felawe is gon
And here is golde and that full grete plente
That shulde be departed amonge vs thre
But nathelesse yif y can shape it so
That it departed were amonge vs two
Had not y done a frendes turne to the
That other aunswerde y not hou that may be
He wote that all the golde is with vs twey
What shulde ye don what shulde we to hym sey
Shall it be counsaile seide the first shrewe
And y shall tell it in wordes fewe
What we shall do and brynge it well aboute
I graunte qd that other oute of doute
That by my trouthe y will the not bewrey
Nowe qd the first thou wotist well we be twey
And . ij . of vs shall strenger be than on
Loke when he is set . that right a non
Arise as thou woldest with hym pley
And y shall rive hym thrugh the sides twey
While that thou stroglest with hym as in game
And with thy daggar loke thou do the same
And then all this golde departed be
My dere frende bitwene me and the
Then mowe we bothe oure lustes all fulfill
And pley at the dice right at oure owne will
And thus accorded ben thise shrewis tweyne
To sle the . iijde . as ye haue harde me seyne
This yongest which that wente to the toun
Full ofte in herte he rolleth vp and doun
The beaute of thise floreyns newe and bright
O . lorde qd he yif so were that y might
Haue all this tresoure to my self a lone
There is no man that livith vnder the Trone
Of god that shulde live so merye as y
And at the last the fende oure enemy
Put in his thought that he shulde poysen beie
With which he myght slene his felawes tweie
For why the fende founde hym in suche livyng
That he had leve hym to sorowe bryng
For this was vttirly his full entente
To slene them bothe and neủer/ree to repente
And furth he goth no lenger wolde he tarie
In to the Toun vnto the Poticarie
And praide hym that he hym wolde selle
Som poysou that he myght his Rattis quelle
And eke there was a Poll Catte in his hawe
That as he seide his Capons had he slawe
And feyne he wolde wreke hym yif he myght
On vermen that destroied hym by nyght
The Poticarie aunswerde and thou shalte haue
A thyng that also was my god saue
In all this worlde there nys no creature
That ete or drunke hath of this conftiture
Not but the mountaunce of a Corn of whete
That he ne shall his lif anon for lete
That sterve he shall and that in lesse while
Then thou wolte go a pase not but a mile
The poysou is so stronge and violente
This cursed man hath in his hande y hente
This poysou in a box and sith he ran
In to the nexte strete vnto a man
And borowed hym large botelles thre
And in the . ij . his poisou put he
The . iijde . kepte clene for his drynke
For all the nyght he shope hym for to swynke
In careyng of the golde oute of that place
And when this Riotoure with sory grace
Had filled with wyne his grete botelle thre
To his felawes ageyne repaireth he
What nedith it to sermon of hit more
For right as they haue cast his deth bifore
Right so they haue slayne hym and a non
And whan that this was don thus spake that on
Nowe let vs sit and drynke and make vs merye
And afturwarde we wolen his body burye
And with that worde it happid hym parcas
To take the Botell there the poisen in was
And dranke and his felawe drynke also
For which anon they storven bothe two
But certis y suppose that Auysen
Wrote neủer/ree in no Canou ne in Nofen
Mo wondre signes of enpoisynynge
Then had thise wrecchis . ij . er ther endynge
Thus ended ben thise homycides two
And eke the fals Empoisenere also
O . cursed synne of all cursidnesse
O . traitours homicide . o . wickidnesse
O . Gloteni9 . luxirie . and hasardrie
Thou blasfemoure of Crist with vilanie
And othes grete of ysage and of pride
Allas mankynde hou may it betide
That to thy creature which that the wrought
And with his precious hert blode the bought
Thou arte so fals and so vnkynde allas
¶ Nowe good men god for yeve you youre trespas
And ware you from the synne of Avarice
Myn holy pardou may you all warise
So that ye offre nobles or sterlyngis
Or ellis silvir broches spones or ryngis
Bowith you hede vnder this holy Bulle
Com vp ye wivis and offre of youre wulle
Youre names y entre here in my rolle anon
In to the blisse of heven shull ye gon
I you assoile by my high powere
Ye that will offre as clene and eke as clere
As ye were born and lo Sires thus y preche
And Ihu Criste that is oure soules leche
So graunte you his pardou to resceive
For that is best y woll you not disceive
¶ But sires a worde for gate y in my tale
I haue Relik and Pardou in my male
As feire as eny man in Englonde
Which were me yeven by the Popes honde
Yif eny of you wolle of devociou
Offren and haue myn absoluciou
Com furth anon and kneleth here a doun
And mekely resceiveth ye my pardoun
Or elles take pardou as ye wende
All newe and fresshe at eủer/rey Townes ende
So that ye offre alway newe and newe
Nobles or pens which that ben good and trewe
It is an honoure to eủer/reyche that is here
That ye mowe haue a sufficiaunte Pardonere
To assoile you in Contre as ye ride
For aventures which that may betide
Paraventure there now on . falle on or two
Doun of his hors and breke his necke a two
Loke which a suerte it is to you alle
That y am in youre felawship y falle
That may assoile you bothe more and lasse
Whan that the soule shall from the body passe
I rede that oure Oste shall be gynne
For he moste envoluped is in synne
Com furth sire Oste and offre first anon
And ye shull kisse the Reliquys eủer/reychon
Yea for a grote vnbocle anon thy purs
Nay nay qd he then haue y cristes curs
Lat be qd he it shall not be theche
Thou woldest make me kisse thyn olde breche
And swere it were a Relike of a seynte
Though it were with thy foundemente peynte
But by that Croys which that seynt Elone fonde
I wolde y had thy Colions in myn honde
In stede of Reliquys or of sentuarie
Lette cut them and y wolde the helpe in carie
They shull be shrined in an hogges torde
This Pardonere aunswerd not a worde
So wroth he was no worde ne wolde he sey
Nowe qd oure Oste y wolde no lenger pley
With the ne with none other angry man
But right a non the worthy knyght bi gan
Whan tha saugh all the peple lough
No more of this for it is right y nough
Sire pardonere he seide be glad and merye of chere
And ye sire Oste that be to me so dere
I pray you that ye kisse the Pardonere
And Pardonere y pray the drawe nere
And as we deden let vs laugh and pley
Anon they kisten and riden furth there wey
Here endeth the Pardoners tale
And bygennyth the Shipmans tale
A Marchaunte which whilom dwelled at seynte Denyse
That riche was for which men helde hym wise
A wif he had of excellent beaute
And compenable and revelous was she
Which is a thyng that causeth more dispence
Than worth is all the chere and reủer/reence
That men them done at festes and at daunces
Suche salutacions and countenaunces
Passeth as doth a shadowe vppon the walle
But wo ys hym that paie mot for alle
The sely husbonde algate he mot pay
He mot vs clothe and he mot vs array
All for his owne worship richely
In which array we dauncen Iolily
And yif that he note may paraventure
Or elles list not suche dispence endure
But thynkith it is wasted and y lost .
Than mot a nother paie for oure cost
Or lene vs golde and that is ꝑper/parilous
This noble Marchaunte hilde a worthy hous
For which he had all day grete repaire
For his largesse and for his wif was so faire
That wondre is . but herkeneth to my tale
Amonge all thise Gestis grete and smale
There was a Monke a faire man and a bolde
I trowe a . xxxᵗⁱ . wynter he was olde
That eủer/rey Mone . was drawyng to that place
This yonge Monke that was so faire of face
Acqueynted was with the good man
Sith that there first knowlege began
That in his hous as famulier was he
As it is possible eny frende to be
And for as moche as this good man
And eke this Monke of which that y began
Were bothe y born in on village
The Monke hym claymeth as for Cosynage
And he ageyns seith not ones nay
But was as glad thereof as foule of the day
For to his harte it was agrete pleasaunce
Thus byn they kyn with eterne aliaunce
For eche of them gan other for to assuere
Of brotherhed while that there lif may dure
Fre was daun Iohn and namely of dispence
As in that hous and full of diligence
To don plesaunce and also grete costage
He not for gete to yeven to the leste page
In all that hous . but aftur there degre
He yave the lorde and sethen all his meyne
Whan that he com som mane honest thyng
For which they were as glad of his commyng
As foule is fayne whan that the son vprisith
No more of this as nowe for it suffisith
But so bifele this Marchaunte on a day
Shope hym to make redy his array
Towarde the toun of Brugges for to fare
To bien there aporciou of ware
For which he hath to Parise sente anon
A Messangere and praide that Daun Iohn
That he shulde com to seynte Denyse and pley
With hym and his wif a day or twey
Ere he to Brugges went in all wise
This noble Monke of which y you devise
Hath of his Abbot as hym left licence
By cause he was a man of grete prudence
And eke an officer oute for to ride
To seene there Graunges and there bernes wide
And vnto seynte Denyse he cometh anon
Who was so welcom as my lorde Daun Iohn
Oure dere Cosyn full of curtessie
With hym brought he a Gubbe of Malmessie
And eke another full of fyne vernage
And volatill as ay was his vsage
And thus let them ete and drynke and pley
This Marchaunte and this Monke a day or twey
The thride day this Marchaunte vp arisith
And on his nedes sadly hym avisith
And vp into his countyng hous goth he
To rekon with hym self well may be
Of thilke yere hou that it with hym stood
And hou that he dispended had his good
And yif that he encresed were or non
His bokis and his bagges many on
He leith biforn hym on his countyng borde
Full riche was his tresoure and his horde
Full fast for which his Countoure dore he shette
And eke he nolde that no man shulde hym lette
Of his accountes for the mene tyme
And thus he sate till it was passed pryme
Daun Iohn was risen on the morowe also
And in the garden walked to and fro
And hath his thynges seyde full curteisly
This good wif came walkyng prively
Into the gardeyne there he walkid softe
And hym salueth as she hath don ofte
A Maide Childe come in hure companye
Which as she lust she may goủer/rene and gye
For yet vnder the yerde was the Maide
O . dere Cosyn myn Daun Iohn she saide
What eileth you so rathe for to arise
Nece qd he it ought y nowe suffise
V . houres for to slepe vppon a nyght
But it were for an olde appalled wyght
As ben thise wedded men that lien and dare
As in a forme sittith a wery hare
Were all for straught with houndes grete and smale
But dere nece why be ye so pale
I trowe certis that oure good man
Hath you labored sith the nyght began
That you were nede to resten hastely
And with that worde he lough full merely
And of his owne thought he wax all rede
This feire wif gan for to shake hure hede
And seide thus ye god wote all qd she
Dar y not tell . hou that it stondith with me
Wherfore y thynke oute of this londe to wende
Or elles of my self to make an ende
So full y am of drede and eke of care
This Monke bigan vppon this wif to stare
And seide Ales my Nece god for bede
That ye for eny sorowe or drede
For do youre self but tell me youre gref
Paraventure y may in youre mischef
Counsaill or helpe and therfore telleth me
All your a noye for it shall be secre
For on my Porteis y make an othe
That neủer/ree in my lif . for leef ne lothe
Ne shall y of no counsaille you be wrey
The same ageyne qd she to you y sey
By god and by this Porteis y swere
Though men me wolde all in peces tere
Ne shall y neủer/ree for to gon to helle
Bewrey aworde of thyng that ye me telle
Not for no Cosynage ne alliaunce
But verrely for loue and affiaunce
Thus ben they sworn and hereuppon they kist
And eche of them tolde other what them list
Cosyn qd she yif that y had a space
As y haue none and namly in this place
Then wolde y tell a legende of my lif
What I haue suffred sith y was a wif
With myn husbonde . all be he youre Cosyn
Nay qd this Monke bi god and seynt Martyn
He is no more Cosyn vnto me
Then is the leef that hangeth on the tre
I clepe hym so by seynte Denyse of Fraunce
To haue the more cause of acqueyntaunce
Of you which y haue loued specially
Aboven all wymmen sikirly
This swere y you on my profession
Telleth youre gref lest that he com doun
And hastith you and goth a wey anon
My dere love qd she . o . Myn Daun Iohn
Full lef were me this counsaille for to hide
But oute it mot y may no lenger abide
Myn husbonde is to me the worst man
That eủer/ree was seth the worlde bigan
But sith that y am wif it sittith not me
To tellen no wight of oure privete
Neither abed ne in none other place
God shilde y shulde it telle of his grace
A wif ne shall not seyn of hure husbonde
But all honoure as y can vnderstonde
Save vnto you thus moche y tellen shall
As helpe me god he is not worth at all
In no degre the value of a flie
But yet me grevith moste his nygardie
And well ye wote that wymmen naturally
Desiren thynges . vj . as well as y
They wolden that there husbondes shulde be
Hardy and wise and riche and therto fre
And buxum vnto his wif and fresshe a bedde
But by that ilke lorde that for vs bledde
For his honoure my self for to array
A sonday nexte y mot nedes pay
An . C . Frankes or elles y am lorn
Yet were me leủer/ree that y were vnborn
Then me were don a sclaundre or vilanye
And yif myn husbonde eke myght it a spye
I were but lost and therfore y you pray
Lende me this som orelles mot y day
Daun y sey . lende me this . C . Frankis
Pardie y will not faile you my thankis
Yif that you lest to don that y you say
For at a certeyne day y woll you pay
And do vnto you what plesaunse and servise
That y may don right as you lest devise
And but y do god take on me veniaunce
As foule as eủer/ree had Genelou of Fraunce
This gentill Monke aunswerd in this manere
Nowe truly myn owne lady dere
I haue qd he on you so grete arouth
That y you swere and plight you my trouth
That whan you husbonde is in to Flaundres fare
I will delyủer/ree you oute of this care
For y woll brynge you an . C . Frankis
And with that worde he caught hure by the flankis
And hure embraceth harde and kist hure ofte
Goth nowe youre wey qd he all still and softe
And let vs dyne as sone as that ye may
And by my Chilundre it is prime of the day
Goth nowe and beth as true as y shall be
Nowe elles god for bede sire qd she
And furth she goith as Ioly as a pie
And bade the Cokes that they shulde them hie
So that men myght dyne and that a non
Vp to hure husbonde is this wif y gon
And cnokkith at his Countre dore boldly
Who is there qd he . Petir it am y
Qd she what sire hou longe will ye fast
How longe tyme will ye reken and cast
Youre sommes and youre bokes and youre thynges
The devill haue parte of all suche rekenynges
Ye haue y nough of goddis sonde
Com doun to day and let youre bagges stonde
Ne be ye not a shamed that Daun Iohn
Shall fastyng all this day elenge gon
What let vs here a Masse and go we dyne
Wyf qd this man litle canst thou devyne
The curious bisynesse that we haue
For of vs Chapmen also god me saue
And by that lorde that clepid is seynte Ive
Scarsly a monge . xij . x . shull thrive
Continually lastyng to oure age
We mowe well make chere and good visage
And drive furth the worlde as it may be
And kepen oure estate in privite
Till we be dede or elles that we pleie
A pilgrimage or go oute of the weie
And therfore haue y grete necessite
Oppon this quyente worlde to a vise me
For eủer/ree mote we stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune in oure Chapmanhede
To Flaundres wolle y go to morowe at day
And com ageyne as sone as eủer/ree y may
For which my dere wif y the beseke
As be to eủer/rey wight buxum and meke
And for to kepe oure good . be curious
And honestly goủer/rene wele oure hous
Thou hast y nowgh in eủer/rey mane wise
That to a thrifty housholde may suffise
Thou lackist none array no no vitaille
Of silvir in thy purs shalte thou not faile
And with that worde his Countoure dore he shet
And doun he goth no lenger wolde he let
But hastily a masse ther was seide
And spedely the table were leide
And to the dynere fast they them spedde
And richely this Monke this Chapman fedde
And aftur dyner Daun Iohn sobirly
This Chapman toke a parte and prively
He seide hym thus . Cosyn it stondith so
That wele y see to Bruggis wolde ye go
God and seynte Austyn spede you and gide
I pray you Cosyn wisely that ye ride
Governeth you also of youre diete
A temꝑper/parally and namely in this hete
Betwixte vs . ijᵒ . nedith no straunge fare
Fare well Cosyn god shelde you from care
And yif that eny thyng by day or nyght
Yif it be in my powere and my myght
That ye will commaunde in eny wise
It shall be don right as ye will devise
But on thyng or ye gon yif it may be
I will preie you forto lende me
An . C . Frankis for a weke or . tweie
For certeyn bestes that y moste beie
To store with a place that is oures
God helpe me so y wolde it were youres
I shall not faile suerly at my day
Not for a . Mˢ . frankes a myle way
But let this thyng be secret y you prey
For yet to nyght thise bestes mot y bey
And fare nowe well myn Cosyn dere
Graunte mcy of youre cost and of youre chere
This noble Marchaunte hertily anon
Answerde and seide . o . Cosyn myn Daun Iohn
Nowe sikirly this is a small request
My golde is yours whan that it you lest
And notonly my gold but my chaffare
Take what you like god shilde that ye spare
But o thyng is this ye knowe it well y nough
Of Chapmen that there money is there plough
We mowne crease while we haue a name
But goldles for to be it is no game
Pay it ageyne whan it lieth in youre ease
Aftur my might full fayne wolde y you please
Thise . C . Frankes he set furth anon
And prively he toke them to Daun Iohn
No wight in all this worlde wist of this lone
Savyng this Marchaunte and Daun Iohn allone
They speke and drynke and rome a while or tweye
Till that Daun Iohn rideth to his Abbey
The morowe came and furth this Marchaunte rideth
To Flaundreswarde his prentise wel hym rideth
Till he come to Brugges merily
Nowe goth this Marchaunte fast and besily
Aboute his nedis and bieth and creaunceth
He nother pleieth at the dice ne daunceth
But as a Marchaunte shortly for to tell
He ledith his lif and there y let hym dwell
The Sonday nexte that the Marchaunt was gon
To seynte Denyse y cōmmyn is Daun Iohn
With croune and berde all fresshe and newe shave
In all the hous there nas so litle a knave
Ne no wight elles that he nas full fayne
That my lorde Daun Iohn was com agayne
And shortly to the poynte right for to don
fair wif accorded with Daun Iohn
t for thise . C . Frankes he shulde all nyght
hire in his armes bolte vpryght
And this accorde parformed was in dede
In myrth all night a besie lif they lede
Till is was day that Daun Iohn went his weie
And bade the meyne fare well and haue good day
For none of them ne no wight in the toun
Hath of Daun Iohn right no suspecioun
And forth he rydeth home to his Abbeie
Or whither hym lest no more of hym y seie
This Marchaunt whan ended was the feire
To seynte Denyse he gan forto repeire
And with his wif he makith feste and chere
And telleth hure that chaffre is so dere
That nedis moste he make a chefisaunce
For he was bounde in a reconisaunce
To paie . xx . Mˢ . scutes anon
For which this Marchaunte is to Parise gon
To borowe of certayne frendes that he hadde
A certayne of Frankes and som with hym he ladde
And whan that he was comyn into the toun
For grete cherite and grete affeccioun
Vnto Daun Iohn he goth first hym to pleie
Not for to axe or borowe of hym moneie
But for to weie and sene of his welfare
And for to sellen hym of his chaffare
As frendes don when they ben met in fere
Daun Iohn hym makith feste and mery chere
And he hym tolde agayne full specially
Hou he had well y bought and graciously
Thanked be god all hole his Marchauntedise
Save that he moste in all mane wise
Maken a chevisaunce . as for his best
And then he shulde ben in Ioy and rest
Daun Iohn aunswerde certis y am fayne
That ye in hele are cōmmyn home a gayne
And yif that y were riche as haue y blisse
Of . xx . Mˢ . Frankis shulde ye not mysse
For ye so kyndely this other day
Lente me golde and as y can or may
I thanke you bigod and by seynte Iame
But natheles y toke it vnto oure Dame
Youre wif at home the same golde ageyne
Vppon youre benche she wote it well certeyne
By certeyne tokenes that y can you telle
Nowe by youre leve y may no lenger dwelle
Oure Abbot woll oute of this toun anon
And in his compenye nedes mot y gon
Grete well oure dame myn owne nece swete
And fare well dere Cosyn till we mete
¶ This Marchaunte that was full ware and wise
Creaunced hath . and paide eke in Parise
To certayne lumbardes redy in there honde
The som of golde and gate of them his bonde
And home he goth merye as a popyniay
For wele he knewe he stode in suche array
That nedis moste he wynne in that viage
A . Mˢ . Frankes a bove all his costage
His wif full redy met hym at the gate
As she was wonte of olde vsage algate
And all that nyght in myrth
and clerely oute of dette
¶ Whan it was day this Marchaunte gan embrace
His wif all newe and kist hure face
And vp he goth and makith it full tough
No more qd she by god ye haue y nough
And wantounly with hym she pleied
Till at the last the Marchaunte seied
Bigod qd he y am a litle wrothe
With you my wif all though it be me lothe
And wote ye why by god as that y gesse
That ye haue made a mane straungenesse
Bitwixt me and my Cosyn Daun Iohn
Ye shulde haue warned me or y had gon
That he you . an . C . Frankes had paide
By redy token and hilde hym well a paide
For that y to hym spake of chevisaunce
Me semed so as by his countenaunce
But nathelesse bi god oure heven kynge
I thought to axe of hym no thynge
I pray the wif ne do no more soo
Tell me alwey or that y fro the go
Yif eny Dettours haue in myn absence
Y paide the lette thrugh thyn necligence
I myght hym axe a thynge that he had paide
This wif was not aferde ne afraide
But boldly she seide and that anon
Mary y defie the fals Monke Daun Iohn
I kepe not of his tokenes neủer/ree a dele
He toke me certeyn golde that y knowe wele
What evill thedom on this Monkes snoute
For god it wote y wende withouten doute
That he had yevyn it me . by cause of yowe
To don therewith myn honoure and my prowe
For Cosynage and eke for beale chere
That he hath had full ofte tyme here
But sith y se y stonde in this dishoynt
I wolle then aunswere shortly to the poynt
Ye haue mo slacker dettours then am y
For y will paie you well and redely
Fro day to day and yif so be y faile
I am youre wif score it vppon my taile
And y shall paie as sone as eủer/ree y may
For By my trouth y haue on myn array
And not on wast by stowede eủer/rey dele
And for y haue bistowed it so wele
For youre honoure for goddis sake y sey
And be not wroth but let vs laugh and pley
Ye shall my Ioly body haue to wedde
By god y will not paie you but on bedde
For geve it me myn owne spouse dere
Turne hitherward and maketh bettir chere
This Marchaunte sawe there was no remedie
And for to chide it were but folie
Sith that the thynge may not amended be
Nowe wif he seide and y for yeven it the
But by thy lif be no more so large
Kepe bet thy good this yeven y the in charge
Thus endeth my tale and god vs sende
Tailyng y nowe vnto oure lyves ende

l.hi: And begynneth the prologge of the Prioresse

div.l: Well seide by corpus dıı̄uns qd oure hoste
Nowe longe mot you saile by the Coste
Sire Ientill Master . Ientill Marynere
God yeve the Monke a M . last quadere
A ha felawes beth ware of suche a Iape
The Monke put in the mans hode an ape
And in his wifis eke by seynt Austyn
Draweth no Monkes mo in to youre yn
But nowe passe and let vs loke aboute
Who shall nowe tell first of all this route
Another tale . with that worde he seide
As curteisly as it had ben a Meide
My lady Prioresse by youre leve
So that y wist y shulde you not greve
I wolde demen that ye tellen shulde
A tale nexte yif so were that ye wolde
Nowe wolde vouchsaf . my lady dere
Gladly qd she and seide as ye shall here
¶ Here begynneth the Prioresse hure prologge
¶ Domine dominus / noster quiᵃ ⁊andr̉er/re
O . lorde . oure lorde thy name so mervelous
Is in this large worlde y spred qd she
For nat only thy laude precious
Performed is by men of dignyte
Not by the mouth o Children thy bounte
Parformed is for on the brest soukyng
Somtyme shewen there thyn heryng
¶ Wherfore . and as y best can or may
Of the and of the white lilye floure
Which that the bare and is a maide alway
To telle a storie y will do my laboure
Not that y may encresen hure honoure
For she hure self is honoure and the Rote
Of bountie nexte hure sonne and soules bote
¶ O. moder maide . o . maide moder fre
O . busshe vnbrent brennyng in Moyses sight
Tha ravisshedest doun from the dethe
Thrugh thyn humblenesse the gost that in the light
Of whos vertue when he thyn hart light
Conceived was with faders sapience
Helpe me to tell it in thy reủer/reence
¶ Lady thy bountie thy magnificence
Thy vertue and thy grete humylite
There may no tonge expresse in no science
For som tyme lady or that men pray to the
Thou goist biforn of thy benignyte
And getest vs the light of thy preire
To giden vs vnto thy son so dere
¶ My connyng is so weike . o . blisfull Quene
For to declare thy grete worthynesse
That y ne may the weight oute sustene
But as a Childe of . xij . Monthe olde or lesse
That y can vnnethe eny worde expresse
Right so fare y and therfore y you preye
Gidith my songe that y shall of you seye

l.hi: Here begynneth the Prioresse hure tale

div.l: There was in Assye a grete
Amonges cristen folke a Iewrie
Susteyned by a lorde of that Contre
The foule vsure and lucre of velaine
Hatefull to Criste and to his companie
And thrugh thise secrete men myght ride or wende
For it was fre and open at either ende
¶ A litle scole of Cristen folke there stode
Doun at the forthere ende in which there were
Children an hepe y com of cristen blode
That lerned in that scole there by yere
Suche mane doctryne as men vsed there
This is to seyne to syngen and rede
As smale Children don in there childehede
¶ Amonges thise . Children . was a widowes sonne
A litle clergiou . vij . yere of age
That day by day to scole was his wonne
And eke also where as he sawe the ymage
Of Cristis modere had he . iijᵉ . vsage
And hym was taught to knele a doun and sey
His Aue marie as he gothe by the wey
¶ Thus hath the wydowe hure litle son taught
Oure blisfull lady criste Modere dere
To worship ay and forgete it naught
For sely childe woll alway sone lere
But ay whan y remembre on this matere
Seynte Nicholas standith eủer/ree in my psence
For he so yonge to Crist did reủer/reence
¶ This litle Childe . his litle boke lernyng
As he sate in the scole at his primere
Alma Redemptoris hard he syng
As Children there Antyphonere
And as he durst he drewe hym nere and nere
And herkened ay the wordes and the note
Till he the first vers coude all by rote
¶ Not wist he what this laten was to say
For he so yonge and tendre was of age
But on a day his felawe gan he praye
To expounen hym this songe in his langage
Or tell hym why this songe was in vsage
This preide he hym to construe and declare
Full often tyme vppon his knees bare
¶ His felawe which that eldre was then he
Aunswerd hym thus this songe y haue harde seye
Was made of oure blisfull ladie fre
Hure to salue and eke hure for to prey
To ben oure helpe and socoure when we dey
I can no more expoune in this matere
I lerne songe y can but small gramere
¶ And is this songe made in reủer/reence
Of cristes Modere seide this Innocent
Nowe certis y will do my diligence
To conne it all er Cristmas be went
Though that y for my primere shalbe shent
And shall be beten thrise in an houre
I will it conne . oure lady forto honoure
¶ His felawe taught hym homward prvely
Fro day to day till he coude it by rote
And there he songe it full wele and boldly
Fro worde accordyng with the note
Twise a day it passed thrugh his throte
To scolewarde and homward whan he went
On cristes Moder set was his entent
¶ As y haue seide thrughoute the Iewrie
This litle Childe as he come to and fro
Full merely wolde he syng and crie
O . Alma Redemptoris . eủer/remo
The swetnesse his hart procede so
O . cristes Modere that to hure to prey
He cannot stynte of syngyng by the wey
¶ Oure first fo . the Serpent Sathanas
That hath in Iewes hart his waspis nest
Vp swall and seide . o . Ebriak peple allas
Is this to you a thyng that is honest
That suche a boy shall walken as hym lest
In youre dispite and syng of suche sentence
Which is a geyns oure lawes reủer/reence
¶ Fro thens furth the Iewys haue conspired
This Innocent oute of this worlde to chace
An homicide . therto haue they hired
That in an aley had a prive place
And as the Childe gan forby forto pace
This cursed Iewe hym hente and hilde hym fast
And kut his throte and in a pitte hym cast
¶ I seie that in a wardrope they hym threwe
Where as this Iewys purgen there entaile
O . cursed folke of herodes all newe
What may youre evill entent you availe
Morther will oute certayne it woll not faile
And namly there as the honoure of god shall sprede
The blode oute crieth on oure cursed dede
Sir Martyr sondede to virginite
Now maist thou syngen and folowe eủer/ree in one
The white lambe celestiall qd she
Of which the grete Evangelist seynt Iohne
In Pathmos wrote . which seith that they that gone
Biforn this lambe and synge a songe all newe
That neủer/ree flesshely wymmen they ne knewe
¶ This poure widowe a waiteth all that nyght
Aftur hure litle Childe but he come nought
For which as sone as it was daie light
With face pale of drede and besie thought
She hath at the scole and elleswhere hym sought
Till fynally . she gan so ferre espye
That he last seen was in the Iewerie
¶ With Modres pite in hure hart enclosed
She goith as she were oute of hure mynde
To eủer/rey place where she hath supposed
By liklyhode hure litle Childe to fynde
And eủer/ree on cristes Moder meke and kynde
She cried and at the last thus she wrought
Amonges the cursed Iewes she hym sought
¶ She fraineth and she preith pitously
To eủer/rey Iewe that dulled in that place
To tell hure yif hure childe wente oughte forby
They seiden nay but Ihu of his grace
Yaf in hure thought within a litle space
That in that place aftur hure son she cried
Where as he was casten in a pitte bisid
¶ O . grete . god . that ꝑper/parformest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentes lo here thy myght
This gemme of Chastite . this Emeraude
And eke of Martirdom the ruby bryght
There he with throte y corvyn lay vp right
He Alma Redemptoris gan to synge
So loude that all the place gan to rynge
¶ The cristen folke that thrugh the strete went
In comen for to wonder on this thyng
And hastly . they for the Prouowst sent
He come anon withouten tareyng
And herieth Criste . that is of heven kyng
And eke his Modere honoure of mankynde
And aftur that the Iewys lette he bynde
¶ This Childe with pitous lamentaciou
Vp taken was syngyng his songe alwey
And with the honoure of grete processiou
They caried hym vnto the nexte Abbey
His Moder swounyng by his bere ley
Vnneth myght the people that was there
This newe Rachell bryngen from his bere
¶ With turnement and with shamefull deth echone
This Prououst doth thise Iewys forto starve
That of this Morther wist and that anon
He nolde no suche cursednesse obsarve
Ivell shall he haue . that evill will deserve
Therfore with wilde hors he did them drawe
And aftur that he honged them by the lawe
¶ Vppon this bere ay lieth this Innocent
Biforn the highest auter while the masse last
And aftur that the Abbot with his Convent
Hym sped them to biry hym full fast
And whan they holywater on hym cast
Yit spake this Childe whan spreynt was the holiwater
And songe . O . Alma Redemptoris Mater
¶ This Abbot which that was an holy man
As monkes ben . or elles oughten to be
This yonge childe to coniure he began
And seide o . dere childe y halsen the
In vertue of the holy Trinite
Tell me what is thy cause for to syng
Sith that thy throte is cutte to my semyng
¶ My throte is cutte vnto my necke bone
Seide this childe and as by wey of kynde
I shulde haue died ya longe tyme a gon
But Ihu Crist as ye in bokes fynde
Well that his glorie . last and be in mynde
And for the worship of his Moder dere
Yet may y synge . o . Alma . loude and clere
¶ This well of mercye cristes Modere swete
I loved alway as aftur my connyng
And whan that y shulde my lif for lete
To me she come and bade me for to syng
This Anteme verreily in my deyng
As ye haue harde . and whan that y ~ had songe
Me thought she leide a greyne vppon my tonge
¶ Wherfore y syng and syng y mot certayne
In honoure of this blisfull Maiden fre
Till fro my tonge of taken is the grayne
And aftur that this seide she to me
My litle Childe nowe will y feche the
When that the grayne is from thy tonge y take
Be not a gast y woll the not forsake
¶ This holy Monke this Abbot hym mene y
His tonge oute caught and toke a waie the grayne
And he yave vp the gost full softly
And whan this Abbot had this wonder sayne
His salte teres trikled doun as rayne
And gruf he fele all plat vppon the grounde
And still he lay as he had layne y bounde
¶ The Convent eke lay on the pavement
Wepyng and heryng cristes Moder dere
And aftur that they rise and furth be went
And toke awey this Martir from his bere
And in a Tombe of Marbill stones clere
Enclosen they this litle body swete
There he is nowe god leve vs for to mete
¶ O . thou yonge hue of lyncoln slayne also
With cursed Iewys as it is notable
For it is but a litle while ago
Pray eke for vs we synfull folke vnstable
That of his mercie god so merciable
On vs his grete mercye multiplie
For the reủer/reence of his Moder Marie
¶ Here endeth the Priores / hure tale . >

l.hi:
And
begynneth the prologge of Chauncer of Sir Thopas

div.l: Whan seyd was this myracle eủer/rey man
As sobre was that wonder was to se
Till that oure hoste iapen bigan
And then at Erst he loked vppon me
And seide thus what man arte thou qd he
Thou lokist as thou woldest fynde an hare
For eủer/ree vppon the grounde y se the stare
¶ A proche nere and loke vp merily
Nowe ware you sires and let this man haue place
He in the wast is shape aswell a y
This were a popet in an arme to embrace
For eny womman small and faire of face
He semeth elvisshe by his countenaunce
For vnto no wight doth he daliaunce
¶ Sey thou nowe somwhat syn other folke haue seide
Tell vs a tale of myrth and that anon
Hoost qd y . ne beth not evill a peide
For other tale certis can y non
But of ryme y lerned longe agon
Yet that is good qd he that will we here
Som deynte thyng me thynkyth by his chere

l.hi: Here begynneth the tale of Sir Thopas

div.l: Listneth lordes in good entent
And y will tell verament
Of myrth and of solace
All of a kynge . was faire and gent
In Batell and in turnement
His name was Sir Thopace
Y born he was in fer Contre
In Flaundres all by yonde the se
At Poperyng in the place
His fader was a man full fre
And lorde he was of that Contre
As it was goddis grace
Sir Thopas waxed a doughty swayne
White was his face a payne de mayne
His lippis as rede as Rose
His rode was like scarlet in greyne
And y you tell in good certeyne
He had a semly nose
His here his berde was like saffron
That to his Girdell raught a doun
His shone of Corduane
Of Bruges were his hosen broun
His Robe was of Siklatoun
That cost many a Iane
He coude hunte at wilde dere
And ride an haukyng by Rivere
With Grey Goshauke on honde
Therto he was a good Archiere
Of wrastlyng was there none his pere
There eny Ram shulde stande
Full many a Maide bright in boure
They morne for his Paramoure
When them were bet to slepe
But he was chast and no lechoure
And swete as is the brambill floure
That bereth the rede hepe
¶ And so it bifele vppon a day
For soth as y you tell may
Sir Thopas wolde oute ride
He worthed vppon his stede gray
And in his honde a launce gay
A longe swerde by his side
He pricketh thrugh a faire forest
Therin was many a wilde best
Ya both bucke and hare
And as he prickith North and Est
I tell it you . hym had al mest
Bitide a sory care
There spryngen herbes grete and smale
The licourise and the setuale
And many a Clowe Gelofre
And Notmygge to put in ale
Whether it be moiste or stale
Or for to ley in Cofre
The briddes syngen it is no nay
The Sparowhauke and the Popyiay
That ioy it was to here
The Thrustle Cocke made eke hure lay
The wode dove vppon a Spray
She songe full loude and clere
Syr Thopas fell in love longynge
All when he herde the threstell synge
And prycked as he were wode
His faire stede in his prickyng
So swatte that men myght hym wryng
His sides were all blod
Sir Thopas eke so wery was
For pricking on the softe gras
So fers was his corage
That doun he laide hym in that place
To make his stede som solace
And yaf hym good forage
O . seynte Marie benedicite
What eileth this loue at ne
To bende me so sore
Me dremed all this nyght parde
An Elf Quene shulde my lemman be
And slepe vnder my gore
An Elf Quene will y loue y wis
For in this worlde no womman is
Worthy to be my make
in Toun
All other wymmen y forsake
And to an Elfe Quene y me take
By dale and eke by doun
In to his sadill he clombe anon
And pricked oủer/ree stile and ston
An Elfe Quene for espie
Till he so longe hath riden and gon
That he fonde in a prive won
The Contre of Fairye
so wilde
For in that Contre was there non
That to hym durst ride or gon
Neither wif ne childe
Till that there come a grete geaunte
His name was sir Olifaunte
A perilous man of dede
He seide childe by Termegaunte
But yif thou pricke oute of myn haunte
Anon y sle thy stede
with mace
Here is the Quene of Feyrie
With harpe Pipe and Symphonie
Dwellyng in this place
The Childe seide as mot y the
To morowe will y mete the
When y haue myn Armoure
And ye y hope parmafay
That thou shalte with this launcegay
A bien it full sone
thy mawe
I shall perce yif y may
Or it be fully Pryme of day
For here thou shalte be slawe
Sir Thopas drowe a backe full fast
This Giaunt at hym stones cast
Oute of fell staf slyng
But faire ecaped childe Thopas
And all it was thrugh goddis gras
And thrugh his faire beryng
¶ Yet lestneth lordes to my tale
Miriere then the nyghtyngale
I will you roun
Hou Sir Thopas with sides smale
Prickyng oủer/ree hill and dale
Ys come a geyne to toun
His mery men commaunded he
To make hym bothe game and gle
For nedis mot he fight
With a Giaunte with hedes thre
For Paramoure and Iolite
Of one that shone full bright
Do com he seide my Mynstralles
And Iestours fo to tell tales
Anon in myn Armyng
Of Romayns that ben Roials
Of Popis and of Cardynals
And eke of loue longyng
They fet hym furth swete wynes
And Meth eke and Malmesynes
And roiall spicerie
Of Gynger that was so fyne
And licourice and eke Comyne
With sugre that is trie
He did nexte his white . lire
A Cloth of laike fyne and clire
A breche and eke a shert
And nexte his sherte a ketou
And oủer/ree that an haberiou
For persyng of his hert
And oủer/ree that a fyne hauberke
Was all y wrought of Iewes werke
Full stronge it was of plate
And oủer/ree that his cote Armoure
As white as is a lilye floure
In which he wolde debate
His shelde was all of golde so rede
There in was a bores hede
A Charbocle bi his side
Hou that the Giaunte shal be dede
And there he swore on ale and brede
Betide what betide
His Iambeus were of quyrbuly
His swerde sheth of Ivery
His helme of latou bright
His sadell was of rowell bone
His bridell as the sonne Shone
Or as the mone light
His spere was of fyne Sipres
That bodeth werre and nothyng pes
The hed full sharpe y grounde
His stede was of Apull Gray
He goth on aumble in the way
Full softly and rounde
in lounde
Lo lordynges myn here is a fitte
Yif ye will eny more of hitte
To tell it y woll fonde
¶ Nowe holde youre mouth pur charite
Bothe knyght and lady fre
And herkeneth to my spell
Of Bataill and of Chyvalrie
And of ladies loue drurie
A non y will you tell
Men speken of Romaunces of prise
Of horn childe and of ypotise
Of Bevise and of Sir Gy
And of Sir libeus and plein damoure
But Sir Thopas he bereth the floure
Of roiall Chyualry
His good stede all he be strode
And furth vppon his way he rode
As sparke oute of bronde
Vppon his crest he bare a Toure
And therin stiked alylie floure
God shelde his Cors from shonde
And for he was a knyght Auntrous
He nolde slepen in no hous
His bright helme was his wongerere
And by hym baith his destrere
Of herbes fyne and good
Hym self dranke water of the welle
As did the knyght sir Percyuelle
So worthy vnder wede
till on a day
¶ No more of this for goddis dignyte
Quod oure hoste for thou makist me
So wery of thy verrey lewednesse
That also wisly god my soule blesse
Myn eeres akyn of thy daffy speche
Nowe suche a Ryme the devill y beteche
This may be well Ryme dogerelle qd he
Why so qd y . why will ye let me
More of my tale . then a nother man
Syn that it is the best ryme y can
By god qd he . for pleynly at a worde
Thy draffy Ryme is not worth a torde
Thou doist not elles but dispendest tyme
Syre at on worde thou shalte no lenger ryme
Lette se whether thou canst tell ought in gest
Or elles in prose somwhat at the lest
In whiche ther be som myrth or som doctryne
Gladly qd y by goddis swete pyne
I woll you tell a litle thynge in prose
That ought to like you as y suppose
Or elles certyane ye be to daungerouse
It is a Morall tale vertuouse
All be it som tyme tolde in sondry wise
Of sondry folke y shall you devise
And thus ye wote that eủer/rey Evangelist
That telleth vs the peyne of Ihu Crist
Ne seith althyng as his felawe doth
But natheles his sentence is all soth
And all accorden as in there sentence
All be there in there tellyng difference
For som of them sey more and som sey lesse
Whan they his pitoıı̄uns passion expresse
I mene of Marke Mathewe Luke . and Iohn
But doutles there sentence is all on
Therfore lordynges all y you beseche
Yif you thynke y varie as in my speche
As thus though that y tell somwhat more
Of proverbes then ye haue harde bifore
Comprehended in this litle tretise here
To enforce with the effecte of my matere
And though y not the same wordes seie
As ye haue harde yet to you all y preie
Blameth me not . for as in my contence
Shull ye fynde nowhere difference
For the sentence of this tretyse lite
Aftur the whiche this mery tale y write
And therfore herkeneth what that y shall sey
And let me tellen all me tale y prey

l.hi: Here endith Chauncers tale of Sir Thopas .

ab.hi: And begynneth the tale of Melibeus .

div.ab:
A yonge man called Melibeus myghty and riche . bigate vppon his wif that
called was Prudence . a Doughtre which that called was Sophie

vppon a day
bifele that he for his sporte . is wente in to the feldes hym to pley .

his wif ~
and eke his Doughtre . hath he lefte within his hous . of which the dores we-
ren fast y shette .

iij . of his olde foos haue it a spied . And setten laddresse is
to the walles of his hous . and by wyndowes ben entred .

and beton his wif
and wounded his Doughtʳ . with . v . mortall woundes . in . v . sondry places .

This is to seyne . in hure fete . in hure hondes . in hure eeres . in hure nose and .
in hure mouthe . and leften hure for dede . And wenten a way .

Whan Meli-
beus returned was to his hous . and sawe all this mychief . he like a madman
and rendyng his clothes gan to wepe and crie .

Prudens his wif as ferfurth
as she durst bi sought hym of his wepyng for to stynte .

But not for that . he
gan to wepen and crie eủer/ree lenger the more .

This noble wif Prudens remem-
bred hure vppon the sentence of . Ovide in his boke . that clepid is the remedie
of love . where as he seith .

he is a fole that distourbeth the Moder to wepe
in the deth of hure childe . till she haue wepte hir fille . as for a certayne tyme .

And then shall man don his diligence . with amyable wordes hure to comforte
And praire hure of hure wepyng to stynte .

For which reason . this noble wif
Prudens suffred hure husbonde for to wepe and crie . as for a certayne space .

And whan she sawe hure tyme she seide vnto hym in this wise . Allas my lorde
qd she . why make ye youre self for to be like afole .

Forsothe it ꝑper/parteyneth not to
a wiseman to make suche sorowe ;

youre Doughtir with the grace of god shalle
warisshe and scape .

and all were it so that she right nowe were dede . ye ne ought
not . as for youre self to destroie .

Senec . seith the wise man shall not take to
grete discomforte for the deth of his Children .

But certis he shulde suffren it in
pacience . as well as he a bideth of his owne ꝓpropre parsone .

This Melibeus ~
aunswerde a non and saide . what man qd he shulde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so grete a cause for to wepe .

Ihıı̄un Criste oure lorde hym self wepte
for the deth of Lazarus his frende .

Prudence aunswerd well y wote attempre
wepyng is no thynge defended to hym that sorowfull is . A monge folke in
sorowe . but it is rather graunted hym to wepe .

The A Postle Paule vnto
the Romayns writeth . Man shall reioyce with hym that makith Ioye . and
wepe with hym suche folke as wepen .

But though attempre wepyng be
graunted . outeragious wepyng certis is defended .

Mesure of wepyng i
shulde be considred . aftur the lore that techeth vs Senec .

When that thy frende
ys dede qd he lette not thyn yeen to moyst be of teres ne to moche drie . all though
the teres com to thyn yeen . let them not falle .

And whan thou hast forgoten
thy frende . do diligence to gete ageyne another frende . And this is more wisdom
Then for to wepe for thy frende . which thou hast lorn for there is no bote .

And
therfore yif ye goủer/rene you by sapience put a way sorowe oute of youre
harte .

Remembre you that Iesus Sirak . seith . A man that is Ioyous in hart
and glad . hit hym consarveth floresshyng in his age .

but sothely sorowe
in hart sleeth many a man .

Salamon . seith that right as moughthes in
the shepes flese a noyen . to the clothes . And the smale wormes to the Tre
Right so . anoyeth sorowe to the hart .

wherfore vs oughte aswele in the
dethe of oure children . as in the lose of oure goodes temporales haue pacience

remembre you vppon the pacient . Iob . whan he had lost his Children and his
temporall substaunce . And in his body endured and resceived full many a
grevous tribulacion . yet seide he thus .

Oure lorde hath yeve it me . oure lorde .
hath biraft it me . Right as oure lorde hath wolde . Right so it is don I blessed be
the name of oure lorde .

To thise forsaide thynges . aunswerde Melibeus vn-
to his wif Prudence . all thy wordes qd he ben sothe . and therto profitable .
But truly myn hart is troubled with this sorowe so grevously that y notte
what to don .

Lette calle qd Prudence thy true frendes alle . and thy lynage
which that ben wise . Telleth youre case . and herkeneth what they seyne
in counseillyng and governe you aftur there sentence .

Salamon seith werke
all thynges by counsaile . and thou shalte neủer/ree repente

Then by the counsaill
of his wif Pru . dence ; this . Melibeus lette calle a grete congregacion of folke

As Surgeners . Phisiciens olde folke and yonge . and som of his olde enemyes
reconsiled as by there semblaunte . to his loue and to his grace .

and therewith
all there com som of his Neightboures that didden hym reủer/reence . more for drede
then for loue . as it happith ofte .

There come also many subtill Flaterers and
wise advocates lerned in the lawe .

and when thise folke to geder assembled
weren This Melibeus in sorowfull wise shewed them his case .

and by the mane
of his speche it semed that in harte a cruell Ire redy for to do veniaunce vppon his
foes . and sodenly desired that were shulde begynne .

But natheles yit
axed he his counsaile . vppon this matere .

A Surgien by licence and assent
of which that weren wise vppe rose . And vnto Melibeus seide as ye mowe
here .

Sir qd he as to vs wise Surgiens ꝑper/parteyneth . that we do to eủer/rey wight
the best that we can . where as we ben with holde . and to oure pacientes
that we do no damage

wherfore it happith many tyme and ofte That when .
ij. men haue eủer/reyche wounded other . o . same Surgien heleth them bothe
Wherfore vnto oure arte . it is not ꝑper/partynent to norisshe warre ne parties to supporte .

But certis as to warisshyng of youre doughter . Albe it so . shee ꝑper/parilously be wounded
we shull do so ententif bysinesse from day to nyght . that with the grace of god
she shall be hole and sounde as sone as is possible .

Almost right in the same
wise . the Phisiciens aunswerden save that they seiden . a fewe wordes more .

That right as maladies ben cured . by there contraries . right so shall man warisshe
werre . by veniaunce

hys Neightbours full of envie . his feyned frendes that
semed reconsiled . his Flaterers .

maden semblaunte of wepyng . and empeired
and aggronged mochell of this matere . impreisyng gretly . Melibe of myght
of powere of Riches and of Frendes . Dispisynge the powere of his adủer/resaries .

and seidēm vttirly . that he anon shulde wreke hym on his Foes and begynne ~

And þer for fayre ꝑper/partelote so dere
Be suche ensamplys olde . may ye lere

¶ Off dremys for y say you douteles
Þat many a dreme full sore ys for to drede
Lo in the lyff of seynt kenelme y rede
That was kenulphus sone the nobyll kyng

¶ This Caunteclere his wyngꝭes gan to bet
As man þᵗat couthe his treson . not aspye

Þᵗat plessyn yow well more be feyth

This Chaunteclere stode heygh vp on his toys

Allas þᵗat Caunteclere Fleygh fro the bemys

Of Chaunteclerys dred ⁊and of his payne

Now woll y turne to my tale a gayn

Þey rennyn so hem þought here hertis breke
